indications.summary: One randomized, double-blind, placebo-controlled trial reported a significant improvement in eye-hand coordination with astaxanthin supplementation at a dose of 6 mg once daily for eight weeks. However, the overall evidence is limited, with only one study demonstrating a benefit and no reports of harm or mixed outcomes.

studies.title: Supplementating with dietary astaxanthin combined with collagen hydrolysate improves facial elasticity and decreases matrix metalloproteinase-1 and -12 expression: a comparative study with placebo.
studies.notes: The study shows significant improvements in skin elasticity and hydration, indicating a beneficial effect of astaxanthin.
studies.evidence_tier_rationale: Placebo-controlled RCT (n=44) showed improved facial skin elasticity, but the intervention combined astaxanthin with collagen hydrolysate. Because astaxanthin’s independent effect cannot be isolated, the evidence for astaxanthin alone on skin elasticity is indirect despite clinically relevant outcomes.

indications.summary: One randomized controlled trial indicates that astaxanthin, at a dose of 2 mg daily for 12 weeks, may improve skin elasticity and hydration when combined with collagen hydrolysate. However, the overall evidence is limited, with only one study reporting a benefit and no data on potential adverse effects or long-term outcomes.

studies.title: Zinc-rich oysters as well as zinc-yeast- and astaxanthin-enriched food improved sleep efficiency and sleep onset in a randomized controlled trial of healthy individuals.
studies.notes: The study showed that astaxanthin, along with zinc, improved sleep outcomes, indicating a beneficial effect.
studies.evidence_tier_rationale: Although this was a randomized, double-blind, placebo-controlled trial with objective sleep measures, astaxanthin was only given in combination with zinc and there was no astaxanthin-only arm. Zinc-alone improved sleep outcomes, so any benefit cannot be attributed specifically to astaxanthin. Participants were healthy rather than diagnosed with insomnia, further limiting relevance to the indication.

indications.summary: There is limited evidence suggesting that astaxanthin may improve sleep efficiency and sleep onset, as indicated by one randomized controlled trial involving healthy individuals. The study reported benefits when astaxanthin was combined with zinc over a 12-week period. However, due to the small number of studies and lack of consistency in findings, the overall evidence remains weak.

studies.title: Efficacy of the natural antioxidant astaxanthin in the treatment of functional dyspepsia in patients with or without Helicobacter pylori infection: A prospective, randomized, double blind, and placebo-controlled study.
studies.notes: No overall curative effect was found, but a significant reduction in reflux symptoms was noted at the higher dose.
studies.evidence_tier_rationale: Randomized, double-blind, placebo-controlled human RCT (~132 participants) with good methods. Reflux symptoms were assessed via a GSRS reflux subscale and showed greater reduction only at the higher dose, while no difference in mean reflux scores at week 4 was found. The study population had functional dyspepsia rather than GERD, and reflux was a secondary/subscale outcome, making applicability to gastric reflux indirect despite the rigorous design.

indications.summary: The evidence for astaxanthin in treating reflux symptoms is limited and mixed. One randomized controlled trial reported no overall curative effect, but noted a significant reduction in reflux symptoms at a higher dose of 40 mg for four weeks. Overall, the findings do not support a clear benefit for this indication.

studies.title: Astaxanthin supplement improves clinical outcomes, quality of life, and inflammatory factors in patients with rheumatoid arthritis: a randomized clinical trial.
studies.notes: The study showed beneficial effects of astaxanthin on clinical outcomes and quality of life in RA patients, with significant reductions in DAS-28, HAQ, ESR, and CRP levels.
studies.evidence_tier_rationale: Triple-blind, randomized, placebo-controlled trial in RA patients (n≈60) with clinically relevant primary outcomes (DAS-28, HAQ) showing benefit, along with reductions in ESR/CRP. Methods and outcomes align directly with the indication. Confidence tempered slightly by modest sample size and short 8-week duration.

indications.summary: One randomized clinical trial reported that astaxanthin supplementation (20 mg/day for 8 weeks) improved clinical outcomes and quality of life in patients with rheumatoid arthritis, demonstrating significant reductions in disease activity and inflammatory markers. However, the evidence is limited to a single study, and further research is needed to confirm these findings and assess long-term effects and safety.

studies.title: Protective Effect of Astaxanthin on Vocal Fold Injury and Inflammation Due to Vocal Loading: A Clinical Trial.
studies.notes: The study shows that astaxanthin protects against vocal fold injury and inflammation, indicating a beneficial effect.
studies.evidence_tier_rationale: Small, uncontrolled pre–post human trial (n=10) assessing vocal function parameters after astaxanthin. No randomization/blinding and no direct oxidative stress biomarkers were measured. Clinical outcomes (phonatory parameters, GRBAS) relate to vocal fold injury/inflammation and only indirectly to oxidative stress, making the evidence for the specific indication of oxidative stress very indirect.

indications.summary: There is limited evidence suggesting that astaxanthin may have a protective effect against vocal fold injury and inflammation, based on a single clinical trial that reported a benefit with a dose of 24 mg daily for 28 days. However, due to the low quantity of studies and lack of corroborating evidence, the overall confidence in this finding is low.

studies.title: An acute, double-blind, placebo-controlled cross-over study of 320 mg and 640 mg doses of Bacopa monnieri (CDRI 08) on multitasking stress reactivity and mood.
studies.notes: The study showed positive effects on mood and cognitive performance, indicating a benefit from Bacopa monnieri supplementation.
studies.evidence_tier_rationale: Small, acute, double-blind cross-over RCT (n=17) in healthy volunteers measured mood and salivary cortisol during a lab stress task. While results suggested reduced stress reactivity, outcomes were surrogate (cortisol, transient mood) and not clinical stress symptoms over time. Thus, preliminary human evidence for stress.

studies.title: Effects of a standardized Bacopa monnieri extract on cognitive performance, anxiety, and depression in the elderly: a randomized, double-blind, placebo-controlled trial.
studies.notes: The study showed enhanced cognitive performance and reduced anxiety and depression scores in the Bacopa group compared to placebo, indicating a benefit.
studies.evidence_tier_rationale: Randomized, double-blind, placebo-controlled RCT (n=54 randomized; 48 completers) in older adults using 300 mg/day standardized Bacopa for 12 weeks found reductions in anxiety and depression versus placebo. However, stress was not a primary outcome and was not directly measured (e.g., no perceived stress scale); affective measures were secondary to the primary cognitive endpoint. Small sample and older population limit generalizability to stress specifically, making the evidence preliminary/indirect for this indication.

indications.summary: Clinical evidence from two randomized, double-blind, placebo-controlled trials suggests that Bacopa monnieri may have beneficial effects on anxiety and cognitive performance. Doses reported include 300 mg daily for 12 weeks and single doses of 320 mg and 640 mg. No adverse effects were noted in the studies, but further research is needed to confirm these findings and assess long-term safety.

studies.title: An acute, double-blind, placebo-controlled crossover study of 320 mg and 640 mg doses of a special extract of Bacopa monnieri (CDRI 08) on sustained cognitive performance.
studies.notes: The study showed that the 320 mg dose improved cognitive performance, indicating a benefit in cognitive function.
studies.evidence_tier_rationale: Double-blind, placebo-controlled crossover RCT in healthy adults with cognitive performance as the primary outcome showed benefit at 320 mg. However, the sample size was small (n=24) and effects were assessed after a single acute dose, limiting robustness and generalizability.

studies.title: Evaluating the effects of Bacopa monnieri on cognitive performance and sleep quality of patients with mild cognitive impairment: A triple-blinded, randomized, placebo-controlled trial.
studies.notes: The study showed some improvement in cognitive performance parameters but no significant effect on overall cognitive performance score or sleep quality, indicating mixed outcomes.
studies.evidence_tier_rationale: Triple-blinded randomized placebo-controlled human trial (n≈62) directly targeting cognitive performance. While methodology and relevance are good, the sample size is small and results are mixed, so it does not meet the threshold for strong, large RCT evidence.

indications.summary: The evidence for Bacopa monnieri in improving cognitive impairment is mixed. One study reported a benefit with a single dose of 320 mg, while another study found some improvements in cognitive performance parameters but no significant overall effect at a dose of 160 mg over two months. No adverse effects were reported in the studies reviewed.

studies.title: Bacopa monnieri in Patients with Parkinson's Disease: A Pilot Study.
studies.notes: The study suggests a benefit in improving emotional function in Parkinson's disease patients with the higher dose of Bacopa monnieri.
studies.evidence_tier_rationale: Pilot randomized controlled trial in Parkinson’s disease patients reported benefit on emotional function at the higher dose. It is an RCT but likely small and possibly with emotional outcomes as secondary measures, so methods and scope are not strong enough for Tier 1. Still, it is controlled human evidence directly addressing the indication.

indications.summary: There is limited evidence from a pilot study suggesting that Bacopa monnieri may improve emotional function in patients with Parkinson's disease, particularly at a higher dose of 450 mg daily. However, the evidence is based on a single study, and further research is needed to confirm these findings and assess safety and efficacy more comprehensively.

studies.title: Chronic effects of Brahmi (Bacopa monnieri) on human memory.
studies.notes: The study showed a significant effect of Brahmi on memory retention, indicating a benefit in memory function.
studies.evidence_tier_rationale: Double-blind, randomized, placebo-controlled trial in 76 adults tested memory as a primary domain and found significant improvement in retention of new information after 3 months of Bacopa monnieri. Methods and sample size are adequate for strong human evidence, though benefits were specific to retention and not other cognitive domains.

studies.title: Does Bacopa monnieri improve memory performance in older persons? Results of a randomized, placebo-controlled, double-blind trial.
studies.notes: The study demonstrated significant improvements in memory performance, indicating a benefit from Bacopa monnieri supplementation.
studies.evidence_tier_rationale: Randomized, double-blind, placebo-controlled RCT in healthy older adults with memory as a primary outcome. Statistically significant improvements on validated memory measures (AVLT) were observed with 300 mg/day Bacopa for 12 weeks. Sample size (n=98 randomized, 81 completers) and methods are adequate, supporting strong human evidence for memory improvement.

indications.summary: Clinical evidence from two randomized, placebo-controlled trials indicates that Bacopa monnieri may improve memory function, with one study using a dose of 300 mg daily for 12 weeks and another using Brahmi for three months. No studies reported harm or lack of benefit, suggesting a positive effect on memory problems; however, further research may be needed to confirm these findings and assess long-term safety.

contraindications: mild side-effects reported by 2.3% of participants

studies.title: Pharmacokinetics of Nitrate and Nitrite Following Beetroot Juice Drink Consumption.
studies.notes: The study shows mixed results regarding the impact of nitrate and nitrite on blood pressure, indicating some effects but also uncertainty about the role of nitrite.
studies.evidence_tier_rationale: This is a small PK-focused RCT in healthy adults (n=11) primarily assessing nitrate/nitrite kinetics after beetroot juice. Any blood pressure data appear exploratory, acute, and mixed, and the population is not hypertensive. Thus, evidence for the hypertension indication is indirect and very low-quality for this specific study.

indications.summary: Current evidence regarding beetroot (nitrate) supplementation for blood pressure is mixed and unclear, with a single study reporting uncertain effects on blood pressure following various doses of beetroot juice (572 mg, 280 mg, 43 mg). No studies have demonstrated a clear benefit, and the overall quality of evidence is low, indicating a need for further research to clarify these findings.

studies.title: Effects of Beetroot Juice Supplementation on Cognitive Function, Aerobic and Anaerobic Performances of Trained Male Taekwondo Athletes: A Pilot Study.
studies.notes: Cognitive function improved with BJ-400, but no significant differences in performance outcomes were observed.
studies.evidence_tier_rationale: Randomized controlled pilot in trained male athletes with acute beetroot juice doses assessed cognitive performance. Cognitive function improved at the 400 mg dose but findings were not consistent across doses. Small sample and likely secondary cognitive outcomes reduce robustness, yet the RCT design provides moderate human evidence relevant to cognitive performance.

indications.summary: Current evidence on beetroot (nitrate) supplementation for cognitive enhancement in healthy adults is limited and mixed, with one pilot study indicating potential cognitive improvement at a dose of 400 mg of beetroot juice, but lacking significant performance outcomes. Overall, the findings do not support a clear benefit, and further research is needed to clarify its effects.

studies.title: Acute effects of a chewable beetroot-based supplement on cognitive performance: a double-blind randomized placebo-controlled crossover clinical trial.
studies.notes: The study found significant improvements in cognitive functions, indicating a beneficial effect of the beetroot supplement.
studies.evidence_tier_rationale: Double-blind, randomized, placebo-controlled crossover RCT (n=44) tested a single dose of a beetroot-based nitrate supplement with cognitive performance as the primary outcome. It showed significant improvements in certain domains (memory consolidation, frontal functions/cognitive flexibility) but not others, and was an acute, modest-sized study. Methods are strong but sample size and mixed domain effects support moderate (not strong) human evidence.

studies.title: Caloric Restriction (CR) Plus High-Nitrate Beetroot Juice Does Not Amplify CR-Induced Metabolic Adaptation and Improves Vascular and Cognitive Functions in Overweight Adults: A 14-Day Pilot Randomised Trial.
studies.notes: The study shows that combining caloric restriction with beetroot juice improves vascular and cognitive functions, indicating a benefit.
studies.evidence_tier_rationale: Small, 14-day pilot randomized trial (n≈29) in overweight adults assessing cognitive function as a secondary outcome while combining caloric restriction with high-nitrate beetroot juice. Although randomized, the short duration, small sample, and combination with caloric restriction make the evidence preliminary for beetroot nitrate’s effect on cognitive performance.

indications.summary: Current evidence suggests that beetroot (nitrate) may have beneficial effects on cognitive performance, with two randomized trials reporting improvements in cognitive functions following supplementation. Doses included 3 g of chewable tablets in one study and beetroot juice over 14 days in another. However, the overall evidence is limited and further research is needed to confirm these findings and establish optimal dosing and long-term effects.

studies.title: Influence of acute beetroot juice supplementation on cold-induced vasodilation and fingertip rewarming.
studies.notes: The study found that beetroot juice supplementation accelerated rewarming of fingertip skin temperature and blood flow, indicating a beneficial effect.
studies.evidence_tier_rationale: Single small randomized crossover trial (n=20 healthy males) using acute beetroot juice ingestion showed faster fingertip rewarming and increased blood flow after cold exposure. Outcomes are physiologic surrogates (CIVD parameters, skin temperature) rather than clinical symptom relief in people with cold extremities or Raynaud’s, and the population was healthy. This supports preliminary human evidence relevant to the indication but not strong clinical evidence.

indications.summary: One randomized trial indicated that beetroot juice supplementation may improve fingertip rewarming and blood flow in individuals with cold hands. However, the evidence is limited to a single study, and further research is needed to confirm these findings and establish consistent dosing recommendations. No adverse effects were reported in the study.

studies.title: Acute effects of beetroot extract and resveratrol ingestion on cardiovascular and cardiac autonomic modulation recovery after moderate-intensity aerobic exercise in individuals with coronary artery disease: a triple-blinded, randomized, placebo-controlled trial.
studies.notes: The study showed enhanced vagal modulation and heart rate recovery but did not significantly alter HRV or cardiovascular parameters, indicating mixed outcomes.
studies.evidence_tier_rationale: Triple-blinded randomized placebo-controlled trial in CAD patients directly assessed cardiac recovery (autonomic modulation and HR recovery) after acute beetroot extract. Despite rigorous design, the sample was very small (n=14), outcomes were surrogate (HRV/HR recovery), effects were mixed with no between-protocol HRV or cardiovascular differences, and benefits were modest/unclear. Thus, moderate human evidence but with limited confidence.

indications.summary: Current evidence on beetroot (nitrate) for coronary artery disease is limited and mixed, with one randomized trial indicating enhanced vagal modulation and heart rate recovery but no significant changes in heart rate variability or cardiovascular parameters. The study utilized a single dose of 500 mg of beetroot extract. Overall, the findings do not support a clear benefit for this indication.

studies.title: Short-Term Beetroot Juice Supplementation Enhances Strength, Reduces Fatigue, and Promotes Recovery in Physically Active Individuals: A Randomized, Double-Blind, Crossover Trial.
studies.notes: The study shows significant improvements in strength performance and recovery metrics, indicating a beneficial effect of beetroot juice supplementation.
studies.evidence_tier_rationale: Randomized, double-blind, crossover human trial directly assessing athletic performance outcomes with positive results. However, likely small sample size and short duration (3 days) temper overall strength, keeping it below Tier 1 despite strong methodology.

studies.title: Beetroot juice intake positively influenced gut microbiota and inflammation but failed to improve functional outcomes in adults with long COVID: A pilot randomized controlled trial.
studies.notes: While beetroot juice improved gut microbiota and inflammatory markers, it did not significantly improve functional outcomes compared to placebo.
studies.evidence_tier_rationale: This RCT tested beetroot juice in adults with long COVID, assessing clinical functional measures (fatigue resistance, 6-minute walk, handgrip, FMD) and biological markers. It did not evaluate athletic performance in healthy or trained individuals, and functional outcomes did not differ from placebo. Therefore, it is not direct evidence for the athletic performance indication.

indications.summary: The evidence for beetroot (nitrate) supplementation in reducing fatigue is mixed. One randomized trial reported benefits in strength and recovery metrics with a dose of 450 mg of beetroot juice daily for three days, while another trial found no significant improvement in functional outcomes despite positive effects on gut microbiota and inflammation with a daily intake of 200 mL for 14 days. Overall, the findings are not consistent, and further research is needed to clarify the effects on fatigue.

studies.title: Beetroot Juice Produces Changes in Heart Rate Variability and Reduces Internal Load during Resistance Training in Men: A Randomized Double-Blind Crossover.
studies.notes: The study shows that beetroot juice supplementation reduces internal load during resistance training, indicating a beneficial effect.
studies.evidence_tier_rationale: Randomized double-blind crossover (n=11) in healthy men assessed HRV and internal load during resistance training after acute beetroot juice. Outcomes are surrogate/autonomic measures and exercise load, not direct measures of cardiac recovery or clinical recovery endpoints. Evidence is human but indirect and small, supporting very low/indirect relevance for the specified indication.

indications.summary: One randomized double-blind crossover study indicates that beetroot juice supplementation may improve heart rate variability by reducing internal load during resistance training in men. However, the evidence is limited to a single study, and further research is needed to confirm these findings and assess consistency across different populations and doses.

studies.title: Acute and short-term beetroot juice nitrate-rich ingestion enhances cardiovascular responses following aerobic exercise in postmenopausal women with arterial hypertension: A triple-blinded randomized controlled trial.
studies.notes: The study shows significant improvements in blood pressure and flow-mediated dilation, indicating a beneficial effect of beetroot nitrate on cardiovascular health.
studies.evidence_tier_rationale: Triple-blinded crossover RCT in 14 postmenopausal hypertensive women showed improved post-exercise BP and FMD after acute and short-term beetroot juice nitrate. While randomized and well-controlled, the study is small, short in duration, and uses surrogate vascular outcomes during exercise recovery rather than direct clinical measures of cardiac recovery. Findings are suggestive but preliminary and indirectly related to the stated indication.

studies.title: Acute beetroot juice reduces blood pressure in young Black and White males but not females.
studies.notes: The study found that beetroot juice supplementation significantly reduced systolic blood pressure in young adults, particularly in males.
studies.evidence_tier_rationale: The randomized, placebo-controlled trial evaluated acute effects of beetroot juice on blood pressure and cardiovascular reactivity in young adults. The outcomes were blood pressure changes, not cardiac recovery (e.g., post-exercise heart rate recovery, post-MI/surgery recovery, or cardiac functional recovery). Therefore, despite being an RCT, it does not provide direct evidence for the specified indication of cardiac recovery.

studies.title: Nitrate-Rich Beetroot Juice Reduces Blood Pressure in Tanzanian Adults with Elevated Blood Pressure: A Double-Blind Randomized Controlled Feasibility Trial.
studies.notes: The study shows a significant reduction in blood pressure, indicating a beneficial effect of beetroot nitrate supplementation.
studies.evidence_tier_rationale: This double-blind RCT evaluated beetroot nitrate for blood pressure reduction in hypertensive adults, not for cardiac recovery. No outcomes related to post-cardiac event recovery, cardiac function, or rehabilitation were assessed. Thus, it is not evidence for the specified indication.

indications.summary: Clinical evidence suggests that beetroot nitrate supplementation may reduce blood pressure, with three randomized controlled trials reporting beneficial effects. Doses reported include 800 mg (acute), 400 mg (daily for 6 days), and 12.8 mmol (juice), with significant reductions observed particularly in specific populations such as postmenopausal women and young males. However, the evidence is limited to a small number of studies, and further research is needed to confirm these findings across diverse populations.

studies.title: A randomized clinical trial of beetroot juice consumption on inflammatory markers and oxidative stress in patients with type 2 diabetes.
studies.notes: The study shows that beetroot juice reduces certain inflammatory markers, indicating a beneficial effect in patients with type 2 diabetes.
studies.evidence_tier_rationale: Single small RCT (n=52) in T2DM, randomized but unblinded with no placebo control, evaluated surrogate inflammatory biomarkers (IL-6, TNF-α, NF-κB) rather than clinical inflammatory outcomes. Some markers improved while hs-CRP and MDA did not. This supports preliminary human evidence for inflammation-related effects but not strong clinical evidence.

indications.summary: One randomized clinical trial suggests that beetroot juice (12 ml twice daily for 12 weeks) may reduce certain inflammatory markers in patients with type 2 diabetes, indicating a potential benefit. However, the evidence is limited, with only one study reporting a positive outcome and no data on adverse effects or consistency across multiple trials.

studies.title: Mitochondria-Derived Vesicles and Inflammatory Profiles of Adults with Long COVID Supplemented with Red Beetroot Juice: Secondary Analysis of a Randomized Controlled Trial.
studies.notes: The study reports a decrease in inflammatory markers, indicating a beneficial effect of beetroot juice supplementation.
studies.evidence_tier_rationale: Secondary analysis of a small, placebo-controlled RCT (n=25) in long COVID showed reductions in inflammatory biomarkers after 14 days of beetroot juice. Outcomes were surrogate (cytokines) rather than primary clinical symptoms or functional endpoints, and duration/sample size were limited. Thus, evidence is preliminary human evidence rather than strong/moderate clinical evidence.

indications.summary: One randomized controlled trial reported a beneficial effect of beetroot juice supplementation on inflammatory markers in adults with long COVID, suggesting a potential anti-inflammatory effect. However, the evidence is limited to a single study, and further research is needed to confirm these findings and assess the consistency and safety of beetroot supplementation in this context.

studies.title: Evaluation of 12-Week Standardized Beetroot Extract Supplementation in Older Participants: A Preliminary Study of Human Health Safety.
studies.notes: The study found no serious adverse events, but the outcomes regarding anthropometric, biochemical, and hemodynamic parameters were not statistically significant, indicating mixed results.
studies.evidence_tier_rationale: This randomized trial primarily evaluated safety/tolerability of beetroot extract in older adults. It did not target high insulin as a primary or clinically relevant outcome, and reported no significant changes in measured parameters. Thus, it provides no substantive evidence for beetroot (nitrate) in treating high insulin.

indications.summary: Current evidence regarding beetroot (nitrate) supplementation for insulin levels is limited and of low quality. A preliminary study reported mixed results with no significant changes in biochemical parameters after 12 weeks of daily supplementation with 20 g of beetroot extract. No serious adverse events were noted, but the lack of consistent positive outcomes suggests further research is needed.

studies.title: Acute Effects of Beetroot Juice Supplementation on Isometric Muscle Strength, Rate of Torque Development and Isometric Endurance in Young Adult Men and Women: A Randomized, Double-Blind, Controlled Cross-Over Pilot Study.
studies.notes: The study shows a positive effect on endurance in men but no effect on maximum strength, indicating mixed outcomes.
studies.evidence_tier_rationale: Randomized, double-blind, controlled cross-over trial directly testing beetroot juice on isometric strength in healthy adults. Strength was a primary outcome. The study is small (n=18) and a pilot, with mixed/mostly null effects on maximal strength (some sex-specific effects on explosive strength/endurance), but the design supports moderate-quality human evidence for this indication.

indications.summary: Current evidence regarding beetroot (nitrate) supplementation for isometric muscle strength is limited and mixed. One randomized, double-blind, controlled trial reported a positive effect on endurance but no significant impact on maximum strength, suggesting that the effects may vary by outcome measure. The typical dose reported in this study was 140 mL of concentrated beetroot juice.

studies.title: Acute Effects of Beetroot Juice Supplementation on Isometric Muscle Strength, Rate of Torque Development and Isometric Endurance in Young Adult Men and Women: A Randomized, Double-Blind, Controlled Cross-Over Pilot Study.
studies.notes: The study shows a positive effect on endurance in men but no effect on maximum strength, indicating mixed outcomes.
studies.evidence_tier_rationale: Randomized, double-blind, cross-over pilot (n=18) assessing a primary endurance outcome. While methodology is strong, the sample is small and effects were sex-specific (benefit in men only), yielding mixed results and preliminary evidence rather than robust, well-powered support.

indications.summary: The evidence regarding beetroot (nitrate) supplementation for knee extensor muscle endurance is limited and mixed, with one randomized controlled trial reporting a positive effect on endurance in men but no effect on maximum strength. The study utilized a dose of 140 mL of concentrated beetroot juice. Overall, the findings do not support a clear benefit for this indication.

studies.title: Caffeine and Beetroot Juice Optimize 1,000-m Performance: Shapley Additive Explanations Analysis.
studies.notes: The study shows that beetroot juice supplementation improves 1,000-m running performance, indicating a beneficial outcome.
studies.evidence_tier_rationale: Randomized crossover human trial directly testing beetroot juice on 1,000-m running performance with a beneficial effect on the primary performance outcome. However, likely small sample size and unclear blinding/methodological details prevent assigning Tier 1.

studies.title: Effect of Beetroot Juice Supplementation on Aerobic Capacity in Female Athletes: A Randomized Controlled Study.
studies.notes: The study found significant improvements in aerobic capacity metrics, indicating a beneficial effect of beetroot juice supplementation.
studies.evidence_tier_rationale: Randomized controlled trial in the target population (female athletes) showing benefit on aerobic capacity, which is relevant to athletic performance. However, details on sample size and blinding are not provided, and the outcomes appear to be physiological (aerobic capacity metrics) rather than direct performance measures, so the evidence is moderate rather than strong.

studies.title: The effect of eight weeks beetroot juice supplement on aerobic, anaerobic power, and field performance of soccer players.
studies.notes: The study shows significant improvements in various performance metrics, indicating a beneficial effect of beetroot juice supplementation.
studies.evidence_tier_rationale: Randomized controlled design in 40 male soccer players over 8 weeks with direct performance outcomes (aerobic/anaerobic power, field test) supports relevance to athletic performance. However, small sample size and likely lack of blinding/placebo control reduce methodological strength, placing it below Tier 1.

studies.title: Combined Effects of Citrulline Plus Nitrate-Rich Beetroot Extract Co-Supplementation on Maximal and Endurance-Strength and Aerobic Power in Trained Male Triathletes: A Randomized Double-Blind, Placebo-Controlled Trial.
studies.notes: The study showed significant improvements in aerobic power and trends in strength tests, indicating a benefit from the supplementation.
studies.evidence_tier_rationale: Although this was a randomized, double-blind, placebo-controlled trial with relevant performance outcomes in trained athletes, the intervention combined citrulline with nitrate-rich beetroot extract. Because the effect cannot be attributed specifically to beetroot (nitrate) alone, the evidence is indirect for this supplement-indication pair.

studies.title: Acute Beetroot Juice Supplementation Attenuates Morning-Associated Decrements in Supramaximal Exercise Performance in Trained Sprinters.
studies.notes: BRJ supplementation prevented morning-associated decrements in performance, indicating a beneficial effect.
studies.evidence_tier_rationale: Human randomized controlled trial in trained male sprinters assessing acute beetroot juice on exercise performance—a primary, clinically relevant outcome. Positive effect reported (attenuated morning performance decrements). Likely small sample and narrow population with acute, context-specific outcome limit generalizability and study size, placing it below strong/large RCTs.

studies.title: Multiday Beetroot Juice Ingestion Improves Some Aspects of Neuromuscular Performance in Semi-Professional, Male Handball Players: A Randomized, Double-Blind, Placebo-Controlled, Crossover Study.
studies.notes: The study found significant improvements in specific neuromuscular performance metrics with beetroot juice ingestion.
studies.evidence_tier_rationale: Randomized, double-blind, placebo-controlled crossover RCT in athletes directly testing performance outcomes relevant to athletic performance. However, the sample size is small (n=12), duration short (3 days), and benefits were limited to some neuromuscular metrics, reducing strength and generalizability despite good methods.

studies.title: Effects of acute beetroot juice intake on performance, maximal oxygen uptake, and ventilatory efficiency in well-trained master rowers: a randomized, double-blinded crossover study.
studies.notes: The study shows an improvement in time trial performance and V˙O2max, indicating a benefit from beetroot juice intake.
studies.evidence_tier_rationale: Randomized, double-blind, crossover RCT in well-trained male master rowers showed improved 2000-m time-trial performance (primary, clinically relevant athletic outcome) after acute beetroot juice intake, with indications of VO2max benefit. However, the sample size was very small (n=10), effects were reported with 90% rather than 95% confidence limits, and the population is narrow (trained male rowers), limiting generalizability. Overall, this is moderate-quality human evidence for athletic performance from a small but well-controlled trial.

studies.title: Understanding the effects of beetroot juice intake on CrossFit performance by assessing hormonal, metabolic and mechanical response: a randomized, double-blind, crossover design.
studies.notes: The study found that beetroot juice intake improved anaerobic performance and affected hormonal responses positively.
studies.evidence_tier_rationale: Randomized, double-blind, crossover RCT in 12 trained male CrossFit athletes assessed acute beetroot juice on a primary, clinically relevant performance outcome (repetitions). It showed a benefit under specific rest conditions. The high-quality design supports moderate evidence, but the small sample size, acute dosing, male-only cohort, and context-specific effect limit strength and generalizability.

studies.title: Influence of Chronic Nitrate-Rich Beetroot Juice Supplementation on the Endurance Performance of Active Winter Triathletes: A Randomized Controlled Trial.
studies.notes: The study found that BRJ supplementation improved running economy and time to exhaustion, indicating a benefit for endurance performance.
studies.evidence_tier_rationale: Randomized controlled trial with a relatively large athletic cohort (n=80) tested beetroot juice for endurance performance. It improved lab-based performance measures (running economy, time to exhaustion), which are relevant to athletic performance, but did not improve a real-world 10-km time trial. Methods/blinding details aren’t fully clear. Overall, this supports moderate human evidence rather than strong.

studies.title: Effects of an Isotonic Beetroot Drink on Power Output During Sprint Exercise and Jump Performance in Physically Active Individuals: A Randomized Crossover Trial.
studies.notes: The isotonic beetroot drink significantly improved peak power output during sprint cycling, indicating a beneficial effect on exercise performance.
studies.evidence_tier_rationale: Randomized crossover human trial in physically active adults directly tested beetroot (nitrate) on exercise performance and found improved sprint peak power. While the outcome is a primary performance measure and the design is robust, the sample size is modest (n=23) and blinding/details are unclear, so evidence is moderate rather than strong.

studies.title: Acute Effects of Beetroot Juice Supplements on Lower-Body Strength in Female Athletes: Double-Blind Crossover Randomized Trial.
studies.notes: The study shows that beetroot juice significantly improves performance in explosive force and muscular endurance tests.
studies.evidence_tier_rationale: Double-blind, randomized crossover RCT in female athletes with performance outcomes (explosive force, muscular endurance) as primary endpoints showed benefit after acute beetroot juice ingestion. However, the sample size is small (n=14) and the findings are limited to acute, lower-body strength tasks in women, preventing Tier 1 classification.

studies.title: Acute effects of various doses of nitrate-rich beetroot juice on high-intensity interval exercise responses in women: a randomized, double-blinded, placebo-controlled, crossover trial.
studies.notes: Nitrate supplementation led to significant decreases in heart rate and rating of perceived exertion during exercise, indicating a beneficial effect.
studies.evidence_tier_rationale: Double-blind, randomized, placebo-controlled crossover RCT in 13 women showed reduced heart rate and perceived exertion during high-intensity intervals after acute beetroot nitrate. However, sample size is small and outcomes are surrogate (HR, RPE) rather than direct performance metrics (e.g., time trial, power output, time to exhaustion), making the evidence preliminary for the indication of athletic performance.

studies.title: Acute Beetroot Juice Supplementation Enhances Intermittent Running Performance but Does Not Reduce Oxygen Cost of Exercise among Recreational Adults.
studies.notes: The study found that beetroot nitrate supplementation improved running performance but did not affect oxygen consumption, indicating a performance benefit.
studies.evidence_tier_rationale: Double-blind, randomized, placebo-controlled crossover RCT in recreational runners showed improved intermittent running performance after acute beetroot nitrate (~12.8 mmol) vs placebo. The indication (athletic performance) was a primary outcome. However, the sample size was small (n=12) and single-session design limits generalizability, preventing Tier 1.

studies.title: Short-term beetroot juice supplementation improves muscle speed and power but does not reduce blood pressure or oxidative stress in 65-79 y old men and women.
studies.notes: The study shows significant improvements in muscle function without adverse effects on blood pressure or oxidative stress.
studies.evidence_tier_rationale: Randomized controlled trial in older adults found improved muscle speed and power after 2 weeks of beetroot juice (nitrate). Outcomes are performance-related and appear to be primary, but the population is not athletes and sample size/power not specified. Short duration and demographic specificity limit generalizability to athletic performance, so evidence is moderate rather than strong.

studies.title: Single and combined effect of beetroot juice and caffeine intake on muscular strength, power and endurance performance in resistance-trained males.
studies.notes: The study found that beetroot juice significantly improved muscular endurance performance.
studies.evidence_tier_rationale: Triple-blind, randomized, crossover RCT in resistance-trained men testing acute beetroot juice (70 mL) with performance outcomes; reported significant improvement in muscular endurance. However, small sample size (n=13), acute single-dose design, and narrow demographic limit generalizability, so evidence is moderate rather than strong.

studies.title: Acute Effects of Beetroot Juice Supplements on Resistance Training: A Randomized Double-Blind Crossover.
studies.notes: The study found that acute supplementation of beetroot juice improved muscular endurance performance in resistance training.
studies.evidence_tier_rationale: Randomized double-blind crossover RCT directly testing beetroot juice on athletic performance (muscular endurance and movement velocity) with beneficial results. However, the sample size is small (n=12) and the effect is from an acute, single-session study, limiting overall strength despite good methods.

studies.title: The Relationship between Resistance Exercise Performance and Ventilatory Efficiency after Beetroot Juice Intake in Well-Trained Athletes.
studies.notes: The study found that beetroot juice improved both ventilatory efficiency and resistance exercise performance, indicating a beneficial effect.
studies.evidence_tier_rationale: Single small RCT (~11 well-trained males) using beetroot juice showed improved resistance exercise performance (a clinically relevant athletic performance outcome) alongside ventilatory efficiency. While randomized/controlled, the sample is small and likely crossover; performance may have been a secondary endpoint. Methods and size fall short of Tier 1, but it's direct human RCT evidence for the indication.

indications.summary: The evidence from multiple randomized controlled trials indicates that beetroot juice supplementation consistently improves exercise performance across various metrics, including aerobic capacity, strength, and endurance. Typical doses reported range from 50 mL to 140 mL of beetroot juice or equivalent nitrate content, with no studies reporting adverse effects. However, the variability in dosing and specific performance outcomes suggests that further research may be needed to fully understand the optimal use of beetroot for enhancing exercise performance.

studies.title: Eight weeks of nitrate-rich beetroot extract supplementation on fasting nitrate and nitrite levels and skeletal muscle contractile properties in postmenopausal women: Results of a randomized, placebo-controlled, and parallel trial.
studies.notes: The study shows significant improvements in muscle strength and power, indicating a beneficial effect of beetroot nitrate supplementation.
studies.evidence_tier_rationale: Randomized, double-blind, placebo-controlled trial showing significant improvements in muscle strength and power after 8 weeks of nitrate-rich beetroot extract in postmenopausal women. Strength was a primary/major outcome. However, the sample size was small (n=22) and the population specific, limiting generalizability and preventing Tier 1.

indications.summary: One randomized controlled trial indicates that daily supplementation with 20 g of nitrate-rich beetroot extract for eight weeks may improve muscle strength and power in postmenopausal women. However, the evidence is limited to a single study, and further research is needed to confirm these findings and assess long-term effects and safety.

studies.title: The effect of acute beetroot juice consumption prior to climbing on lower-body isokinetic and isometric strength, aerobic power, and muscle soreness among mountain climbers.
studies.notes: The study shows significant benefits in muscle soreness reduction and strength improvements after beetroot juice consumption.
studies.evidence_tier_rationale: Randomized, double-blind, placebo-controlled trial in climbers reported reduced delayed-onset muscle soreness after a single 70 mL beetroot juice dose. The study is well controlled but small (n=27; ~9 per arm), muscle soreness was one of several outcomes (likely secondary), and the significant effect appears mainly versus the water control rather than clearly versus placebo. This supports moderate, not strong, human evidence for this indication from this study.

indications.summary: One randomized trial indicates that acute consumption of 70 mL of beetroot juice may reduce muscle soreness and improve strength in mountain climbers. However, the evidence is limited to a single study, and further research is needed to confirm these findings and assess long-term effects and safety.

studies.title: Effect of Beetroot Juice Supplementation on Muscle Soreness and Performance Recovery after Exercise-Induced Muscle Damage in Female Volleyball Players.
studies.notes: The study found that BRJ supplementation improved muscle endurance and reduced perceived muscle soreness, indicating a beneficial effect.
studies.evidence_tier_rationale: Double-blind, randomized, placebo-controlled cross-over trial directly assessing perceived muscle soreness after EIMD with beetroot juice showed benefit. However, the sample size was very small (n=12) and limited to young female volleyball players, reducing generalizability and precluding Tier 1 strength.

indications.summary: Current evidence suggests that beetroot juice supplementation may reduce perceived muscle soreness and improve endurance following exercise-induced muscle damage, based on a single study involving doses of 50 mL four times a day for two days. However, the overall evidence is limited and further research is needed to confirm these findings and assess consistency across different populations and exercise types.

studies.title: Prior beetroot juice ingestion prevents the temporal reduction of endothelial function following acute high-intensity resistance exercise.
studies.notes: The study found that beetroot juice ingestion improved endothelial function after exercise, indicating a beneficial effect.
studies.evidence_tier_rationale: Single small RCT (n=12) in healthy young males with an acute, single dose intervention. The primary outcome was flow-mediated dilation, a surrogate marker of endothelial function, showing benefit post-exercise versus placebo. While randomized and controlled, the study is small, short-term, and context-specific (post–high-intensity exercise), limiting generalizability, thus fitting preliminary human evidence.

indications.summary: One randomized trial indicates that beetroot juice (140 mL single dose) may improve endothelial function following high-intensity resistance exercise, suggesting a potential benefit for poor blood vessel function. However, the overall evidence is limited, with only one study reporting a positive outcome and no evidence of harm or consistent findings across multiple studies.

studies.title: Increasing nitric oxide availability via ingestion of nitrate-rich beetroot juice improves vascular responsiveness in individuals with Alzheimer's Disease.
studies.notes: The study shows improvements in vascular responsiveness but indicates that acute administration may not fully restore function in Alzheimer's patients.
studies.evidence_tier_rationale: Single randomized controlled trial directly assessing endothelial/vascular responsiveness after nitrate-rich beetroot juice in humans (Alzheimer’s population). Endothelial function appears to be a primary outcome with some improvement reported, but effects were mixed and acute dosing did not fully restore function. Likely small sample and limited duration reduce robustness, yet design remains an RCT focused on the indication.

studies.title: The effect of microencapsulated watermelon rind (Citrullus lanatus) and beetroot (Beta vulgaris L.) ingestion on ischemia/reperfusion-induced endothelial dysfunction: a randomised clinical trial.
studies.notes: The study shows that beetroot co-ingestion with watermelon significantly restored macrovascular function after ischemia/reperfusion injury, indicating a beneficial effect.
studies.evidence_tier_rationale: Randomized, crossover, placebo-controlled human trial (n=12) with a single acute dose showed improved flow-mediated dilation after ischemia/reperfusion, a surrogate marker of endothelial function. However, the study is small, uses surrogate outcomes, and the effective arm included co-ingestion with watermelon rind (citrulline), limiting attribution to beetroot (nitrate) alone.

indications.summary: The evidence regarding beetroot (nitrate) for improving vascular function is mixed. One randomized trial reported a benefit in restoring macrovascular function after ischemia/reperfusion injury, while another study indicated improvements in vascular responsiveness in Alzheimer's patients but noted that acute administration may not fully restore function. No adverse effects were reported, but the overall quality and consistency of the evidence are limited.

studies.title: Prior beetroot juice ingestion offsets endothelial dysfunction following prolonged sitting.
studies.notes: The study found that beetroot juice ingestion prevented sitting-induced endothelial dysfunction, indicating a beneficial effect on vascular health.
studies.evidence_tier_rationale: Randomized controlled trial in healthy young men (n=11) with endothelial function as the primary outcome showed benefit after a single dose of beetroot juice. The study is small and acute with limited generalizability, but it is randomized and directly tests the indication.

studies.title: Acute supplementation with beetroot juice improves endothelial function in HIV-infected individuals.
studies.notes: The study found that beetroot juice improved endothelial function, indicating a beneficial effect on vascular health in HIV-infected individuals.
studies.evidence_tier_rationale: Randomized, placebo-controlled human trial showing acute improvement in endothelial function (FMD) after beetroot juice. The outcome directly matches the indication. However, the sample is small (n=13 HIV; n=18 healthy), effects are acute (120 min), and it’s a single study, limiting generalizability and durability of effect.

indications.summary: Current evidence suggests that beetroot juice may have beneficial effects on vascular health, as indicated by two randomized trials demonstrating improvements in endothelial function. The doses used in these studies include a single dose of 140 mL of beetroot juice. However, the overall evidence is limited and further research is needed to establish consistent effects and optimal dosing.

studies.title: Effects of 4 weeks of β-alanine supplementation on aerobic fitness in water polo players.
studies.notes: The study showed mixed results regarding the effectiveness of β-alanine supplementation on performance outcomes.
studies.evidence_tier_rationale: Placebo-controlled randomized trial in humans with aerobic capacity (VO2peak/critical force) as primary outcomes. Sample size was small (n=22), population was specific (male water polo players), and between-group effects were largely non-significant with mixed findings. Design supports moderate human evidence, but size, population specificity, and unclear effects prevent Tier 1.

indications.summary: Current evidence on beta-alanine supplementation for improving aerobic fitness is limited and mixed, with one study reporting unclear results. The doses used in this study ranged from 4.8 g daily for 10 days to 6.4 g daily for 18 days. No studies reported significant benefits or harms, indicating a need for further research to clarify its effectiveness in this area.

studies.title: Effect of High-Dose, Short-Duration β-Alanine Supplementation on Circulating IL-10 Concentrations During Intense Military Training.
studies.notes: The study suggests that β-alanine may enhance the anti-inflammatory response, indicating a beneficial outcome.
studies.evidence_tier_rationale: Small randomized, placebo-controlled human trial (n=20) in a military training context measured a surrogate inflammatory marker (IL-10) rather than clinical inflammation outcomes. While relevant to exercise-induced inflammation and showing a possible benefit, the short duration, small sample size, and reliance on a biomarker make the evidence preliminary.

indications.summary: One study suggests that high-dose β-alanine supplementation (12 g daily for 7 days) may enhance the anti-inflammatory response by increasing circulating IL-10 concentrations during intense military training. However, the evidence is limited and consists of a single trial, indicating a need for further research to confirm these findings and assess consistency across different populations and settings.

studies.title: Effects of 4 weeks of β-alanine supplementation on aerobic fitness in water polo players.
studies.notes: The study showed mixed results regarding the effectiveness of β-alanine supplementation on performance outcomes.
studies.evidence_tier_rationale: Randomized, placebo-controlled human trial in trained athletes assessing performance-related outcomes (VO2, critical force, 3-min all-out). However, the sample size is small (n=22) and findings were mixed, reducing strength despite appropriate design and direct relevance to athletic performance.

studies.title: Effects of Four Weeks of β-Alanine Supplementation on Repeated Sprint Ability in Water Polo Players.
studies.notes: The study found likely beneficial effects of β-alanine on repeated sprint ability, indicating a positive outcome direction.
studies.evidence_tier_rationale: Double-blind, placebo-controlled RCT in trained athletes with athletic performance (repeated sprint ability) as the primary outcome. However, the sample size is small (n=22) and conventional significance was not reached, with results based on magnitude-based inference. This supports moderate, not strong, human evidence for this specific indication.

indications.summary: The evidence on beta-alanine supplementation for athletic performance is mixed. One study reported likely beneficial effects on repeated sprint ability with doses of 4.8 g to 6.4 g daily, while another study showed unclear results regarding its effectiveness on aerobic fitness. No adverse effects were reported in the reviewed studies.

studies.title: Role of β-Alanine Supplementation on Cognitive Function, Mood, and Physical Function in Older Adults; Double-Blind Randomized Controlled Study.
studies.notes: The study showed significant improvements in cognitive function and a decrease in depression scores for participants with baseline cognitive impairment, indicating a benefit from β-alanine supplementation.
studies.evidence_tier_rationale: Double-blind randomized controlled trial (~100 older adults) assessed cognitive function as a major outcome. However, benefits were primarily observed in the subgroup with baseline cognitive impairment rather than the entire cohort, warranting a downgrade from Tier 1 to moderate evidence.

studies.title: β-Alanine supplementation improves fractional anisotropy scores in the hippocampus and amygdala in 60-80-year-old men and women.
studies.notes: The study shows a benefit in cognitive function as indicated by improved fractional anisotropy scores in brain regions associated with cognition.
studies.evidence_tier_rationale: This is a small randomized trial in older adults that assessed imaging biomarkers (fractional anisotropy in hippocampus/amygdala) and mechanistic markers rather than direct cognitive performance measures. While suggestive of neural changes relevant to cognition, the outcomes are indirect and not clinically validated for cognitive performance, making the evidence for this indication very low/indirect.

studies.title: β-Alanine supplementation increased physical performance and improved executive function following endurance exercise in middle aged individuals.
studies.notes: The study shows that beta-alanine supplementation improved exercise capacity and executive function, indicating a benefit.
studies.evidence_tier_rationale: Randomized, placebo-controlled human trial showed attenuation of post-exercise executive function decline (Stroop) with beta-alanine versus placebo. However, the study was very small (n=12), cognition was a secondary/context-specific outcome (post-endurance exercise), and a clear between-group interaction for the cognitive measure was not reported, limiting certainty.

indications.summary: Beta-alanine supplementation at a dose of 2.4 g daily has shown consistent benefits in cognitive function across three randomized controlled trials involving older adults and middle-aged individuals. Improvements were noted in cognitive performance, mood, and brain structure related to cognition, with no reported harms or instances of no benefit. However, the evidence is limited to specific populations and further research may be needed to generalize findings.

studies.title: Effects of High-Dose, Short-Duration β-Alanine Supplementation on Cognitive Function, Mood, and Circulating Brain-Derived Neurotropic Factor (BDNF) in Recreationally-Active Males Before Simulated Military Operational Stress.
studies.notes: While β-alanine did not affect cognitive function or BDNF, it showed a reduction in subjective feelings of depression, indicating mixed outcomes.
studies.evidence_tier_rationale: Human randomized controlled trial in recreationally active males reported reduced subjective depressive feelings after 14 days of high-dose beta-alanine, while other outcomes were unaffected. Mood was likely a secondary outcome, the overall results were mixed, and the intervention was short in duration, supporting moderate but not strong evidence for mood improvement.

indications.summary: The evidence for beta-alanine in the treatment of depression is limited and mixed, with one study reporting a reduction in subjective feelings of depression after high-dose supplementation (12 g/day for 14 days), but no consistent benefits observed across studies. Overall, the findings do not support a clear efficacy for beta-alanine in this indication.

studies.title: Effects of acute beta-alanine supplementation on post-exertion rating of perceived exertion, heart rate, blood lactate, and physical performance on the 6-minute race test in middle-distance runners.
studies.notes: The study showed a decrease in post-exertion RPE with both doses, but no significant differences in physical performance outcomes, indicating mixed results.
studies.evidence_tier_rationale: The RCT evaluated acute beta-alanine in healthy runners with outcomes of RPE, heart rate, blood lactate, and 6-minute run distance. It did not assess cardiac recovery as a clinical condition (e.g., post-cardiac event recovery or heart rate recovery as a primary endpoint), and there were no significant heart rate effects. Thus, the study is not testing the supplement for the specified indication, providing no direct clinical evidence for cardiac recovery.

indications.summary: The evidence regarding beta-alanine for reducing high perceived exertion during exercise is mixed and unclear, based on one study that reported a decrease in post-exertion rating of perceived exertion (RPE) with doses of 30 mg and 45 mg taken as single doses 72 hours apart, but found no significant differences in physical performance outcomes. Overall, the findings do not support a clear benefit for this indication.

studies.title: Effects of Acute Beta-Alanine Ingestion and Immersion-Plus-Exercise on Connectedness to Nature and Perceived Pain.
studies.notes: The study shows an increase in perceived pain sensations with beta-alanine, but also an increase in connectedness to nature, leading to mixed outcomes.
studies.evidence_tier_rationale: Double-blind, placebo-controlled crossover RCT (n=20) with acute 6.4 g beta-alanine assessed perceived pain (McGill Pain Questionnaire) and found increased pain sensations. Methods are rigorous but sample is small and pain was likely a secondary/exploratory outcome within a study primarily focused on connectedness to nature, so evidence is moderate rather than strong.

indications.summary: The evidence regarding beta-alanine for increased pain sensitivity is limited and mixed. One study reported an increase in perceived pain sensations with a single dose of 6.4 g, but also noted a positive effect on connectedness to nature, leading to unclear overall outcomes. No studies demonstrated a clear benefit or harm associated with beta-alanine for this indication.

studies.title: Distinct Effects of Repeated-Sprint Training in Normobaric Hypoxia and β-Alanine Supplementation.
studies.notes: The study showed that while β-alanine maintained anaerobic working capacity, it did not provide additional benefits for fatigue or repeated-sprint performance.
studies.evidence_tier_rationale: Human randomized controlled trial with aerobic performance as a primary outcome and a BA vs placebo comparison. Sample size is modest and results showed no BA benefit for aerobic capacity (effect observed only for anaerobic working capacity). This provides moderate-quality, directly relevant human evidence with null findings for the indication.

studies.title: Additive Benefits of β-Alanine Supplementation and Sprint-Interval Training.
studies.notes: The study shows that β-alanine supplementation improves training intensity and performance outcomes, indicating a beneficial effect.
studies.evidence_tier_rationale: Placebo-controlled, double-blind RCT in trained cyclists (n=14). Aerobic capacity (VO2peak) was measured but as a secondary outcome and showed no additional benefit from beta-alanine versus placebo. While methods are strong, the small sample and secondary status of the aerobic capacity outcome place this as moderate human evidence relevant to the indication, with null effect on the target outcome.

studies.title: Physiological and performance adaptations to beta alanine supplementation and short sprint interval training in volleyball players.
studies.notes: The study showed significant improvements in various performance metrics, indicating a beneficial effect of Beta-Alanine supplementation.
studies.evidence_tier_rationale: Randomized, placebo-controlled human trial (n=20) measured cardiorespiratory fitness alongside other performance outcomes. Aerobic capacity was assessed but appears to have been a secondary outcome, and beta-alanine did not outperform placebo for this measure. Thus, there is moderate human evidence relevant to the indication, but small sample size and lack of a clear benefit for aerobic capacity lower confidence.

studies.title: Effects of Combined Versus Single Supplementation of Creatine, Beta-Alanine, and L-Citrulline During Short Sprint Interval Training on Basketball Players' Performance: A Double-Blind Randomized Placebo-Controlled Trial.
studies.notes: The study shows significant improvements in physical and physiological performance in basketball players using beta-alanine, indicating a benefit from supplementation.
studies.evidence_tier_rationale: Double-blind, randomized, placebo-controlled trial with a beta-alanine-only arm (4.8 g/day, 28 days) measured cardiorespiratory fitness (a proxy for aerobic capacity) and reported greater improvements vs placebo. However, the per-arm sample size was small (n≈8), multiple outcomes were tested, and aerobic capacity was not clearly a primary endpoint, limiting strength despite the RCT design.

studies.title: One-Week High-Dose β-Alanine Loading Improves World Tour Cyclists' Time-Trial Performance.
studies.notes: The study shows a significant improvement in cycling performance metrics with β-alanine supplementation.
studies.evidence_tier_rationale: Randomized placebo-controlled trial showing improved 10-min time-trial power (a primary, clinically relevant endurance performance outcome) in world-tour cyclists after 7 days of high-dose sustained-release β-alanine. However, the sample size was very small (n=12 total), duration short, and population highly specific, limiting generalizability and preventing Tier 1 classification. Outcome pertains to aerobic performance but does not directly measure VO2max or classic aerobic capacity metrics.

studies.title: [Effects of acute supplementation with beta-alanine on a limited time test at maximum aerobic speed on endurance athletes].
studies.notes: The study found significant improvements in execution time during the limited time test, indicating a benefit from beta-alanine supplementation.
studies.evidence_tier_rationale: Small double-blind randomized cross-over trial (n=11) showed a modest improvement in time during a test at maximal aerobic speed after acute beta-alanine. While methods are sound, the sample is small, the effect size and p-value are modest, distance was not significant, and the outcome assesses performance at a given intensity rather than directly measuring aerobic capacity (e.g., VO2max). Thus, evidence is preliminary and indirect for the aerobic capacity indication.

studies.title: Beta-Alanine Supplementation Improves Throwing Velocities in Repeated Sprint Ability and 200-m Swimming Performance in Young Water Polo Players.
studies.notes: The study shows likely beneficial effects of beta-alanine on performance metrics in young athletes.
studies.evidence_tier_rationale: Although this is a randomized controlled trial in young athletes, the outcomes assessed (200-m swim performance, repeated-sprint ability, throwing velocity, eggbeater kicks) are sport-specific performance metrics and do not directly measure aerobic capacity (e.g., VO2max, ventilatory thresholds, prolonged time trial). Therefore, it does not provide direct evidence for the indication of aerobic capacity.

studies.title: Beta-alanine supplementation enhances judo-related performance in highly-trained athletes.
studies.notes: Beta-alanine supplementation improved performance outcomes in judo athletes, indicating a beneficial effect.
studies.evidence_tier_rationale: Although this is a randomized controlled trial showing improved judo performance, the outcomes were sport-specific (throws in SJFT/randori) and did not directly assess aerobic capacity (e.g., VO2max, aerobic time-to-exhaustion). Therefore, it does not constitute direct evidence for the indication of aerobic capacity.

studies.title: Effects of Acute Carnosine and β-Alanine on Isometric Force and Jumping Performance.
studies.notes: The study shows that Carn-BA supplementation improved MVC and CMJ performance, indicating a benefit for athletic performance.
studies.evidence_tier_rationale: This small RCT tested an acute combination of L-carnosine plus beta-alanine (not beta-alanine alone) and measured isometric force, countermovement jump performance, RPE, lactate, and muscle pain during a 45-second jumping task. These outcomes reflect short-duration neuromuscular/anaerobic performance, not aerobic capacity (no VO2max, endurance time-trial, or time-to-exhaustion measures). Thus it does not provide direct evidence for beta-alanine on aerobic capacity.

studies.title: Effect of 8-Week β-Alanine Supplementation on CRP, IL-6, Body Composition, and Bio-Motor Abilities in Elite Male Basketball Players.
studies.notes: The study showed significant decreases in CRP and IL-6, indicating a beneficial effect of β-alanine supplementation on inflammatory markers and performance.
studies.evidence_tier_rationale: Although this is a randomized controlled trial, the measured outcomes were inflammatory markers (CRP, IL-6), body composition, and anaerobic peak power. No direct aerobic capacity endpoints (e.g., VO2max, time-to-exhaustion, aerobic performance tests) were reported, so it does not provide actual evidence for the aerobic capacity indication.

studies.title: Effects of 28-Day Beta-Alanine Supplementation on Isokinetic Exercise Performance and Body Composition in Female Masters Athletes.
studies.notes: The study found significant improvements in lower-body exercise performance metrics, indicating a benefit from Beta-alanine supplementation.
studies.evidence_tier_rationale: Although this was a randomized, double-blind trial, the outcomes were isokinetic strength/torque and total work, not measures of aerobic capacity (e.g., VO2max, time-to-exhaustion, aerobic time trial). Therefore, it does not provide direct evidence for the indication of aerobic capacity.

studies.title: Effects of β-alanine supplementation on physical performance, cognition, endocrine function, and inflammation during a 24 h simulated military operation.
studies.notes: The study shows mixed results with some benefits in cognition and physical performance, but no significant changes in endocrine function or inflammation.
studies.evidence_tier_rationale: Small human RCT (n=19) in a military setting with mixed results. Aerobic capacity was not a primary outcome and no direct measures (e.g., VO2max) were assessed; only a 1 km run time under fatigue showed a borderline difference. Findings are indirect and exploratory for aerobic capacity, supporting only preliminary evidence.

studies.title: Effects of Four Weeks of Beta-Alanine Supplementation Combined with One Week of Creatine Loading on Physical and Cognitive Performance in Military Personnel.
studies.notes: The study showed significant improvements in physical and cognitive performance with beta-alanine supplementation.
studies.evidence_tier_rationale: This RCT compared beta-alanine plus creatine versus beta-alanine plus placebo; both groups received beta-alanine, so it does not test beta-alanine alone against control. Reported benefits pertain to power/strength and cognition, not clearly to aerobic capacity (no VO2max or equivalent primary aerobic outcomes reported). Thus, it is not actual evidence for beta-alanine’s effect on aerobic capacity.

studies.title: The effect of β-alanine supplementation on cycling time trials of different length.
studies.notes: The study found significant increases in time to exhaustion and a likely benefit to 4-km time trial performance, indicating a positive outcome from β-alanine supplementation.
studies.evidence_tier_rationale: Double-blind, placebo-controlled RCT in trained cyclists with performance outcomes directly relevant to aerobic capacity. Shows significant improvement in time to exhaustion and likely benefit for 4-km time trial, but no effect on 1- or 10-km trials. Small sample size (n=14) limits power, so evidence is moderate rather than strong.

studies.title: β-Alanine Supplementation's Improvement of High-Intensity Game Activities in Water Polo.
studies.notes: The study shows a significant improvement in sprint numbers and a likely beneficial effect on distance covered and time spent in higher speed zones.
studies.evidence_tier_rationale: Double-blind, placebo-controlled RCT but very small (n=11) and conducted in a niche athletic population. Outcomes were sport-specific performance metrics (sprint counts, distance/time in speed zones) rather than direct measures of aerobic capacity (e.g., VO2max, aerobic time-to-exhaustion). While results suggest benefit, they provide only indirect, preliminary evidence for the aerobic capacity indication.

studies.title: Acute Supplementation with Beta-Alanine Improves Performance in Aerobic-Anaerobic Transition Zones in Endurance Athletes.
studies.notes: The study shows that both doses of beta-alanine significantly improved physical performance, indicating a benefit.
studies.evidence_tier_rationale: Single small randomized controlled trial (n=12) in endurance athletes assessing maximal aerobic speed (a performance proxy for aerobic capacity) after acute beta-alanine dosing showed benefit. While the outcome is relevant and the design is randomized, the sample is small, population narrow, and the acute dosing is atypical for beta-alanine, limiting generalizability and strength to moderate rather than strong evidence.

studies.title: The Effect of Beta-Alanine versus Alkaline Agent Supplementation Combined with Branched-Chain Amino Acids and Creatine Malate in Highly-Trained Sprinters and Endurance Athletes: A Randomized Double-Blind Crossover Study.
studies.notes: The study shows a benefit in increasing fat-free mass and exercise adaptation with beta-alanine supplementation.
studies.evidence_tier_rationale: Double-blind randomized crossover in elite athletes (n=31) suggests performance/adaptation benefits, but the intervention combined beta-alanine with BCAAs and creatine malate and compared against an alkaline agent plus the same co-supplements, confounding attribution to beta-alanine. Aerobic capacity does not appear to be a primary outcome; reported benefits emphasize fat-free mass and exercise adaptation rather than direct VO2max/clear aerobic metrics. Small sample and elite cohort further limit generalizability.

studies.title: Acute carnosine and β-alanine supplementation increase the compensated part of the ventilation versus work rate relationship during a ramp incremental cycle test in physically active men.
studies.notes: The study showed a positive effect of acute β-alanine supplementation on exercise performance, specifically on the compensated part of the ventilation during exercise.
studies.evidence_tier_rationale: Double-blind RCT but very small (n=10) and used an acute combined carnosine+beta-alanine dose rather than beta-alanine alone. The positive finding was on a surrogate ventilatory parameter (compensated portion between VT1 and VT2), with no change in peak exercise or ventilatory thresholds. This provides preliminary, indirect evidence for aerobic capacity rather than a clear clinical performance outcome.

studies.title: Effects of β-alanine supplementation during a 5-week strength training program: a randomized, controlled study.
studies.notes: The study found significant improvements in power output and strength gains in the β-alanine group compared to placebo.
studies.evidence_tier_rationale: Although this was a randomized controlled trial, it evaluated strength/power outcomes (1RM, power, velocity, jump performance) during resistance training, not aerobic capacity (e.g., VO2max, aerobic endurance). Thus it does not provide direct evidence for the aerobic capacity indication.

studies.title: β-Alanine supplementation elevates intramuscular carnosine content and attenuates fatigue in men and women similarly but does not change muscle l-histidine content.
studies.notes: The study shows that Beta-alanine supplementation likely increases muscle carnosine and reduces fatigue, indicating a benefit.
studies.evidence_tier_rationale: Although this is an RCT showing increased muscle carnosine and reduced fatigue, the outcomes pertain to buffering and high-intensity fatigue (anaerobic performance) rather than aerobic capacity (e.g., VO2max, aerobic time-to-exhaustion). The study does not directly test or report aerobic capacity outcomes, making it not actual evidence for this specific indication.

studies.title: β-Alanine supplementation slightly enhances repeated plyometric performance after high-intensity training in humans.
studies.notes: The study shows a slight improvement in explosive force and performance metrics, indicating a benefit from β-Alanine supplementation.
studies.evidence_tier_rationale: This RCT assessed β-alanine effects on plyometric performance (jump height, repeated CMJ fatigue test) and blood lactate response, not on aerobic capacity (e.g., VO2max/VO2peak, aerobic time trial, submaximal economy). The outcomes are primarily anaerobic/explosive performance metrics. Therefore, it does not provide direct evidence for the indication of aerobic capacity.

studies.title: Incremental effects of 28 days of beta-alanine supplementation on high-intensity cycling performance and blood lactate in masters female cyclists.
studies.notes: The study found significant improvements in time to exhaustion and total work completed, indicating a benefit from beta-alanine supplementation.
studies.evidence_tier_rationale: Double-blind randomized controlled trial in humans showing significant improvements in time to exhaustion and total work. However, the sample size is small (n=22) and limited to masters female cyclists, and outcomes reflect high-intensity performance rather than direct measures of aerobic capacity (e.g., VO2max), reducing generalizability and directness.

studies.title: Twenty-four Weeks of β-Alanine Supplementation on Carnosine Content, Related Genes, and Exercise.
studies.notes: The study shows significant benefits in muscle carnosine content and exercise capacity with β-alanine supplementation.
studies.evidence_tier_rationale: This RCT assessed high-intensity cycling capacity (CCT110%) and muscle carnosine, not aerobic capacity measures (e.g., VO2max, ventilatory/lactate thresholds, or aerobic time-trial performance). Thus, despite performance benefits, the study does not directly test beta-alanine for the specified indication of aerobic capacity.

studies.title: Effect of high-dose β-Alanine supplementation on uphill cycling performance in World Tour cyclists: A randomised controlled trial.
studies.notes: The study demonstrated a benefit in cycling performance with high-dose β-alanine supplementation, indicating its effectiveness as an ergogenic aid.
studies.evidence_tier_rationale: Double-blind RCT in elite cyclists (n=11) showed improved uphill time-trial performance with high-dose beta-alanine, but did not assess aerobic capacity (e.g., VO2max) as an outcome. Performance/time-trial metrics are not direct measures of aerobic capacity, so this study does not provide direct evidence for the specified indication.

studies.title: Effects of β-Alanine Supplementation on Subjects Performing High-Intensity Functional Training.
studies.notes: The study showed significant improvements in vertical jump and power performance, indicating a benefit from β-alanine supplementation.
studies.evidence_tier_rationale: Although this is a human RCT, the measured outcomes were vertical jump and power (anaerobic performance), not aerobic capacity metrics (e.g., VO2max, time-to-exhaustion, ventilatory threshold). Therefore, the study does not provide direct evidence for the supplement’s effect on aerobic capacity.

studies.title: Beta-alanine supplementation improves isometric, but not isotonic or isokinetic strength endurance in recreationally strength-trained young men.
studies.notes: The study shows a significant improvement in isometric endurance performance with beta-alanine supplementation.
studies.evidence_tier_rationale: This double-blind RCT evaluated isometric/isotonic/isokinetic strength endurance in recreationally strength-trained men, not aerobic capacity (e.g., VO2max, aerobic time-to-exhaustion). The reported benefit in isometric endurance does not address the specified indication of aerobic capacity, so it is not direct evidence for this condition.
