studies.notes: The study found that the choline-based supplement improved explosive strength and delayed fatigue onset, indicating a beneficial outcome.

indications.summary: The evidence for choline supplementation in improving low exercise performance is limited but suggests potential benefits. Two studies reported positive outcomes, with one using 2.5 g of Neptune krill oil daily for 12 weeks and another utilizing a single dose of a multi-ingredient choline supplement before testing. However, the overall quality and consistency of the evidence are low, and further research is needed to confirm these findings.

studies.title: The Effect of Choline and Resistance Training on Strength and Lean Mass in Older Adults.
studies.notes: The study shows that higher choline intake is associated with better strength gains and muscle quality in older adults undergoing resistance training.

indications.summary: One randomized trial indicates that higher choline intake (ranging from 0.7 to 7.5 mg/kg lean body mass per day) may improve muscle strength and quality in older adults participating in resistance training. However, the evidence is limited to a single study, and further research is needed to confirm these findings and assess long-term effects and safety.

studies.title: Comparison between Egg Intake versus Choline Supplementation on Gut Microbiota and Plasma Carotenoids in Subjects with Metabolic Syndrome.
studies.notes: The study shows significant increases in plasma lutein and zeaxanthin after egg intake, indicating a benefit related to oxidative stress protection.
studies.evidence_tier_rationale: This randomized crossover trial compared eggs (phosphatidylcholine) vs choline bitartrate and evaluated gut microbiota, TMAO, and plasma carotenoids. HDL was not a prespecified outcome and no treatment effect on HDL was reported; only a non-interventional correlation between bacterial diversity and HDL was mentioned. Thus, the study does not provide direct evidence on choline for low HDL.

indications.summary: One randomized trial has shown that choline supplementation (400 mg daily for 4 weeks) may provide benefits related to oxidative stress protection in individuals with metabolic syndrome, as indicated by increased plasma lutein and zeaxanthin levels. However, the evidence is limited, with only one study reporting a benefit and no adverse effects noted. Further research is needed to establish the consistency and robustness of these findings.

studies.title: An α7 nAChR approach for the baseline-dependent modulation of deviance detection in schizophrenia: A pilot study assessing the combined effect of CDP-choline and galantamine.
studies.notes: The study showed mixed results with significant improvements in specific subgroups but no main treatment effect overall.

studies.title: CDP-choline and galantamine, a personalized α7 nicotinic acetylcholine receptor targeted treatment for the modulation of speech MMN indexed deviance detection in healthy volunteers: a pilot study.
studies.notes: The study shows an increase in MMN generation, indicating a benefit from the treatment.

indications.summary: The evidence for choline, specifically CDP-choline, in the treatment of schizophrenia is limited and mixed. One pilot study reported a benefit in generating mismatch negativity (MMN) in healthy volunteers, while another study showed mixed results with significant improvements in specific subgroups but no overall main treatment effect. Doses of 500 mg were consistently reported, but the overall quality of evidence is low and further research is needed.

contraindications: fishy body odor in 36% of choline group

studies.title: Randomised clinical trial: mucosal protection combined with acid suppression in the treatment of non-erosive reflux disease - efficacy of Esoxx, a hyaluronic acid-chondroitin sulphate based bioadhesive formulation.
studies.notes: The study showed a significant improvement in symptoms and quality of life with Esoxx compared to placebo, indicating a benefit.

indications.summary: There is limited evidence suggesting that a hyaluronic acid-chondroitin sulfate formulation (Esoxx) may improve symptoms and quality of life in patients with non-erosive reflux disease, based on one randomized clinical trial. No adverse effects or harm were reported in the study, but the overall evidence is sparse and further research is needed to confirm these findings.

studies.title: Comparison of the effects of sodium hyaluronate-chondroitin sulphate and corticosteroid in the treatment of lateral epicondylitis: a prospective randomized trial.
studies.notes: The study shows that HA + CS provides better pain relief compared to triamcinolone, indicating a benefit.
studies.evidence_tier_rationale: Human RCT in lateral epicondylitis showed benefit, but the intervention was a hyaluronic acid + chondroitin sulfate combination versus corticosteroid, so the effect cannot be attributed to chondroitin alone. Small sample size (~57) and unclear blinding further limit quality. Injection formulation also limits generalizability to typical supplement use.

indications.summary: There is limited evidence suggesting that a combination of sodium hyaluronate and chondroitin sulfate may provide better pain relief in patients with lateral epicondylitis compared to corticosteroids, based on one randomized trial. However, the overall quality and quantity of evidence are low, and further studies are needed to confirm these findings and assess long-term effects and safety.

studies.title: Effects of glucosamine-chondroitin combination on synovial fluid IL-1β, IL-6, TNF-α and PGE2 levels in internal derangements of temporomandibular joint.
studies.notes: The study showed significant improvement in maximum mouth opening and reduction in inflammatory cytokines in the study group, indicating a benefit from the chondroitin intervention.

indications.summary: One randomized trial reported a benefit of chondroitin (1200 mg daily for 8 weeks) in improving maximum mouth opening and reducing inflammatory cytokines in patients with temporomandibular joint disorders. However, the overall evidence is limited, with only one study available, and no adverse effects were noted. Further research is needed to confirm these findings and establish the efficacy of chondroitin for jaw pain.

studies.title: Effectiveness of a Dietary Supplement Containing Hydrolyzed Collagen, Chondroitin Sulfate, and Glucosamine in Pain Reduction and Functional Capacity in Osteoarthritis Patients.

doses.formulation: dietary supplement containing hydrolyzed gelatin, chondroitin sulfate, glucosamine sulfate, and other extracts

studies.notes: The study shows significant reductions in pain and improvements in functional capacity, indicating a beneficial effect of the supplement.

studies.title: Differences in Serum Biomarkers Between Combined Glucosamine and Chondroitin Versus Celecoxib in a Randomized, Double-blind Trial in Osteoarthritis Patients.

doses.formulation: combined glucosamine hydrochloride plus chondroitin sulfate

studies.notes: The study shows that GH+CS reduces IL-6, indicating a beneficial effect on inflammation in osteoarthritis patients.
studies.evidence_tier_rationale: Randomized, double-blind human trial in osteoarthritis patients, but the outcomes were serum inflammatory biomarkers (e.g., IL-6 reduction) rather than clinical joint pain or function. The supplement was a combination of glucosamine plus chondroitin, making attribution to chondroitin alone uncertain. As a result, this provides preliminary human evidence based on surrogate endpoints rather than direct clinical outcomes.

studies.title: Comparison of the efficacy and tolerability of chondroitin plus glucosamine and D-002 (beeswax alcohols) in subjects with osteoarthritis symptoms.
studies.notes: The study shows significant reductions in OA symptoms, indicating a benefit from the treatment.

indications.summary: Clinical evidence from three randomized trials indicates that chondroitin, often combined with glucosamine, may provide benefits in reducing joint pain and improving functional capacity in patients with osteoarthritis. Doses reported include 375 mg once daily and 1500 mg daily, with no studies indicating harm or lack of benefit. However, the overall quality of evidence and long-term effects remain unclear, necessitating further research.

studies.title: Phonophoretic application of a glucosamine and chondroitin nanoemulsion for treatment of knee chondropathies.
studies.notes: The study showed some pain reduction and recovery in patients, but results were not statistically significant.

indications.summary: The evidence for chondroitin in the treatment of knee chondropathy is low quality, with a single study reporting mixed and unclear outcomes regarding pain reduction and recovery, though results were not statistically significant. No consistent dose ranges were reported, and there were no documented harms associated with its use.

studies.title: Effect of chondroitin sulfate on soluble biomarkers of osteoarthritis: a method to analyze and interpret the results from an open-label trial in unilateral knee osteoarthritis patients.
studies.notes: The study shows significant improvements in pain and function, indicating a beneficial effect of chondroitin sulfate.

studies.title: Multicenter, randomized, double-blind clinical trial to evaluate efficacy and safety of combined glucosamine sulfate and chondroitin sulfate capsules for treating knee osteoarthritis.
studies.notes: The study demonstrated non-inferiority of the new formulation compared to the control, indicating a benefit in treating knee OA.

studies.title: Effect of chondroitin sulphate on synovitis of knee osteoarthritic patients.
studies.notes: Chondroitin sulfate showed a significant reduction in synovitis and improvement in pain, indicating a beneficial effect.

studies.title: Combined glucosamine and chondroitin sulfate, once or three times daily, provides clinically relevant analgesia in knee osteoarthritis.
studies.notes: The study shows significant pain reduction in knee osteoarthritis patients, indicating a benefit from the treatment.

studies.title: Glucosamine and chondroitin for knee osteoarthritis: a double-blind randomised placebo-controlled clinical trial evaluating single and combination regimens.
studies.notes: The study showed a significant reduction in joint space narrowing but no significant symptomatic benefit for knee pain compared to placebo.

studies.title: Effectiveness of Cucumis sativus extract versus glucosamine-chondroitin in the management of moderate osteoarthritis: a randomized controlled trial.
studies.notes: The study showed a greater reduction in pain scores for the CSE group compared to the GC group, indicating a benefit from the intervention.

studies.title: Effects of N-acetyl glucosamine and chondroitin sulfate supplementation on knee pain and self-reported knee function in middle-aged and older Japanese adults: a randomized, double-blind, placebo-controlled trial.
studies.notes: The study showed a positive effect on self-reported knee function and household physical activity, indicating a benefit from the supplementation.

indications.summary: The evidence from randomized trials indicates that chondroitin sulfate may provide benefits in reducing knee pain and improving function in patients with osteoarthritis, with several studies reporting positive outcomes at doses such as 800 mg daily and 400 mg three times daily. However, one study showed mixed results, indicating no significant symptomatic benefit despite some structural improvements, suggesting that the overall evidence is promising but not unequivocal. No significant harms were reported.

studies.title: [Clinical use of chondroitin sulfate in patients with osteoarthritis in geriatric practice].
studies.notes: The study shows sufficient decrease in pain and functional disorders, indicating a benefit from chondroitin sulfate therapy.

studies.title: Cost-Effectiveness Analysis of Pharmaceutical-Grade Chondroitin Sulfate for Knee Osteoarthritis Based on Individual Patient Data from a Randomized Clinical Trial.
studies.notes: The study demonstrated that chondroitin sulfate was superior to placebo in reducing pain and improving function in patients with knee osteoarthritis, indicating a beneficial outcome.
studies.evidence_tier_rationale: Based on individual patient data from a randomized, placebo-controlled trial (~400 participants) of pharmaceutical-grade chondroitin sulfate 800 mg/day for 6 months in knee osteoarthritis, which showed superiority over placebo in reducing pain and improving function—major clinical outcomes directly relevant to joint pain. Although the paper reports a cost-effectiveness analysis, it relies on RCT data demonstrating clinically meaningful pain benefits.

studies.title: Treatment of knee osteoarthritis with a new formulation of a fixed-dose combination of glucosamine sulfate and bovine chondroitin: a multicenter, randomized, single-blind, non-inferiority clinical trial.
studies.notes: The study demonstrated non-inferiority of the GS/CS combination compared to the reference product, indicating a benefit in treating knee osteoarthritis.
studies.evidence_tier_rationale: Large multicenter randomized controlled trial with a primary clinical pain outcome (WOMAC pain) showing benefit over 24 weeks. However, it was single-blind, used a non-inferiority design versus an active reference, and tested a fixed-dose combination of chondroitin plus glucosamine rather than chondroitin alone, making the evidence indirect for chondroitin as a standalone supplement for joint pain.

studies.title: Effect of an oral preparation containing hyaluronic acid, chondroitin sulfate, hydrolyzed collagen type II and hydrolyzed keratin on synovial fluid features and clinical indices in knee osteoarthritis. A pilot study.
studies.notes: The study showed significant improvements in clinical indices for the treatment group, indicating a beneficial effect of the supplement.

studies.title: Effectiveness of Non-Animal Chondroitin Sulfate Supplementation in the Treatment of Moderate Knee Osteoarthritis in a Group of Overweight Subjects: A Randomized, Double-Blind, Placebo-Controlled Pilot Study.
studies.notes: The study shows significant improvements in knee function, pain, and inflammation markers, indicating a beneficial effect of chondroitin supplementation.

studies.title: Pharmaceutical-grade chondroitin sulfate in the management of knee osteoarthritis.
studies.notes: The study shows that chondroitin sulfate is superior to placebo and similar to celecoxib in reducing pain and improving function.
studies.evidence_tier_rationale: Large, well-designed double-blind RCT (n≈604) in knee osteoarthritis showed pharmaceutical-grade chondroitin sulfate 800 mg/day reduced pain and improved function versus placebo and was similar to celecoxib. Pain/function were primary clinical outcomes, directly relevant to joint pain. Minor caveat: results pertain to pharmaceutical-grade CS and OA-related joint pain specifically.

studies.title: Efficacy of Chondroitin Sulfate for Painful Knee Osteoarthritis: A One-Year, Randomized, Double-Blind, Multicenter Clinical Study in Japan.
studies.notes: The study found that chondroitin sulfate improved pain control in knee osteoarthritis, indicating a beneficial outcome.

studies.title: Comparison of Glucosamine-Chondroitin Sulfate with and without Methylsulfonylmethane in Grade I-II Knee Osteoarthritis: A Double Blind Randomized Controlled Trial.
studies.notes: The study found significant clinical benefits for the combination treatment including chondroitin for knee osteoarthritis.

studies.title: Pharmaceutical-grade Chondroitin sulfate is as effective as celecoxib and superior to placebo in symptomatic knee osteoarthritis: the ChONdroitin versus CElecoxib versus Placebo Trial (CONCEPT).
studies.notes: Chondroitin sulfate showed significant pain reduction and improvement in function compared to placebo, indicating a beneficial effect.

studies.title: Chondroitin sulfate efficacy versus celecoxib on knee osteoarthritis structural changes using magnetic resonance imaging: a 2-year multicentre exploratory study.
studies.notes: The study demonstrated that chondroitin sulfate significantly reduced cartilage volume loss compared to celecoxib, indicating a benefit for knee osteoarthritis patients.

studies.title: The efficacy and safety of a combination of glucosamine hydrochloride, chondroitin sulfate and bio-curcumin with exercise in the treatment of knee osteoarthritis: a randomized, double-blind, placebo-controlled study.
studies.notes: The study found significant improvements in pain and function in knee OA patients receiving the supplement.

studies.title: Combined chondroitin sulfate and glucosamine for painful knee osteoarthritis: a multicentre, randomised, double-blind, non-inferiority trial versus celecoxib.
studies.notes: The study demonstrated comparable efficacy of chondroitin plus glucosamine to celecoxib in reducing pain and improving function in knee osteoarthritis.

studies.title: [Comparative efficacy of a combination of undenatured type II collagen, Boswellic acids, methylsulfonylmethane, vitamins C and D3 and a combination of chondroitin sulfate and glucosamine hydrochloride in the treatment of primary osteoarthritis of the knee joint].
studies.notes: The study showed improvements in WOMAC index and pain, but no significant intergroup differences, indicating mixed outcomes.

indications.summary: Chondroitin sulfate has been associated with beneficial effects in reducing knee pain and improving function in patients with osteoarthritis, as evidenced by multiple randomized trials. Typical doses reported range from 600 mg to 1200 mg daily, with no studies indicating significant harm. However, the evidence is primarily positive with one study showing mixed outcomes, suggesting that while chondroitin sulfate may be effective, results can vary among individuals.

studies.title: Adding collagen, propolis plus quercetin, bacillus coagulans, hyaluronic acid and chondroitin sulphate to D-mannose avoids symptoms and prevents recurrence in women with recurrent urinary tract infections: a single-blind randomized controlled trial.

doses.formulation: dietary supplement with D-mannose, Propolis-Quercetin, Bacillus Coagulans, Hyaluronic Acid and Chondroitin Sulfate

studies.notes: The study demonstrated a significant reduction in rUTI episodes and improvement in quality of life, indicating a beneficial outcome from the combination therapy.

studies.title: Efficacy of an orally administered combination of hyaluronic acid, chondroitin sulfate, curcumin and quercetin for the prevention of recurrent urinary tract infections in postmenopausal women.
studies.notes: The study showed significant improvement in preventing recurrent urinary tract infections with the combination therapy, especially when combined with local estrogen therapy.

indications.summary: Chondroitin, when used in combination with other agents, has shown beneficial effects in preventing recurrent urinary tract infections (rUTIs) in two randomized controlled trials. Both studies reported significant reductions in rUTI episodes and improvements in quality of life, although specific dose ranges were not consistently reported. No adverse effects were noted in the studies, but further research may be needed to confirm these findings and establish optimal dosing.

studies.title: Randomized trial of glucosamine and chondroitin supplementation on inflammation and oxidative stress biomarkers and plasma proteomics profiles in healthy humans.
studies.notes: The study found a significant reduction in serum CRP concentrations, indicating a benefit in reducing systemic inflammation.

indications.summary: One randomized trial reported that chondroitin supplementation (1200 mg daily for 28 days) resulted in a significant reduction in serum CRP concentrations, suggesting a potential benefit in reducing systemic inflammation. However, the overall evidence is limited, with only one study demonstrating this effect and no additional trials to confirm consistency or address potential adverse effects.

studies.title: A hyaluronic acid- and chondroitin sulfate-based medical device improves gastritis pain, discomfort, and endoscopic features.
studies.notes: The study showed significant improvement in gastritis-related pain and endoscopic features, indicating a beneficial outcome.

indications.summary: One study has shown that a medical device containing chondroitin sulfate, used for 5 weeks, resulted in significant improvement in gastritis-related pain and discomfort. However, the evidence is limited to this single trial, and further research is needed to confirm these findings and assess the consistency of the results across different populations and formulations.

studies.title: Oral preparation of hyaluronic acid, chondroitin sulfate, N-acetylglucosamine, and vitamin C improves sexual and urinary symptoms in participants with recurrent urinary tract infections: a randomized crossover trial.

doses.formulation: oral preparation of HA, chondroitin sulfate, N-acetylglucosamine, and vitamin C
oral preparation of cranberry, D-mannose, propolis extract, turmeric, and Boswellia

studies.notes: The study shows significant improvement in sexual and urinary symptoms, indicating a beneficial effect of the treatment.

indications.summary: One randomized crossover trial reported a benefit of an oral preparation containing chondroitin sulfate, among other ingredients, in improving urinary symptoms in participants with recurrent urinary tract infections. The study involved a daily dose for three months, but overall evidence is limited to this single trial, indicating a need for further research to confirm these findings. No adverse effects were noted in the study.

contraindications: DMSO should be used with caution and with active monitoring of side effects

studies.title: Effects of 12 Weeks of Chromium, Phyllanthus emblica Fruit Extract, and Shilajit Supplementation on Markers of Cardiometabolic Health, Fitness, and Weight Loss in Men and Women with Risk Factors to Metabolic Syndrome Initiating an Exercise and Diet Intervention: A Randomized Double-Blind, Placebo-Controlled Trial.

doses.formulation: trivalent chromium with 6 mg of PE and 6 mg of SJ
trivalent chromium with 12 mg of PE and 12 mg of SJ

studies.notes: The study showed benefits in improving markers related to metabolic syndrome and cardiometabolic health, indicating a positive outcome direction.

studies.title: Effects of Chromium and Carnitine Co-supplementation on Body Weight and Metabolic Profiles in Overweight and Obese Women with Polycystic Ovary Syndrome: a Randomized, Double-Blind, Placebo-Controlled Trial.
studies.notes: The study shows beneficial effects on weight, glycemic control, and lipid profiles, indicating a positive outcome direction.

indications.summary: Human clinical evidence suggests that chromium supplementation may have beneficial effects on body weight and metabolic profiles, particularly in specific populations such as those with metabolic syndrome and polycystic ovary syndrome. Two randomized controlled trials reported positive outcomes with doses of 200 µg to 800 µg of chromium per day over 12 weeks. However, the overall evidence is limited to a small number of studies, and further research is needed to confirm these findings and assess long-term effects.

studies.title: Chromium picolinate balances the metabolic and clinical markers in nonalcoholic fatty liver disease: a randomized, double-blind, placebo-controlled trial.
studies.notes: The study shows significant improvements in various metabolic markers, indicating a benefit from chromium picolinate supplementation.

indications.summary: One randomized, double-blind, placebo-controlled trial found that chromium picolinate (400 µg daily for 12 weeks) resulted in significant improvements in metabolic markers in patients with nonalcoholic fatty liver disease, indicating a potential benefit. However, the evidence is limited to a single study, and further research is needed to confirm these findings and assess long-term effects and safety.

studies.title: A novel nutritional supplement containing amino acids and chromium decreases postprandial glucose response in a randomized, double-blind, placebo-controlled study.
studies.notes: The study shows a significant reduction in postprandial glucose levels, indicating a beneficial effect of the supplement.

indications.summary: One randomized, double-blind, placebo-controlled study reported that a nutritional supplement containing chromium picolinate (250 mcg) significantly reduced postprandial glucose levels, indicating a potential benefit for high blood sugar. However, the overall evidence is limited, with only one study demonstrating this effect and no reports of harm or mixed outcomes.

studies.title: Synchronizing positive effect of vitamin C and chromium on hyper lipidemia, hyperglycemia, liver enzymes and BMI of diabetes mellitus type 2 patients.
studies.notes: The study shows significant improvements in various health parameters, indicating a beneficial effect of chromium supplementation.

studies.title: Improving the endothelial dysfunction in type 2 diabetes with chromium and vitamin D3 by reducing homocysteine and oxidative stress: A randomized placebo-controlled trial.
studies.notes: The study shows significant improvements in various health markers related to endothelial dysfunction and cardiovascular risk in T2DM patients, indicating a benefit from chromium supplementation.

studies.title: The Influences of Chromium Supplementation on Metabolic Status in Patients with Type 2 Diabetes Mellitus and Coronary Heart Disease.
studies.notes: The study shows significant improvements in various metabolic parameters, indicating a beneficial effect of chromium supplementation.

studies.title: Efficacy and Tolerability of a Food Supplement Based on Zea mays L., Gymnema sylvestre (Retz.) R.br.ex Sm, Zinc and Chromium for the Maintenance of Normal Carbohydrate Metabolism: A Monocentric, Randomized, Double-Blind, Placebo-Controlled Clinical Trial.

studies.title: Effects of Mediterranean Diet, Curcumin, and Resveratrol on Mild-to-Moderate Active Ulcerative Colitis: A Multicenter Randomized Clinical Trial.
studies.notes: The study showed that curcumin supplementation, along with the Mediterranean diet, was effective in reducing disease activity and improving quality of life in patients with ulcerative colitis.

indications.summary: Curcumin supplementation at a dose of 1600 mg daily for 8 weeks has shown benefit in reducing disease activity and improving quality of life in patients with active ulcerative colitis, according to a multicenter randomized clinical trial. However, the evidence is limited to a single study, and further research is needed to confirm these findings and assess long-term safety and efficacy.

studies.title: Mental health and health-related quality of life response to curcumin-probiotic drink powder co-supplementation in adults with overweight/obesity and metabolic syndrome: a four-arm randomised, double-blind, placebo-controlled, clinical trial.
studies.notes: The study showed significant improvements in mental health and HRQOL, indicating a benefit from curcumin-probiotic co-supplementation.

indications.summary: Current evidence on curcumin for anxiety is limited to one randomized controlled trial, which reported a benefit in mental health and health-related quality of life with a daily dose of 1 g of a curcumin-probiotic drink powder over 8 weeks. No studies reported mixed outcomes or harm, but the overall evidence remains sparse and requires further investigation to establish efficacy and safety.

studies.title: A clinical trial of curcumin effect in comparison to metronidazole on the treatment of bacterial vaginosis.
studies.notes: Curcumin showed superior effectiveness and fewer adverse effects compared to metronidazole in treating bacterial vaginosis.

indications.summary: One randomized clinical trial indicated that curcumin may be more effective than metronidazole in treating bacterial vaginosis, with fewer adverse effects reported. However, the evidence is limited to a single study, and further research is needed to confirm these findings and establish consistent dosing guidelines.

studies.title: Effect of phospholipid curcumin Meriva on liver histology and kidney disease in nonalcoholic steatohepatitis: A randomized, double-blind, placebo-controlled trial.
studies.notes: The study shows significant improvements in liver histology and kidney function, indicating a beneficial effect of Meriva.

indications.summary: One randomized, double-blind, placebo-controlled trial reported a benefit of phospholipid curcumin (Meriva) at a dose of 2 g daily over 72 weeks, showing significant improvements in kidney function in patients with chronic kidney disease. No studies reported mixed outcomes or harm, but the overall evidence is limited to a single trial, necessitating caution in generalizing these findings.

studies.title: Add-on effect of curcumin to dienogest in patients with endometriosis: a randomized, double-blind, controlled trial.
studies.notes: The study demonstrated significant improvements in pain and quality of life, indicating a beneficial effect of curcumin as an adjunct therapy in endometriosis.

indications.summary: One randomized, double-blind, controlled trial reported a beneficial effect of curcumin (80 mg daily for 8 weeks) as an adjunct therapy in improving pain and quality of life in patients with endometriosis-related chronic pelvic pain. No studies reported mixed outcomes or harm, but the overall evidence is limited to a single trial, indicating a need for further research to confirm these findings.

studies.title: Curcumin Reduces Depression in Obese Patients with Type 2 Diabetes: A Randomized Controlled Trial.
studies.notes: The study shows significant improvement in depression severity and related biomarkers, indicating a beneficial effect of curcumin.

indications.summary: One randomized controlled trial indicates that curcumin may reduce depression severity in obese patients with type 2 diabetes over a 12-month period. No adverse effects were reported in this study, but further research is needed to confirm these findings and assess the effects in broader populations.

studies.title: Role of oral bio-enhanced curcumin in dry eye disease.
studies.notes: The study shows significant improvement in various objective parameters of dry eye disease with the use of oral bio-enhanced curcumin, indicating a beneficial outcome.

indications.summary: There is limited evidence suggesting that oral bio-enhanced curcumin may improve objective parameters of dry eye disease, as indicated by one study reporting a beneficial outcome. However, the overall quality of evidence is low, and further research is needed to confirm these findings and assess consistency across different populations and formulations. No adverse effects were reported in the study.

studies.title: Curcumin Supplementation Improves Gastrointestinal Symptoms in Women with Severe Obesity: A Double-Blind, Randomized, Placebo-Controlled Trial-A Pilot Study.
studies.notes: The study showed significant improvements in gastrointestinal symptoms and anthropometric measures, indicating a beneficial effect of curcumin supplementation.

indications.summary: Curcumin supplementation at a dose of 1500 mg daily for 13 weeks demonstrated a beneficial effect on gastrointestinal symptoms in a pilot study involving women with severe obesity. However, the evidence is limited to a single study, and further research is needed to confirm these findings and assess long-term safety and efficacy.

studies.title: The effectiveness of curcumin as a safe agent on hearing threshold improvement in patients with chronic kidney disease: a double-blind, placebo-controlled trial.
studies.notes: The study shows significant improvement in hearing thresholds with curcumin, indicating a beneficial effect.

indications.summary: One randomized controlled trial has reported a significant improvement in hearing thresholds with curcumin in patients with chronic kidney disease, suggesting a potential benefit for hearing impairment. The study utilized a daily dose of curcumin for 12 weeks. However, further research is needed to confirm these findings and assess long-term effects and safety.

studies.title: Effect of nano-curcumin supplementation on cardiometabolic risk factors, physical and psychological quality of life, and depression in patients with coronary slow flow phenomenon: a randomized double-blind clinical trial.
studies.notes: The study showed significant improvements in quality of life and depression, indicating a beneficial effect of curcumin supplementation.

indications.summary: There is limited evidence suggesting a potential benefit of curcumin supplementation for high blood sugar, with one randomized trial reporting positive outcomes at a dose of 80 mg of nano-curcumin daily for 12 weeks. However, the overall evidence is sparse, and further studies are needed to establish consistency and efficacy. No adverse effects were reported in the available study.

studies.title: Twelve-Week Curcumin Supplementation Improves Glucose Homeostasis and Gut Health in Prediabetic Older Adults: A Pilot, Double-Blind, Placebo-Controlled Trial.
studies.notes: Curcumin supplementation showed significant improvement in glucose homeostasis markers, indicating a beneficial effect in prediabetic older adults.

indications.summary: Curcumin supplementation at a dose of 80 mg daily for 12 weeks demonstrated a beneficial effect on glucose homeostasis in a pilot study involving prediabetic older adults. However, this evidence is based on a single randomized trial, and further research is needed to confirm these findings and assess long-term effects and safety.

studies.title: Curcumin supplementation improves the clinical outcomes of patients with diabetes and atherosclerotic cardiovascular risk.
studies.notes: Curcumin supplementation showed significant improvements in various cardiovascular risk factors and was well tolerated with mild adverse effects.

studies.title: Curcumin extract improves beta cell functions in obese patients with type 2 diabetes: a randomized controlled trial.
studies.notes: The study reports significant improvements in glucose levels and β-cell function, indicating a beneficial effect of curcumin in type 2 diabetes patients.

studies.title: Curcumin for Inflammation Control in Individuals with Type 2 Diabetes Mellitus and Metabolic Dysfunction-Associated Steatotic Liver Disease: A Randomized Controlled Trial.
studies.notes: Curcumin showed significant improvements in inflammation and liver parameters, indicating a beneficial effect in the studied conditions.

studies.title: Effect of adding fenofibrate versus curcumin to glimepiride in patients with type 2 diabetes: a randomized controlled trial.
studies.notes: Both fenofibrate and curcumin showed benefits in improving lipid profiles and inflammatory markers in patients with type 2 diabetes.

studies.title: The effect of curcumin and high-content eicosapentaenoic acid supplementations in type 2 diabetes mellitus patients: a double-blinded randomized clinical trial.
studies.notes: The study shows significant benefits in reducing insulin levels and improving metabolic parameters, indicating a positive effect of curcumin supplementation.

indications.summary: Curcumin supplementation appears to provide consistent benefits for individuals with type 2 diabetes, as evidenced by five randomized controlled trials demonstrating improvements in glucose levels, β-cell function, inflammation, and cardiovascular risk factors. Reported doses varied, with common ranges including 80 mg to 1500 mg daily. All studies noted mild adverse effects, indicating that curcumin is generally well tolerated.

studies.title: The Effect of Curcumin on Reducing Atherogenic Risks in Obese Patients with Type 2 Diabetes: A Randomized Controlled Trial.
studies.notes: The study found significant reductions in atherogenic risks and cardiometabolic biomarkers, indicating a beneficial effect of curcumin.

indications.summary: Current evidence from a randomized controlled trial indicates that curcumin may reduce atherogenic risks and improve cardiometabolic biomarkers in obese patients with type 2 diabetes, suggesting a potential benefit for lowering high LDL cholesterol. However, the evidence is limited to a single study, and further research is needed to confirm these findings and assess long-term safety and efficacy.

studies.title: Curcumin supplementation alleviates hepatic fat content associated with modulation of gut microbiota-dependent bile acid metabolism in patients with nonalcoholic simple fatty liver disease: a randomized controlled trial.
studies.notes: Curcumin significantly reduced hepatic fat content and improved various metabolic parameters, indicating a beneficial effect.

indications.summary: Curcumin supplementation at a dose of 500 mg daily for 24 weeks has shown a beneficial effect in reducing hepatic fat content in patients with nonalcoholic simple fatty liver disease, according to a randomized controlled trial. However, the overall evidence is limited, with only one study reporting positive outcomes and no data on potential adverse effects or long-term efficacy.

studies.title: The effect of curcumin-piperine supplementation on lipid profile, glycemic index, inflammation, and blood pressure in patients with type 2 diabetes mellitus and hypertriglyceridemia.
studies.notes: The study showed significant reductions in triglycerides and fasting blood glucose, indicating a benefit from curcumin-piperine supplementation.

indications.summary: One randomized trial reported that curcumin-piperine supplementation (500 mg for 12 weeks) significantly reduced triglyceride levels in patients with type 2 diabetes and hypertriglyceridemia, indicating a potential benefit. However, the overall evidence is limited to this single study, and further research is needed to confirm these findings and assess long-term effects and safety.

studies.title: The effects of curcumin supplementation on inflammatory markers in systemic lupus erythematosus patients: a randomized placebo-controlled trial.
studies.notes: Curcumin supplementation significantly reduced anti-ds DNA and IL-6 levels, indicating a beneficial effect on inflammation in SLE patients.

indications.summary: One randomized placebo-controlled trial reported that curcumin supplementation at a dose of 1000 mg daily for 10 weeks significantly reduced inflammatory markers, including anti-ds DNA and IL-6 levels, in patients with systemic lupus erythematosus. However, the overall evidence is limited to a single study, and further research is needed to confirm these findings and assess long-term safety and efficacy.

studies.title: Impaired postprandial GLP-2 response enhances endotoxemia, systemic inflammation, and kidney injury in metabolic dysfunction-associated steatohepatitis (MASH): effect of phospholipid curcumin meriva.
studies.notes: The study shows that curcumin may improve GLP-2 response and related outcomes in MASH patients, indicating a potential benefit.

indications.summary: One randomized trial suggests that phospholipid curcumin (Meriva) may improve GLP-2 response and related outcomes in patients with metabolic dysfunction-associated steatohepatitis (MASH), indicating a potential benefit for kidney injury. However, the evidence is limited to a single study, and further research is needed to confirm these findings and assess long-term safety and efficacy.

studies.title: The Immunomodulatory Effects of Curcumin on Forkhead Box O1 and MicroRNA-873 in Patients with Osteoarthritis.
studies.notes: The study shows a significant increase in gene expression related to Th17 function, indicating a beneficial effect of curcumin in OA patients.

indications.summary: Current evidence from a randomized trial indicates that curcumin may have a beneficial effect on knee pain in patients with osteoarthritis, as demonstrated by significant changes in gene expression related to Th17 function. However, the evidence is limited to a single study, and no adverse effects were reported. Further research is needed to confirm these findings and establish consistent dosing guidelines.

studies.title: Efficacy of highly bioavailable oral curcumin in asymptomatic or mild COVID-19 patients: a double-blind, randomized, placebo-controlled trial.
studies.notes: The study shows a reduction in disease progression and antipyretic medication use, indicating a beneficial effect of curcumin.

indications.summary: One randomized, double-blind, placebo-controlled trial reported a benefit of curcumin in patients with mild COVID-19 symptoms, showing a reduction in disease progression and antipyretic medication use with a dose of 360 mg (curcuRouge®) twice daily for 7 days. However, the overall evidence is limited to this single study, and further research is needed to confirm these findings and assess long-term safety and efficacy.

studies.title: Curcumin plus piperine improve body composition in patients with inflammatory bowel disease: a randomized, double-blind, placebo-controlled clinical trial.
studies.notes: The study shows significant improvements in body composition and muscle mass in patients with IBD, indicating a beneficial effect of curcumin plus piperine.

indications.summary: One randomized, double-blind, placebo-controlled trial reported that curcumin combined with piperine (1000 mg and 10 mg daily, respectively) improved body composition and muscle mass in patients with inflammatory bowel disease. Overall evidence is limited to this single study, and further research is needed to confirm these findings and assess long-term effects and safety.

studies.title: The dose-response effects of hydrolyzed curcumin on recovery, inflammation, and oxidative stress following exercise-induced muscle damage in males.
studies.notes: The study shows mixed outcomes; higher doses improved biochemical recovery but may have impaired performance recovery.

indications.summary: Current evidence on curcumin for muscle soreness after exercise is mixed, with one study indicating that higher doses (750 mg and 1500 mg, taken twice daily for 7 days) may improve biochemical recovery but could impair performance recovery. No consistent benefits have been established, and further research is needed to clarify its effects.

studies.title: Curcumin Supplementation as a Preventive Strategy Against Tamoxifen-Induced Nonalcoholic Fatty Liver Disease in ER+ Breast Cancer Patients: A Triple-Blind Randomized Placebo-Controlled Trial.
studies.notes: Curcumin showed a protective effect against tamoxifen-induced NAFLD, indicating a benefit in the studied population.

indications.summary: Curcumin supplementation has shown a beneficial effect in preventing tamoxifen-induced nonalcoholic fatty liver disease (NAFLD) in a specific population of ER+ breast cancer patients, based on a triple-blind randomized placebo-controlled trial that used a dose of 500 mg daily for 6 months. However, the evidence is limited to this single study, and further research is needed to establish broader efficacy and safety in other populations.

studies.title: Sustained Release of Liposomal Curcumin: Enhanced Periodontal Outcomes in Diabetic Patients.
studies.notes: The study shows significant improvement in clinical and biochemical parameters, indicating a benefit from the treatment with liposomal curcumin.

indications.summary: One randomized trial reported a benefit of liposomal curcumin gel in improving clinical and biochemical parameters in diabetic patients with periodontitis over 6 and 12 weeks. However, the overall evidence is limited, with only one study available, and further research is needed to confirm these findings and assess long-term effects and safety.

studies.title: Effects of metformin and curcumin in women with polycystic ovary syndrome: A factorial clinical trial.
studies.notes: The study shows significant improvements in various health parameters, indicating a beneficial effect of curcumin in the treatment of PCOS.

indications.summary: One randomized clinical trial reported a beneficial effect of curcumin (80 mg of nanocurcumin soft gel capsule) in improving health parameters in women with polycystic ovary syndrome over 12 weeks. However, the overall evidence is limited, with only one study available, and further research is needed to confirm these findings and assess long-term safety and efficacy.

studies.title: The effect of curcumin on postpartum depression and anxiety in primiparous women: a double-blind randomized placebo-controlled clinical trial.
studies.notes: The study shows significant improvement in postpartum depression and anxiety scores, indicating a beneficial effect of curcumin.

indications.summary: One double-blind randomized placebo-controlled trial has reported a beneficial effect of curcumin (500 mg once daily for eight weeks) on postpartum anxiety and depression scores in primiparous women. However, the evidence is limited to a single study, and further research is needed to confirm these findings and assess long-term safety and efficacy.

studies.title: The efficacy of curcumin supplementation on serum total antioxidant capacity, malondialdehyde, and disease activity in women with rheumatoid arthritis: A randomized, double-blind, placebo-controlled clinical trial.
studies.notes: Curcumin supplementation significantly improved serum TAC and reduced disease activity scores in women with RA.

indications.summary: Curcumin supplementation at a dose of 500 mg daily for 8 weeks has shown a benefit in improving serum total antioxidant capacity and reducing disease activity scores in women with rheumatoid arthritis, according to a randomized, double-blind, placebo-controlled trial. However, the overall evidence is limited, with only one study reporting positive outcomes and no data on potential adverse effects or long-term efficacy.

studies.title: Comparison of the antimicrobial effects of 0.2% curcumin mouthwash and chlorhexidine mouthwash on Streptococcus mutans in orthodontic patients: a randomized clinical trial.
studies.notes: The study shows that curcumin mouthwash significantly reduced S mutans more than chlorhexidine after 20 days, indicating a benefit.

indications.summary: One randomized clinical trial demonstrated that a 0.2% curcumin mouthwash used twice daily for 20 days significantly reduced Streptococcus mutans levels compared to chlorhexidine, indicating a potential benefit. However, the evidence is limited to a single study, and further research is needed to confirm these findings and assess long-term effects and safety.

contraindications: Higher incidence of adverse events in curcumin group compared to control group.
mild adverse drug reaction observed in three cases of the curcumin group and one case of group A
minor gastrointestinal adverse effects reported by 7.1% of patients
significantly more vomiting in the curcumin group

studies.title: The effects of docosahexaenoic acid supplementation on cognition and well-being in mild cognitive impairment: A 12-month randomised controlled trial.
studies.notes: The study found no effect on cognition but positive effects on depression and anxiety in APOE ɛ4 carriers, indicating mixed outcomes.

indications.summary: The evidence regarding docosahexaenoic acid (DHA) supplementation for anxiety is mixed and unclear, based on a single randomized controlled trial that reported positive effects on anxiety in a specific subgroup (APOE ɛ4 carriers) but no overall effect on cognition. The study utilized a daily dose of 1491 mg of DHA from a fish oil supplement over 12 months. No adverse effects were reported, but the limited and mixed nature of the evidence suggests caution in interpretation.

studies.title: EPA and DHA differentially modulate monocyte inflammatory response in subjects with chronic inflammation in part via plasma specialized pro-resolving lipid mediators: A randomized, double-blind, crossover study.
studies.notes: DHA showed a broader effect in attenuating pro-inflammatory cytokines, indicating a beneficial outcome.

studies.title: Monocyte transcriptomic profile following EPA and DHA supplementation in men and women with low-grade chronic inflammation.
studies.notes: The study shows both similar and differential effects of DHA and EPA on gene expression related to inflammation, indicating mixed outcomes.

indications.summary: The evidence for docosahexaenoic acid (DHA) in reducing chronic inflammation is limited and mixed. One randomized trial reported a beneficial effect on pro-inflammatory cytokines with a dose of 3 g daily for 10 weeks, while another study indicated mixed outcomes regarding gene expression related to inflammation. No studies reported harm or no benefit, but the overall quality and consistency of the evidence are low.

studies.title: Intake of Docosahexaenoic Acid-Enriched Milk Beverage Prevents Age-Related Cognitive Decline and Decreases Serum Bone Resorption Marker Levels.
studies.notes: The study shows that DHA intake prevents cognitive decline and may benefit bone health, indicating a positive outcome.

indications.summary: Current evidence from a single randomized trial suggests that docosahexaenoic acid (DHA) may prevent age-related cognitive decline when consumed at a dose of 297 mg daily for 12 months. However, the overall evidence is limited, with only one study reporting a benefit and no adverse effects noted. Further research is needed to confirm these findings and assess long-term effects.

studies.title: Baseline Findings of PreventE4: A Double-Blind Placebo Controlled Clinical Trial Testing High Dose DHA in APOE4 Carriers before the Onset of Dementia.
studies.notes: The study aims to assess the effects of DHA on cognitive function and brain imaging biomarkers, but the outcomes are not definitively beneficial or harmful based on the abstract.

studies.title: Supplementation of medium-chain triglycerides combined with docosahexaenoic acid improves cognitive function in Chinese older adults with mild cognitive impairment: A randomized double-blind, placebo-controlled trial.
studies.notes: The study shows significant improvements in cognitive function for MCI patients, indicating a benefit from the supplementation.

studies.title: Cognitive Benefits of Folic Acid, Docosahexaenoic Acid, and a Combination of Both Nutrients in Mild Cognitive Impairment: Possible Alterations through Mitochondrial Function and DNA Damage.
studies.notes: The study demonstrated significant cognitive improvements in participants with mild cognitive impairment, indicating a beneficial effect of DHA supplementation.

indications.summary: The evidence for docosahexaenoic acid (DHA) in improving cognitive function in individuals with mild cognitive impairment is mixed. Three studies reported benefits with doses of 800 mg daily, while one study showed unclear outcomes despite high doses of 2 grams per day. No studies reported harm, but the overall findings suggest that while DHA may have potential benefits, further research is needed to clarify its effectiveness and optimal dosing.

studies.title: The Effect of Eicosapentaenoic and Docosahexaenoic Acid Supplementation on Coronary Artery Calcium Progression in Subjects With Diabetes and Coronary Artery Disease: A Secondary Analysis of a Randomized Trial.
studies.notes: The study found that EPA+DHA supplementation was associated with greater coronary artery calcium progression in subjects with diabetes, indicating potential harm.

studies.title: Regression of Coronary Fatty Plaque and Risk of Cardiac Events According to Blood Pressure Status: Data From a Randomized Trial of Eicosapentaenoic Acid and Docosahexaenoic Acid in Patients With Coronary Artery Disease.
studies.notes: The study shows that DHA, along with eicosapentaenoic acid, leads to regression of coronary fatty plaque and reduced cardiac events, indicating a beneficial outcome.

indications.summary: The evidence regarding docosahexaenoic acid (DHA) supplementation for coronary artery disease is mixed. One study indicated potential harm, showing increased coronary artery calcium progression with DHA and eicosapentaenoic acid (EPA) supplementation at a dose of 1.86 g daily, while another study suggested a benefit with a higher dose of 3.36 g daily, reporting regression of coronary fatty plaque and reduced cardiac events. Overall, the findings are inconsistent, and caution is warranted due to the potential for adverse effects.

studies.title: Myokine Circulating Levels in Postmenopausal Women with Overweight or Obesity: Effects of Resistance Training and/or DHA-Rich n-3 PUFA Supplementation.
studies.notes: The study indicates improvements in cardiometabolic health markers and muscle function, suggesting a benefit from DHA supplementation and resistance training.

studies.title: Oils Rich in α-Linolenic Acid or Docosahexaenoic Acid Have Distinct Effects on Plasma Oxylipin and Adiponectin Concentrations and on Monocyte Bioenergetics in Women with Obesity.
studies.notes: DHA supplementation led to increased plasma oxylipins and adiponectin, indicating a beneficial effect on metabolic health.

indications.summary: Clinical evidence suggests that docosahexaenoic acid (DHA) supplementation may have beneficial effects on metabolic health and body weight in individuals with excess body weight, as indicated by two studies showing improvements in cardiometabolic markers and adiponectin levels. Doses reported include 4 g of fish oil daily for 4 weeks and DHA-rich n-3 PUFA for 16 weeks. However, the overall evidence is limited to a small number of studies, and further research is needed to confirm these findings and assess long-term effects.

studies.title: The ALGOVUE Clinical Trial: Effects of the Daily Consumption of Eggs Enriched with Lutein and Docosahexaenoic Acid on Plasma Composition and Macular Pigment Optical Density.
studies.notes: The study shows a slight but significant increase in MPOD and DHA concentrations, indicating a benefit from the intervention.

indications.summary: The evidence for docosahexaenoic acid (DHA) in promoting eye health is limited, with only one randomized trial reporting a slight but significant benefit in macular pigment optical density after daily consumption of DHA-enriched eggs for four months. Overall, the quality of evidence is low, and further research is needed to establish more definitive conclusions.

studies.title: Omega-3 Polyunsaturated Fatty Acids EPA and DHA as an Adjunct to Non-Surgical Treatment of Periodontitis: A Randomized Clinical Trial.
studies.notes: The study shows significant improvement in periodontal health outcomes with DHA supplementation.

indications.summary: One randomized clinical trial indicates that docosahexaenoic acid (DHA) supplementation at a dose of 1.8 g daily for three months may improve periodontal health outcomes in patients with gum disease. However, the evidence is limited to a single study, and further research is needed to confirm these findings and assess long-term effects and safety.

studies.title: Effects of DHA-Rich n-3 Fatty Acid Supplementation and/or Resistance Training on Body Composition and Cardiometabolic Biomarkers in Overweight and Obese Post-Menopausal Women.
studies.notes: The study shows beneficial effects of DHA on cardiovascular health markers and muscle quality.

indications.summary: One randomized trial indicates that docosahexaenoic acid (DHA) supplementation may have beneficial effects on cardiovascular health markers in overweight and obese post-menopausal women. The study involved DHA-rich n-3 PUFA supplementation over 16 weeks, but further research is needed to confirm these findings and assess long-term effects. No adverse effects were reported in the available evidence.

studies.title: DHA-enriched fish oil reduces insulin resistance in overweight and obese adults.
studies.notes: The study shows a significant reduction in insulin resistance, indicating a beneficial effect of DHA supplementation.

studies.title: EPA and DHA inhibit LDL-induced upregulation of human adipose tissue NLRP3 inflammasome/IL-1β pathway and its association with diabetes risk factors.
studies.notes: The study shows that DHA, along with EPA, has beneficial effects on IL-1β secretion and diabetes risk factors.

indications.summary: Two randomized trials indicate that docosahexaenoic acid (DHA) supplementation may reduce insulin resistance and positively influence diabetes risk factors in overweight and obese adults, with doses reported around 2 g to 2.7 g daily for 12 weeks. However, the overall evidence is limited and further studies are needed to confirm these findings and assess long-term effects and safety.

studies.title: Eicosapentaenoic and Docosahexaenoic Acid Supplementation Increases HDL Content in n-3 Fatty Acids and Improves Endothelial Function in Hypertriglyceridemic Patients.
studies.notes: The study shows a beneficial effect of DHA on endothelial function in hypertriglyceridemic patients.

studies.title: Ethyl EPA and ethyl DHA cause similar and differential changes in plasma lipid concentrations and lipid metabolism in subjects with low-grade chronic inflammation.
studies.notes: DHA supplementation led to beneficial changes in lipid profiles, indicating a positive health outcome.

indications.summary: Clinical evidence suggests that docosahexaenoic acid (DHA) may have beneficial effects on lipid profiles and endothelial function in individuals with high triglycerides, with three studies reporting positive outcomes. Doses reported include 380 mg twice daily and 3 g daily, though the consistency of these findings and the overall quality of evidence is moderate. No adverse effects were noted in the studies reviewed.

studies.title: An open-label, multicenter, phase 2 study of a food enriched with docosahexaenoic acid in adults with sickle cell disease.

doses.formulation: food enriched with omega-3 fatty acids

studies.notes: The study showed a significant reduction in CRP, indicating a benefit in inflammation, although other measures were not significantly improved.

indications.summary: One phase 2 study reported a significant reduction in C-reactive protein (CRP) levels in adults with sickle cell disease after 28 days of consuming a food enriched with docosahexaenoic acid (DHA), suggesting a potential benefit for inflammation. However, other inflammatory measures did not show significant improvement, indicating that the evidence is limited and further research is needed to confirm these findings.

studies.title: Multiple Micronutrients, Lutein, and Docosahexaenoic Acid Supplementation during Lactation: A Randomized Controlled Trial.
studies.notes: The study shows a significant increase in maternal milk DHA content, indicating a benefit from supplementation.

indications.summary: One randomized controlled trial indicates that docosahexaenoic acid (DHA) supplementation during lactation may significantly increase maternal milk DHA content, suggesting a potential benefit for addressing insufficient nutrient supply. No adverse effects or harm were reported in the study. However, the evidence is limited to a single trial, and further research is needed to confirm these findings and establish consistent dosing guidelines.

studies.title: Re-esterified DHA improves ventilatory threshold 2 in competitive amateur cyclists.
studies.notes: DHA supplementation led to significant improvements in power output and oxygen consumption, indicating a benefit for athletic performance.

indications.summary: One randomized trial found that re-esterified DHA (975 mg daily for 30 days) improved ventilatory threshold and performance metrics in competitive amateur cyclists, suggesting a potential benefit for low exercise performance. However, the evidence is limited to a single study, and further research is needed to confirm these findings and assess long-term effects and safety.

studies.title: Dietary supplementation with docosahexaenoic acid rich fish oil increases circulating levels of testosterone in overweight and obese men.
studies.notes: The study found that DHA supplementation increased testosterone levels in overweight and obese men, indicating a beneficial effect.

indications.summary: One randomized trial indicates that dietary supplementation with docosahexaenoic acid (DHA) at a dose of 860 mg daily for 12 weeks may increase testosterone levels in overweight and obese men. No studies reported mixed results or adverse effects, but the evidence is limited to a single trial, warranting caution in generalizing these findings.

studies.title: Long-Chain Omega-3 Fatty Acid Supplementation and Exercise-Induced Muscle Damage: EPA or DHA?
studies.notes: DHA supplementation showed benefits in reducing muscle soreness and improving recovery metrics compared to placebo.

indications.summary: One randomized trial indicates that docosahexaenoic acid (DHA) supplementation at a dose of 4 g daily for 52 days may reduce muscle soreness and improve recovery metrics compared to placebo. There is currently no evidence of harm or mixed outcomes associated with DHA for this indication, but further research is needed to confirm these findings and establish consistency across studies.

studies.title: DHA Supplementation During Pregnancy Enhances Maternal Vagally Mediated Cardiac Autonomic Control in Humans.
studies.notes: DHA supplementation showed beneficial effects on maternal heart rate and heart rate variability metrics.

indications.summary: One randomized trial indicates that docosahexaenoic acid (DHA) supplementation during pregnancy may enhance maternal heart rate control, with reported doses of 200 mg and 800 mg daily. No studies reported mixed outcomes or harm, but the evidence is limited to a single trial, necessitating caution in interpretation.

studies.title: Effect of Docosahexaenoic Acid and Eicosapentaenoic Acid Supplementation on Sleep Quality in Healthy Subjects: A Randomized, Double-Blinded, Placebo-Controlled Trial.
studies.notes: The study reports significant improvements in sleep quality metrics, indicating a beneficial effect of DHA.

studies.title: Differential Effects of DHA- and EPA-Rich Oils on Sleep in Healthy Young Adults: A Randomized Controlled Trial.
studies.notes: The study shows improvements in sleep efficiency with DHA but also reports negative feelings, indicating mixed outcomes.

indications.summary: The evidence for docosahexaenoic acid (DHA) in improving sleep quality is limited and mixed. One randomized controlled trial reported significant improvements in sleep quality metrics with a daily dose of 576 mg for 12 weeks, while another trial indicated mixed outcomes, showing some benefits in sleep efficiency but also negative feelings associated with DHA supplementation. Overall, the findings are not robust enough to draw definitive conclusions.

studies.title: Changes in eicosapentaenoic acid and docosahexaenoic acid and risk of cardiovascular events and atrial fibrillation: A secondary analysis of the OMEMI trial.
studies.notes: The study shows potential benefits in reducing MACE with EPA but unclear effects with DHA, indicating mixed outcomes.

indications.summary: The evidence regarding docosahexaenoic acid (DHA) for reducing the risk of major cardiovascular events is low quality and mixed. A secondary analysis of the OMEMI trial indicated unclear effects of DHA, with no consistent benefits reported across studies. Typical doses in the analyzed study included 1.8 g of EPA/DHA daily for 2 years, but the overall findings do not support a definitive conclusion on DHA's efficacy for this indication.

studies.title: Antioxidant and Anti-Inflammatory Effects of Oral Supplementation with a Highly-Concentrated Docosahexaenoic Acid (DHA) Triglyceride in Patients with Keratoconus: A Randomized Controlled Preliminary Study.
studies.notes: The study found significant improvements in various corneal and inflammatory markers in the DHA group, indicating a beneficial effect.

indications.summary: One randomized controlled trial reported a beneficial effect of docosahexaenoic acid (DHA) supplementation (1000 mg daily for 3 months) on corneal and inflammatory markers in patients with keratoconus. However, the evidence is limited to a single study, and further research is needed to confirm these findings and assess long-term effects and safety.

contraindications: higher risk of gestational diabetes associated with DHA supplementation
higher risk of obesity in high-DHA group
possible adverse effect on language of females at 1.5 years

indications.summary: One randomized trial indicated that aged garlic extract (2.56 g daily for 90 days) may enhance immune cell function and reduce the severity of cold and flu symptoms. However, the evidence is limited to a single study, and further research is needed to confirm these findings and assess consistency across different populations and formulations.

studies.title: Randomized trial evaluating the effect of aged garlic extract with supplements versus placebo on adipose tissue surrogates for coronary atherosclerosis progression.
studies.notes: The study shows a significant reduction in adipose tissue volumes associated with AGE+S, indicating a beneficial effect on coronary atherosclerosis progression.

studies.title: Aged Garlic Extract Reduces Low Attenuation Plaque in Coronary Arteries of Patients with Metabolic Syndrome in a Prospective Randomized Double-Blind Study.
studies.notes: The study shows a significant reduction in low-attenuation plaque in the AGE group, indicating a beneficial effect.

indications.summary: Two randomized trials indicate that aged garlic extract may have beneficial effects on coronary artery disease, showing significant reductions in adipose tissue volumes and low-attenuation plaque. The doses reported include 2400 mg daily for one study, while the other involved aged garlic extract with supplements over 12 months. Overall, the evidence suggests potential benefits, but further research is needed to confirm these findings and assess long-term effects.

studies.title: Effect of Encapsulated Purple Garlic Oil on Microvascular Function and the Components of Metabolic Syndrome: A Randomized Placebo-Controlled Study-The ENDOTALLIUM Study.
studies.notes: The study demonstrated significant improvements in microvascular function and components of metabolic syndrome, indicating a beneficial effect of garlic oil.

studies.title: Differential responses of endothelial integrity upon the intake of microencapsulated garlic, tomato extract or a mixture: a single-intake, randomized, double-blind, placebo-controlled crossover trial.
studies.notes: The study shows mixed effects on biomarkers related to endothelial integrity, indicating both benefits and unclear outcomes.

indications.summary: The evidence on garlic for improving endothelial dysfunction is limited and mixed. One randomized controlled trial reported significant benefits from encapsulated purple garlic oil on microvascular function, while another trial showed mixed effects on endothelial integrity with microencapsulated garlic powder. Overall, the findings are not consistent, and further research is needed to clarify the effects.

studies.title: Gastric administration of garlic powder containing the trpa1- agonist allicin induces specific epigastric symptoms and gastric relaxation in healthy subjects.
studies.notes: Garlic induced specific symptoms but did not significantly affect mechanosensitivity or compliance, indicating mixed outcomes.

indications.summary: The clinical evidence regarding garlic for epigastric discomfort is limited and mixed, with one study indicating that garlic powder (2 g single dose) induced specific symptoms but did not significantly impact mechanosensitivity or gastric compliance. Overall, there is no consistent evidence supporting its efficacy for this indication.

studies.title: Prospective, randomized, placebo-controlled, two-arm study to evaluate the efficacy of coadministration of garlic as a hydrogen sulfide donor and tadalafil in patients with erectile dysfunction not responding to tadalafil alone - A pilot study.
studies.notes: The study showed statistically significant improvement in erectile function with garlic coadministration, indicating a benefit.

indications.summary: One pilot study reported a statistically significant improvement in erectile function with the coadministration of garlic (5 g orally twice a day for 4 weeks) alongside tadalafil in patients who did not respond to tadalafil alone. However, the evidence is limited to this single study, and further research is needed to confirm these findings and assess long-term safety and efficacy.

studies.title: Effects of garlic powder supplementation on metabolic syndrome components, insulin resistance, fatty liver index, and appetite in subjects with metabolic syndrome: A randomized clinical trial.
studies.notes: Garlic supplementation led to significant improvements in various metabolic syndrome components and appetite, indicating a beneficial effect.

indications.summary: One randomized clinical trial reported that garlic powder supplementation (1600 mg daily for 3 months) resulted in significant improvements in components of metabolic syndrome and appetite, suggesting a potential benefit for excess body weight. However, the evidence is limited to a single study, and further research is needed to confirm these findings and assess long-term effects.

studies.title: Effect of garlic powder supplementation on hepatic steatosis, liver enzymes and lipid profile in patients with non-alcoholic fatty liver disease: a double-blind randomised controlled clinical trial.
studies.notes: Garlic powder supplementation significantly improved hepatic features and lipid profile among NAFLD patients.

indications.summary: One randomized controlled trial found that garlic powder supplementation (400 mg, 4 tablets daily for 12 weeks) significantly improved hepatic features and lipid profile in patients with non-alcoholic fatty liver disease (NAFLD). No studies reported mixed outcomes or harm, indicating a potential benefit, but further research is needed to confirm these findings and assess long-term effects.

studies.title: Improved microvascular reactivity after aged garlic extract intake is not mediated by hydrogen sulfide in older adults at risk for cardiovascular disease: a randomized clinical trial.
studies.notes: The study showed improved microvascular reactivity and reduced systolic blood pressure after aged garlic extract intake, indicating a benefit for older adults at risk for cardiovascular disease.

studies.title: Effects of an Optimized Aged Garlic Extract on Cardiovascular Disease Risk Factors in Moderate Hypercholesterolemic Subjects: A Randomized, Crossover, Double-Blind, Sustainedand Controlled Study.
studies.notes: The study showed a significant reduction in diastolic blood pressure, indicating a beneficial effect of aged black garlic on cardiovascular risk factors.

studies.title: Antihypertensive Effects of an Optimized Aged Garlic Extract in Subjects with Grade I Hypertension and Antihypertensive Drug Therapy: A Randomized, Triple-Blind Controlled Trial.
studies.notes: The study demonstrated a significant reduction in blood pressure, indicating a beneficial effect of the garlic extract in hypertensive patients.

studies.title: Randomized, double-blind clinical trial evaluating the impact of freeze-dried garlic extract capsules on blood pressure, lipid profile, and nitric oxide levels in individuals at risk for hypertension.
studies.notes: The study demonstrated significant improvements in blood pressure and lipid profiles, indicating a beneficial effect of garlic supplementation in prehypertensive individuals.

indications.summary: Clinical evidence from four randomized trials indicates that garlic supplements, particularly aged garlic extract, may reduce blood pressure in various populations, including older adults and individuals with hypertension. Reported doses include 250 mg to 2.4 g of aged garlic extract and 0.25 mg of s-allyl-cysteine daily. No adverse effects were noted in the studies, but the overall quality of evidence remains moderate and further research may be needed to confirm these findings.

studies.title: The effect of aged garlic extract on the atherosclerotic process - a randomized double-blind placebo-controlled trial.
studies.notes: The study showed significant benefits in reducing coronary artery calcification progression, lowering blood glucose, and decreasing blood pressure.

indications.summary: One randomized double-blind placebo-controlled trial reported that aged garlic extract (2400 mg daily for one year) significantly reduced blood glucose levels, indicating a potential benefit for high blood sugar. However, the overall evidence is limited, with only one study demonstrating this effect and no other studies providing conflicting or supportive data. No adverse effects were reported in the study.

studies.title: Effects of garlic powder supplementation on insulin resistance, oxidative stress, and body composition in patients with non-alcoholic fatty liver disease: A randomized controlled clinical trial.
studies.notes: Garlic powder supplementation led to significant improvements in various health markers related to NAFLD.

studies.title: Efficacy of garlic (Allium sativum) on metabolic syndrome components in women with polycystic ovary syndrome: randomized controlled trial.
studies.notes: The study showed significant improvements in various metabolic syndrome markers and quality of life, indicating a beneficial effect of garlic supplementation.

studies.title: Effect of Raw Crushed Garlic (Allium sativum L.) on Components of Metabolic Syndrome.
studies.notes: The study shows significant reductions in various components of metabolic syndrome, indicating a beneficial effect of garlic.

indications.summary: The evidence from three randomized controlled trials indicates that garlic supplementation may have beneficial effects on metabolic markers related to high blood sugar and metabolic syndrome in various populations. Doses reported include 400 mg of garlic powder daily, 500 mg of garlic tablets twice daily, and 100 mg/kg of raw crushed garlic twice daily. However, the studies primarily focus on specific populations and conditions, and further research is needed to confirm these findings across broader groups.

studies.title: Supplementation of garlic and coriander seed powder: Impact on body mass index, lipid profile and blood pressure of hyperlipidemic patients.
studies.notes: The study shows significant improvements in lipid parameters and BMI, indicating a beneficial effect of garlic supplementation.

studies.title: Effect of Black Garlic Consumption on Endothelial Function and Lipid Profile: A Before-and-After Study in Hypercholesterolemic and Non-Hypercholesterolemic Subjects.
studies.notes: The study shows significant improvements in endothelial function and lipid profile, indicating a benefit from black garlic consumption.

studies.title: Garlic extract favorably modifies markers of endothelial function in obese patients -randomized double blind placebo-controlled nutritional intervention.
studies.notes: The study shows significant improvements in endothelial biomarkers, indicating a beneficial effect of garlic extract.

studies.title: LDL-Cholesterol-Lowering Effects of a Dietary Supplement Containing Onion and Garlic Extract Used in Healthy Volunteers.

doses.formulation: standardized formulation containing extracts from garlic and onions

studies.notes: The study showed significant reductions in LDL cholesterol and total cholesterol levels, indicating a beneficial effect on mild hypercholesterolemia.

studies.title: The effect of garlic (Allium sativum) supplementation on the lipid parameters and blood pressure levels in women with polycystic ovary syndrome: A randomized controlled trial.
studies.notes: Garlic supplementation showed significant reductions in total cholesterol and LDL-C, indicating a beneficial effect on lipid parameters.

indications.summary: The evidence from five randomized trials indicates that garlic supplementation may significantly reduce LDL cholesterol levels and improve lipid profiles in various populations. Typical doses reported include 400 mg of garlic extract daily and 2-4 cloves of black garlic daily. No studies reported adverse effects or harm associated with garlic supplementation, but further research may be needed to confirm these findings across broader populations.

studies.title: The effect of a garlic supplement on the pro-inflammatory adipocytokines, resistin and tumor necrosis factor-alpha, and on pain severity, in overweight or obese women with knee osteoarthritis.
studies.notes: Garlic supplementation significantly reduced pain severity and resistin levels, indicating a beneficial effect.

indications.summary: One randomized trial reported that garlic supplementation (1000 mg twice daily for 12 weeks) significantly reduced pain severity in overweight or obese women with knee osteoarthritis. However, the overall evidence is limited, with only one study available, and further research is needed to confirm these findings and assess long-term effects and safety.

studies.title: Garlic supplementation improves intestinal transit time, lipid accumulation product and cardiometabolic indices in subjects with metabolic syndrome: A randomized controlled trial.
studies.notes: Garlic supplementation showed significant improvements in intestinal transit time and various cardiometabolic indices, indicating a beneficial effect in subjects with metabolic syndrome.

indications.summary: Human clinical evidence suggests that garlic supplementation may have beneficial effects on components of metabolic syndrome, with three randomized controlled trials reporting positive outcomes. Doses reported include 1600 mg of garlic powder daily for three months and 2400 mg of aged garlic extract daily for approximately one year. No adverse effects were noted in the studies, but further research may be needed to confirm these findings and assess long-term safety.

studies.title: Efficacy and safety of fermented garlic extract on hepatic function in adults with elevated serum gamma-glutamyl transpeptidase levels: a double-blind, randomized, placebo-controlled trial.
studies.notes: The study shows improvement in serum GGT and ALT levels, indicating a benefit for mild hepatic dysfunction.

indications.summary: One randomized, double-blind, placebo-controlled trial reported a benefit of fermented garlic extract in improving serum gamma-glutamyl transpeptidase (GGT) and alanine aminotransferase (ALT) levels in adults with mild liver dysfunction, using a dose of 2 sachets daily for 12 weeks. Overall evidence is limited, with only one study demonstrating positive outcomes and no reports of harm or mixed results.

studies.title: A randomized, double-blind, placebo-controlled clinical trial, evaluating the garlic supplement effects on some serum biomarkers of oxidative stress, and quality of life in women with rheumatoid arthritis.
studies.notes: The study found significant improvements in oxidative stress biomarkers and quality of life, indicating a benefit from garlic supplementation.
