indications.summary: One randomized, double-blind, placebo-controlled trial found that garlic supplementation (500 mg twice daily for 8 weeks) resulted in significant improvements in oxidative stress biomarkers and quality of life in women with rheumatoid arthritis, indicating a potential benefit. However, the evidence is limited to a single study, and further research is needed to confirm these findings and assess long-term effects and safety.

studies.title: Effects of garlic on brachial endothelial function and capacity of plasma to mediate cholesterol efflux in patients with coronary artery disease.
studies.notes: Garlic improved endothelial function and reduced hs-CRP levels, indicating a potential benefit.

indications.summary: One randomized trial found that garlic powder taken twice daily for three months improved endothelial function and reduced high-sensitivity C-reactive protein (hs-CRP) levels in patients with coronary artery disease, suggesting a potential benefit for poor endothelial function. No studies reported mixed or negative outcomes, but further research is needed to confirm these findings and assess long-term effects and safety.

studies.title: Evaluation of the Effect of Garlic Tablet as a Complementary Treatment for Patients with Diabetic Retinopathy.
studies.notes: The study shows significant improvement in visual acuity and reduction in intraocular pressure, indicating a beneficial effect of garlic in diabetic patients.

indications.summary: One randomized trial suggests that garlic tablets (500 mg, 2 tablets per day for 4 weeks) may improve visual acuity and reduce intraocular pressure in patients with diabetic retinopathy. However, the evidence is limited to a single study, and further research is needed to confirm these findings and assess long-term effects and safety.

studies.title: Effect of Topical Garlic on Wound Healing and Scarring: A Clinical Trial.
studies.notes: The study shows that garlic ointment improved wound healing and resulted in more cosmetically appealing scars compared to Vaseline.

indications.summary: One randomized clinical trial indicated that a 30% garlic ointment applied twice daily for two weeks improved wound healing and resulted in more cosmetically appealing scars compared to a control (Vaseline). However, the overall evidence is limited, with only one study demonstrating a benefit and no reports of harm or mixed outcomes. Further research is needed to confirm these findings and assess long-term effects.

studies.title: Successful improved peripheral tissue perfusion was seen in patients with atherosclerosis after 12 months of treatment with aged garlic extract.
studies.notes: The study shows a significant improvement in peripheral tissue perfusion, indicating a beneficial effect of aged garlic extract.

indications.summary: One randomized trial reported a benefit of aged garlic extract (2400 mg daily for 12 months) in improving peripheral tissue perfusion in patients with atherosclerosis, which may suggest a potential positive effect on wound healing due to impaired blood flow. However, the overall evidence is limited, with only one study demonstrating this outcome and no data on adverse effects or additional studies to confirm these findings.

studies.title: Aged garlic extract preserves cutaneous microcirculation in patients with increased risk for cardiovascular diseases: A double-blinded placebo-controlled study.
studies.notes: The study shows a significant increase in microcirculation, indicating a benefit for patients at risk for cardiovascular events.

indications.summary: One randomized controlled trial found that aged garlic extract (2400 mg daily for one year) significantly improved cutaneous microcirculation in patients with cardiovascular disease risk, suggesting a potential benefit for poor wound healing due to impaired circulation. No studies reported mixed outcomes or adverse effects, but further research is needed to confirm these findings and establish broader applicability.

studies.title: Evaluating the effect of garlic extract on serum inflammatory markers of peritoneal dialysis patients: a randomized double-blind clinical trial study.
studies.notes: The study shows significant reduction in inflammatory markers, indicating a beneficial effect of garlic extract.

indications.summary: One randomized double-blind clinical trial reported that garlic extract (400 mg twice daily for 8 weeks) significantly reduced inflammatory markers in peritoneal dialysis patients, suggesting a beneficial effect on systemic inflammation. No studies reported mixed results or harm, but the overall evidence is limited to a single trial, indicating a need for further research to confirm these findings.

contraindications: advised against application of fresh garlic onto skin and mucosa

studies.title: The effects of ginger supplementation on common gastrointestinal symptoms in patients with relapsing-remitting multiple sclerosis: a double-blind randomized placebo-controlled trial.
studies.notes: Ginger supplementation showed significant improvements in gastrointestinal symptoms in RRMS patients, indicating a beneficial effect.

indications.summary: Ginger supplementation has shown a beneficial effect on gastrointestinal symptoms, including abdominal pain, in a double-blind randomized placebo-controlled trial involving patients with relapsing-remitting multiple sclerosis. The study utilized a dose of 500 mg of ginger three times a day for 12 weeks. No adverse effects or mixed results were reported, but further research is needed to confirm these findings across broader populations.

studies.title: Ginger extract versus Loratadine in the treatment of allergic rhinitis: a randomized controlled trial.
studies.notes: Both ginger extract and loratadine improved symptoms, but no significant difference was found between the two treatments.

indications.summary: The evidence for ginger as a treatment for allergic rhinitis is limited and mixed, with one randomized controlled trial comparing ginger extract (500 mg) to loratadine showing improvements in symptoms for both but no significant difference between the two. Overall, the findings do not support a clear benefit of ginger for this indication, and further research is needed to establish its efficacy.

studies.title: Comparison of the effect of prayer and ginger on the severity of pain and anxiety in inpatients with burn: Palliative care.
studies.notes: Ginger showed a reduction in pain levels, indicating a beneficial effect.

indications.summary: There is limited evidence suggesting that ginger may reduce anxiety, as indicated by one study that reported a benefit in patients with burn injuries using a daily dose of 250 mg. However, the overall quality of evidence is low, and further research is needed to establish the efficacy and safety of ginger for anxiety.

studies.title: Increasing Warmth in Oncological Patients: A Randomized Controlled Cross-Over Pilot Trial Examining the Efficacy of Mustard and Ginger Footbaths.
studies.notes: The study shows that ginger footbaths significantly increased warmth perception compared to warm water only, indicating a beneficial effect.

indications.summary: One randomized controlled trial found that ginger footbaths significantly increased warmth perception in oncological patients compared to warm water alone, suggesting a potential benefit for cold feet. However, the evidence is limited to this single study, and further research is needed to confirm these findings and assess the consistency of the effect.

studies.title: The effect of ginger (Zingiber officinale) supplementation on clinical, biochemical, and anthropometric parameters in patients with multiple sclerosis: a double-blind randomized controlled trial.
studies.notes: Ginger supplementation showed significant improvements in disability and quality of life metrics, indicating a beneficial effect.

indications.summary: One double-blind randomized controlled trial reported that ginger supplementation (500 mg three times daily for 12 weeks) resulted in significant improvements in disability and quality of life metrics in patients with multiple sclerosis. However, the overall evidence is limited, with only one study demonstrating benefit and no reports of harm or mixed outcomes.

studies.title: Comparison of the effect of ginger and aloe vera mouthwashes on xerostomia in patients with type 2 diabetes: A clinical trial, triple-blind.
studies.notes: The study found that ginger mouthwash significantly reduced symptoms of xerostomia, indicating a beneficial effect.

indications.summary: One randomized clinical trial found that ginger mouthwash (20 cc three times daily for 14 days) significantly reduced symptoms of xerostomia in patients with type 2 diabetes, indicating a beneficial effect. No studies reported mixed results or harm, but the evidence is limited to a single trial, necessitating caution in generalizing findings.

studies.title: Beneficial Effects of Ginger Extract on Eye Fatigue and Shoulder Stiffness: A Randomized, Double-Blind, and Placebo-Controlled Parallel Study.
studies.notes: Ginger consumption showed improvement in eye fatigue and shoulder stiffness, indicating a beneficial effect.

indications.summary: One randomized, double-blind, placebo-controlled study reported beneficial effects of ginger extract on eye fatigue after eight weeks of treatment. No adverse effects were noted, but the evidence is limited to a single study, indicating a need for further research to confirm these findings and establish consistent dosing guidelines.

studies.title: Effect of ginger on the blood glucose level of women with gestational diabetes mellitus (GDM) with impaired glucose tolerance test (GTT): a randomized double-blind placebo-controlled trial.
studies.notes: The study shows significant improvement in fasting blood sugar, insulin levels, and HOMA index, indicating a benefit from ginger supplementation.

indications.summary: One randomized double-blind placebo-controlled trial indicates that ginger supplementation may improve fasting blood sugar, insulin levels, and HOMA index in women with gestational diabetes mellitus, using a dose of 126 tablets daily for six weeks. However, the evidence is limited to a single study, and further research is needed to confirm these findings and assess long-term effects and safety.

studies.title: The Effects of Ginger (Zingiber Officinale Roscoe) on Non-Alcoholic Fatty Liver Disease in Patients with Type 2 Diabetes Mellitus: A Randomized Double-Blinded Placebo-Controlled Clinical Trial.
studies.notes: Ginger supplementation showed significant improvements in blood pressure, insulin levels, insulin resistance, and HDL-cholesterol, indicating a beneficial effect on the studied conditions.

studies.title: Effectiveness of ginger in reducing metabolic levels in people with diabetes: a randomized clinical trial.
studies.notes: The experimental group showed a greater reduction in blood glucose and total cholesterol, indicating a beneficial effect of ginger.

indications.summary: Two randomized controlled trials indicate that ginger supplementation may improve blood glucose levels in individuals with Type 2 Diabetes, with doses reported as 1000 mg twice daily and 1.2 g daily for 90 days. No adverse effects were noted in these studies, but the overall evidence is limited to a small number of trials, necessitating further research to confirm these findings.

studies.title: A Triple-blind randomized controlled trial on the effects of turmeric versus ginger on inflammatory biomarkers in patients with COVID-19.
studies.notes: The study showed that ginger had equivalent anti-inflammatory effects as turmeric in reducing inflammatory markers in COVID-19 patients, indicating a benefit.

indications.summary: The evidence for ginger in reducing inflammation in COVID-19 is limited, with only one randomized controlled trial reporting a benefit. In this study, ginger was administered at a dose of 500 mg three times daily for five days and showed equivalent anti-inflammatory effects compared to turmeric. Overall, the quality of evidence is low, and further research is needed to confirm these findings.

studies.title: An oil-in-water emulsion containing a combination of ginger extract and synthetic cannabidiol with potent in vitro anti-inflammatory effects alleviates symptoms of atopic dermatitis in a clinical trial.
studies.notes: The study demonstrated significant alleviation of symptoms in patients with atopic dermatitis, indicating a clear benefit from the treatment.

indications.summary: One clinical trial reported that an oil-in-water emulsion containing ginger extract and synthetic cannabidiol significantly alleviated symptoms of atopic dermatitis over a five-day treatment period. However, the evidence is limited to a single study, and further research is needed to confirm these findings and assess long-term safety and efficacy.

studies.title: Effects of Ginger Supplementation on Markers of Inflammation and Functional Capacity in Individuals with Mild to Moderate Joint Pain.
studies.notes: Ginger supplementation showed favorable effects on pain perception, functional capacity, and inflammatory markers, indicating a benefit for individuals with mild to moderate joint and muscle pain.

indications.summary: One randomized trial reported that ginger supplementation (125 mg daily for 58 days) had beneficial effects on pain perception, functional capacity, and inflammatory markers in individuals with mild to moderate joint pain. However, the overall evidence is limited, with only one study demonstrating a positive outcome and no reports of harm or adverse effects. Further research is needed to confirm these findings and establish consistency.

studies.title: A randomized, double-blind placebo-controlled phase I clinical study on safety and efficacy of the G-Rup® syrup (a mixture of ginger extract and honey) in symptomatic treatment of knee osteoarthritis.
studies.notes: The study reports significant improvements in pain and physical functioning, indicating a beneficial outcome.

studies.title: Effectiveness and safety of steamed ginger extract on mild osteoarthritis: a randomized, double-blind, placebo-controlled clinical trial.
studies.notes: The study showed significant improvement in joint pain and management of knee OA with no reported side effects.

indications.summary: Two randomized, double-blind, placebo-controlled trials report beneficial effects of ginger on knee pain, specifically in the context of osteoarthritis. One study used a ginger extract syrup at a dose of 30 ml twice daily, while the other utilized steamed ginger extract at a dose of 0.48 g daily, both for 12 weeks. No adverse effects were reported in these studies, but the overall evidence is limited and further research is needed to confirm these findings.

studies.title: The Effect of Ginger on Postoperative Nausea and Vomiting Among Patients Undergoing Upper and Lower Limb Surgery: A Randomized Controlled Trial.
studies.notes: The study shows that ginger significantly reduces the incidence and severity of postoperative nausea and vomiting, indicating a beneficial effect.

indications.summary: One randomized controlled trial indicates that ginger (250 mg capsules, 4 capsules taken 2 hours before surgery) may significantly reduce the incidence and severity of postoperative nausea and vomiting. However, the overall evidence is limited, with only one study reporting a benefit and no evidence of harm or mixed outcomes. Further research is needed to confirm these findings and establish consistent dosing guidelines.

studies.title: [Ginger-partitioned moxibustion in prevention of vomiting induced by chemotherapy in advanced malignant bone tumors: a randomized controlled trial].
studies.notes: The study shows that ginger-partitioned moxibustion significantly improves digestive tract reactions and quality of life, indicating a beneficial effect.

indications.summary: There is limited evidence suggesting that ginger-partitioned moxibustion may improve digestive tract reactions and quality of life in patients experiencing nausea and vomiting after chemotherapy, as indicated by one randomized controlled trial. However, the overall evidence is sparse, and further studies are needed to confirm these findings and assess consistency across different populations and dosing regimens.

studies.title: Using Ginger Oil to Treat Nausea and Vomiting Following Breast Augmentation Surgery.
studies.notes: The study demonstrated a significant reduction in postoperative nausea and vomiting (PONV) with ginger oil, indicating a beneficial effect.

indications.summary: One randomized trial reported a beneficial effect of ginger oil (3 drops) in reducing postoperative nausea and vomiting following breast augmentation surgery. However, the evidence is limited to a single study, and further research is needed to confirm these findings and assess consistency across different surgical contexts.

studies.title: Effect of ginger-partitioned moxibustion combined with ringheaded thumb-tack needle stimulation on gastrointestinal reactions of malignant tumor patients undergoing chemotherapy.

doses.formulation: ginger-partitioned moxibustion combined with ringheaded thumb-tack needle stimulation

studies.notes: The study shows that ginger-partitioned moxibustion effectively relieves nausea and vomiting in chemotherapy patients, indicating a benefit.

studies.title: Effect of ginger and P6 acupressure on chemotherapy-induced nausea and vomiting: a randomized controlled study.
studies.notes: Ginger showed significant improvement in delayed CINV but no significant effect on acute CINV, indicating mixed outcomes.

studies.title: Effect of a Standardized Ginger Root Powder Regimen on Chemotherapy-Induced Nausea and Vomiting: A Multicenter, Double-Blind, Placebo-Controlled Randomized Trial.
studies.notes: Ginger showed clinically relevant benefits in reducing nausea and vomiting related to chemotherapy, improving quality of life, and reducing fatigue and malnutrition.

studies.title: [Ginger-partitioned moxibustion in the prevention of nausea and vomiting induced by chemotherapy in lung cancer：a randomized controlled trial].
studies.notes: The study shows a benefit in preventing nausea and vomiting, improving quality of life, and enhancing blood counts after chemotherapy.

original_labels: gastrointestinal reactions in malignant tumor patients
indications.summary: The evidence on ginger for managing nausea and vomiting from chemotherapy is mixed, with three studies indicating benefits and two showing unclear outcomes. Doses reported include 84 mg of ginger root powder daily for five days and ginger-partitioned moxibustion applied once daily for three days. No studies reported significant harms associated with ginger use in this context.

studies.title: Effects of ginger adjunct to the standard prophylaxis on reducing carboplatin and paclitaxel-induced nausea vomiting: a randomized controlled study.
studies.notes: Ginger significantly reduced acute phase nausea but had no effect on delayed phase nausea and vomiting.

indications.summary: Ginger supplementation at a dose of 2 g per day has shown benefit in reducing acute nausea associated with chemotherapy, specifically in patients receiving carboplatin and paclitaxel, according to a randomized controlled trial. However, it did not demonstrate effectiveness for delayed nausea and vomiting, indicating that its benefits may be limited to specific phases of nausea. No adverse effects were reported in the study.

studies.title: Effect of honey-ginger mouthwash on oral mucositis in patients undergoing chemotherapy.
studies.notes: The study shows a beneficial effect of a 7-day ginger-honey mouthwash on reducing oral mucositis severity, but no significant effect on pain intensity.

indications.summary: One randomized trial suggests that a ginger-honey mouthwash may reduce the severity of oral mucositis in patients undergoing chemotherapy over a 7-day period, although it did not significantly affect pain intensity. Overall, the evidence is limited and only indicates a potential benefit without reporting any adverse effects or harm.

studies.title: The effect of ginger (Zingiber officinale Roscoe) in patients with advanced cancer.
studies.notes: Ginger showed improvement in gastric myoelectrical activity and symptom relief, indicating a beneficial effect.

indications.summary: One randomized trial reported that ginger (Zingiber officinale) at a dose of 1650 mg daily for 14 days improved gastric myoelectrical activity and provided symptom relief in patients with advanced cancer, suggesting a potential benefit for poor appetite. However, the evidence is limited to a single study, and further research is needed to confirm these findings and assess long-term effects and safety.

studies.title: Effect of aromatherapy with peppermint, ginger, and lavender on postoperative nausea severity after oral surgery under general anaesthesia: A single-blind randomized controlled trial.
studies.notes: Aromatherapy with ginger significantly reduced postoperative nausea severity and improved patient satisfaction, indicating a beneficial outcome.

indications.summary: One randomized controlled trial found that aromatherapy with ginger essential oil (0.01 ml) significantly reduced postoperative nausea severity and improved patient satisfaction. Overall, the evidence is limited, with only one study demonstrating a benefit and no reports of harm or no benefit. Further research is needed to confirm these findings and establish consistent dosing guidelines.

contraindications: Lower incidence of nausea and vomiting compared to control group.

studies.title: Evaluation of the effect of the administration of a glucosamine‑containing supplement on biomarkers for cartilage metabolism in soccer players: A randomized double‑blind placebo‑controlled study.
studies.notes: The study found significant decreases in biomarkers for cartilage degradation, indicating a beneficial effect of glucosamine on cartilage metabolism.

indications.summary: One randomized double-blind placebo-controlled study found that a glucosamine-containing supplement (2 g daily for 16 weeks) significantly decreased biomarkers for cartilage degradation, suggesting a beneficial effect on cartilage metabolism. However, the evidence is limited to a single study, and further research is needed to confirm these findings and assess long-term effects and safety.

studies.title: Impact of Glucosamine Supplementation on Gut Health.
studies.notes: The study showed significant benefits in gut health, particularly in reducing stomach bloating and trends towards alleviating constipation.

indications.summary: There is limited evidence suggesting that glucosamine supplementation may have a beneficial effect on gut health, including a reduction in stomach bloating and potential alleviation of constipation, based on a single study that administered 3000 mg daily for three weeks. However, the overall evidence is weak and further research is needed to confirm these findings and assess long-term effects and safety.

studies.title: Effects of glucosamine-chondroitin combination on synovial fluid IL-1β, IL-6, TNF-α and PGE2 levels in internal derangements of temporomandibular joint.
studies.notes: The study showed significant improvement in maximum mouth opening and reduction in inflammatory cytokines in the glucosamine group compared to control.

studies.title: Glucosamine oral administration as an adjunct to hyaluronic acid injection in treating temporomandibular joint osteoarthritis.
studies.notes: The study shows that glucosamine provides additional long-term benefits in reducing pain and improving mouth opening compared to placebo.

indications.summary: Two studies indicate that glucosamine may provide benefits for jaw pain, specifically in improving mouth opening and reducing inflammatory markers in temporomandibular joint disorders. Doses reported include 1500 mg daily when combined with chondroitin. However, the overall evidence remains limited and further research is needed to confirm these findings and assess long-term effects.

studies.title: Oral Glucosamine Hydrochloride Combined With Hyaluronate Sodium Intra-Articular Injection for Temporomandibular Joint Osteoarthritis: A Double-Blind Randomized Controlled Trial.
studies.notes: The study showed mixed results; glucosamine had no meaningful short-term effect but did relieve pain and improve function in the long-term.

indications.summary: The evidence for glucosamine in treating jaw pain from temporomandibular joint osteoarthritis is low quality, with one double-blind randomized controlled trial reporting mixed results. While the study indicated that glucosamine may not have a meaningful short-term effect, it suggested potential long-term benefits in pain relief and function improvement at a dose of 1.44 g daily for three months. No adverse effects were reported, but overall findings are inconclusive.

studies.title: Differences in Serum Biomarkers Between Combined Glucosamine and Chondroitin Versus Celecoxib in a Randomized, Double-blind Trial in Osteoarthritis Patients.
studies.notes: The study shows a significant reduction in IL-6, indicating a beneficial effect of glucosamine in reducing inflammation.

studies.title: Effectiveness of a Dietary Supplement Containing Hydrolyzed Collagen, Chondroitin Sulfate, and Glucosamine in Pain Reduction and Functional Capacity in Osteoarthritis Patients.
studies.notes: The study shows significant reductions in pain and improvements in functional capacity, indicating a beneficial outcome.

studies.title: Comparison of the efficacy and tolerability of chondroitin plus glucosamine and D-002 (beeswax alcohols) in subjects with osteoarthritis symptoms.
studies.notes: The study shows significant reductions in OA symptoms with glucosamine, indicating a beneficial effect.

indications.summary: The evidence for glucosamine in treating joint pain from osteoarthritis includes three studies demonstrating benefits, particularly in reducing inflammation and improving pain and functional capacity, with doses reported around 1500 mg daily and 375 mg combined with chondroitin. However, one study indicated mixed outcomes potentially due to variability in plasma levels, suggesting that results may not be consistent across all patients. No studies reported harm associated with glucosamine use.

studies.title: The role of diet and exercise and of glucosamine sulfate in the prevention of knee osteoarthritis: Further results from the PRevention of knee Osteoarthritis in Overweight Females (PROOF) study.
studies.notes: Glucosamine sulfate significantly decreased the risk of developing knee OA, indicating a beneficial outcome.

indications.summary: One randomized trial found that glucosamine sulfate at a dose of 1500 mg once daily for 2.5 years significantly decreased the risk of developing knee osteoarthritis in overweight females, indicating a beneficial outcome. No studies reported mixed results, harm, or no benefit, suggesting a positive effect; however, further research is needed to confirm these findings and assess long-term safety.

studies.title: Comparative study of the efficacy of glucosamine sulfate capsules and Huoxue Xiaozhong prescription in the treatment of knee osteoarthritis and the recovery of knee joint function.
studies.notes: The study shows mixed outcomes; glucosamine sulfate was effective in pain relief but less effective in overall joint function improvement compared to traditional Chinese medicine.

studies.title: Effect of celecoxib combined with glucosamine hydrochloride in promoting the functional recovery and decreasing the inflammatory factor levels in patients with knee osteoarthritis.
studies.notes: The study shows that the combination of celecoxib and glucosamine hydrochloride is effective in improving functional recovery and reducing inflammatory factors in knee osteoarthritis patients, indicating a beneficial outcome.

studies.title: Multicenter, randomized, double-blind clinical trial to evaluate efficacy and safety of combined glucosamine sulfate and chondroitin sulfate capsules for treating knee osteoarthritis.
studies.notes: The study demonstrated the efficacy of the glucosamine sulfate combination in treating knee osteoarthritis with a good safety profile.

studies.title: Mud-bath therapy and oral glucosamine sulfate in patients with knee osteoarthritis: a randomized, controlled, crossover study.
studies.notes: The study shows significant improvement in pain, function, and quality of life in knee OA patients, indicating a benefit from glucosamine sulfate.

studies.title: Milk-Fat Globule Membrane Plus Glucosamine Improves Joint Function and Physical Performance: A Randomized, Double-Blind, Placebo-Controlled, Parallel-Group Study.
studies.notes: The study reports significant improvements in joint function and physical performance, indicating a beneficial effect of glucosamine.

studies.title: Effectiveness of Cucumis sativus extract versus glucosamine-chondroitin in the management of moderate osteoarthritis: a randomized controlled trial.
studies.notes: The study shows a greater reduction in pain scores for the Cucumis sativus extract compared to glucosamine-chondroitin, indicating a benefit.

studies.title: Glucosamine-containing supplement improves locomotor functions in subjects with knee pain: a randomized, double-blind, placebo-controlled study.
studies.notes: The study showed significant improvements in knee-extensor strength and walking speed in the glucosamine group compared to placebo, indicating a benefit.

studies.title: Effects of N-acetyl glucosamine and chondroitin sulfate supplementation on knee pain and self-reported knee function in middle-aged and older Japanese adults: a randomized, double-blind, placebo-controlled trial.
studies.notes: The study showed a significant improvement in knee function and household physical activity, indicating a benefit from the supplementation.

indications.summary: The evidence from randomized trials indicates that glucosamine is generally effective in improving knee pain and function in patients with knee osteoarthritis, with benefits reported in multiple studies. Typical doses reported include glucosamine sulfate and glucosamine hydrochloride, often ranging from 1.2 g to 1.5 g daily. However, one study presented mixed outcomes regarding overall joint function improvement, suggesting variability in effectiveness across different formulations and combinations.

studies.title: Methylsulfonylmethane and boswellic acids versus glucosamine sulfate in the treatment of knee arthritis: Randomized trial.
studies.notes: The study shows improvements in both treatment groups, but the results favor the experimental group, indicating mixed outcomes.

indications.summary: The clinical evidence for glucosamine in treating knee pain from arthritis is limited and mixed, with one randomized trial indicating unclear outcomes when compared to other treatments. The study reported a dose of 1500 mg of glucosamine sulfate daily for 60 days, but overall, no definitive benefits were established. No adverse effects were noted in the available evidence.

studies.title: The synergic use of the High Power Laser Therapy and Glucosamine sulfate in Knee osteoarthritis: A Randomized Controlled Trial.
studies.notes: The study shows significant long-term benefits of glucosamine sulfate combined with HPLT in treating knee osteoarthritis.

studies.title: Treatment of knee osteoarthritis with a new formulation of a fixed-dose combination of glucosamine sulfate and bovine chondroitin: a multicenter, randomized, single-blind, non-inferiority clinical trial.
studies.notes: The study demonstrated non-inferiority of glucosamine sulfate combined with chondroitin sulfate in improving knee osteoarthritis symptoms, indicating a benefit.

studies.title: Comparison of Glucosamine-Chondroitin Sulfate with and without Methylsulfonylmethane in Grade I-II Knee Osteoarthritis: A Double Blind Randomized Controlled Trial.
studies.notes: The study found significant clinical benefits for the combination treatment involving glucosamine.

studies.title: The efficacy and safety of a combination of glucosamine hydrochloride, chondroitin sulfate and bio-curcumin with exercise in the treatment of knee osteoarthritis: a randomized, double-blind, placebo-controlled study.
studies.notes: The study showed significant improvements in pain and function in knee OA patients, indicating a benefit from the treatment.

studies.title: Combined chondroitin sulfate and glucosamine for painful knee osteoarthritis: a multicentre, randomised, double-blind, non-inferiority trial versus celecoxib.
studies.notes: The study demonstrated comparable efficacy of glucosamine combined with chondroitin sulfate to celecoxib in reducing pain and other symptoms in knee osteoarthritis.

studies.title: [Comparative efficacy of a combination of undenatured type II collagen, Boswellic acids, methylsulfonylmethane, vitamins C and D3 and a combination of chondroitin sulfate and glucosamine hydrochloride in the treatment of primary osteoarthritis of the knee joint].
studies.notes: The study showed improvements in WOMAC index and pain, but no significant intergroup differences, indicating mixed outcomes.

indications.summary: The evidence for glucosamine in treating knee pain from osteoarthritis is predominantly positive, with five randomized controlled trials reporting benefits, particularly at doses of 1500 mg. However, two studies presented mixed outcomes, indicating that while glucosamine may be effective, results can vary depending on the formulation and comparison treatments used. No significant adverse effects were reported in the reviewed studies.

studies.title: Clinical efficacy of glucosamine hydrochloride tablets in the treatment of cervical spondylosis.
studies.notes: The study shows significant advantages in treatment efficacy and patient satisfaction with glucosamine compared to the reference group.

indications.summary: One randomized trial reported a benefit of glucosamine hydrochloride in treating cervical spondylosis, showing significant treatment efficacy and patient satisfaction compared to a reference group. However, the overall evidence is limited, with only one study available, and no adverse effects were noted. Further research is needed to confirm these findings and establish consistent dosing guidelines.

studies.title: Phonophoretic application of a glucosamine and chondroitin nanoemulsion for treatment of knee chondropathies.
studies.notes: The study showed some pain reduction and recovery in patients, but no statistical significance was found.

indications.summary: The clinical evidence for glucosamine in the treatment of osteoarthritis is mixed and unclear, with two studies reporting variable outcomes. One study noted no significant differences in pharmacokinetics, while another suggested some pain reduction without statistical significance. No consistent dosing information was provided across studies, and no evidence of harm was reported.

studies.title: Oral Administration of Glucosamine Improves Vascular Endothelial Function by Modulating Intracellular Redox State.
studies.notes: Glucosamine administration improved vascular endothelial function and intracellular redox state, indicating a beneficial effect.

indications.summary: There is limited evidence suggesting that glucosamine may improve vascular endothelial function, as indicated by one study that reported a benefit with a daily dose of 3000 mg for four weeks. However, due to the low quantity of studies and lack of corroborating evidence, the overall confidence in glucosamine's effectiveness for poor vascular health remains low.

studies.title: Efficacy of Glucosamine Sulphate in Skin Ageing: Results from an ex vivo Anti-Ageing Model and a Clinical Trial.
studies.notes: The study shows a positive effect of glucosamine on skin markers associated with ageing.

indications.summary: The evidence for glucosamine in addressing skin ageing is limited, with a single clinical trial reporting a positive effect on skin markers associated with ageing at a dose of 250 mg once daily for 8 weeks. Overall, the quality of evidence is low, and further research is needed to confirm these findings and assess long-term safety and efficacy.

studies.title: Randomized trial of glucosamine and chondroitin supplementation on inflammation and oxidative stress biomarkers and plasma proteomics profiles in healthy humans.
studies.notes: The study found a significant reduction in serum CRP concentrations, indicating a benefit in reducing systemic inflammation.

indications.summary: One randomized trial reported a benefit of glucosamine (1500 mg daily for 28 days) in reducing serum CRP concentrations, suggesting a potential effect on systemic inflammation. However, the overall evidence is limited, with only one study demonstrating this outcome and no additional studies to corroborate the findings. No adverse effects were reported in the available evidence.

contraindications: Statistically significant rise of intraocular pressure in elderly patients
mild and transient adverse effects similar to placebo
no increased wound bleeding observed in patients treated with antiplatelet drugs

studies.title: Effect of oral glycine on the clinical, spirometric and inflammatory status in subjects with cystic fibrosis: a pilot randomized trial.
studies.notes: The study showed improvement in clinical, spirometric, and inflammatory outcomes after glycine intake, indicating a beneficial effect.

indications.summary: One pilot randomized trial reported a beneficial effect of oral glycine (0.5 g/kg daily for 8 weeks) on clinical, spirometric, and inflammatory outcomes in individuals with cystic fibrosis. However, the evidence is limited to a single study, and further research is needed to confirm these findings and assess long-term safety and efficacy.

studies.title: Dose-Related Target Occupancy and Effects on Circuitry, Behavior, and Neuroplasticity of the Glycine Transporter-1 Inhibitor PF-03463275 in Healthy and Schizophrenia Subjects.
studies.notes: The study shows improvement in working memory accuracy, indicating a benefit from the intervention.

indications.summary: One randomized trial reported a benefit of glycine on working memory accuracy in healthy and schizophrenia subjects, with doses ranging from 10 mg to 60 mg taken twice a day. However, the overall evidence is limited, and further studies are needed to confirm these findings and assess long-term effects and safety.

studies.title: Activation of N-methyl-D-aspartate receptor glycine site temporally ameliorates neuropsychiatric symptoms of Parkinson's disease with dementia.
studies.notes: The study shows significant improvement in neuropsychiatric symptoms and depression in patients treated with sarcosine, indicating a beneficial effect.

indications.summary: The evidence for glycine in the treatment of depression is limited but suggests potential benefits, with two studies reporting positive outcomes. One study indicated significant improvement in neuropsychiatric symptoms and depression in patients with Parkinson's disease, while another trial showed a reduction in depressive symptoms with GLYX-13, a glycine site partial agonist, at doses ranging from 1 to 30 mg/kg. Overall, the quality of evidence is low, and further research is needed to establish efficacy and safety.

studies.title: Capryloyl glycine and soy isoflavonoids in hypertrichosis: An experimental and placebo-controlled clinical study.
studies.notes: The study showed significant improvement in hypertrichosis with the cream containing glycine.

indications.summary: One randomized controlled trial reported a benefit of a cream containing 4% capryloyl glycine applied twice daily for four months in improving hypertrichosis. However, the evidence is limited to a single study, and further research is needed to confirm these findings and assess long-term safety and efficacy.

studies.title: 2-Mercaptonicotinoyl glycine prevents UV-induced skin darkening and delayed tanning in healthy subjects: A randomized controlled clinical study.
studies.notes: The study shows that 2-MNG significantly reduces skin pigmentation caused by UV exposure, indicating a beneficial effect.

indications.summary: One randomized controlled trial indicates that glycine, in the form of 2-Mercaptonicotinoyl glycine at doses of 0.5% and 1% in a cosmetic formula, may reduce skin pigmentation caused by UV exposure. However, the evidence is limited to a single study, and further research is needed to confirm these findings and assess long-term safety and efficacy.

studies.title: Combined Supplementation with Glycine and Tryptophan Reduces Purine-Induced Serum Uric Acid Elevation by Accelerating Urinary Uric Acid Excretion: A Randomized, Single-Blind, Placebo-Controlled, Crossover Study.
studies.notes: The study shows that glycine supplementation significantly reduced serum uric acid levels, indicating a beneficial effect.

studies.title: Serum Uric Acid-Lowering Effects of Combined Glycine and Tryptophan Treatments in Subjects with Mild Hyperuricemia: A Randomized, Double-Blind, Placebo-Controlled, Crossover Study.
studies.notes: The study shows a significant decrease in serum uric acid levels, indicating a beneficial effect of glycine supplementation.

indications.summary: Human clinical evidence suggests that glycine supplementation may reduce serum uric acid levels, with two randomized controlled trials reporting beneficial effects. One study utilized a dose of 3.0 g of a glycine and tryptophan mixture daily for six weeks. No adverse effects were reported in the studies, but the overall evidence remains limited and further research is needed to confirm these findings.

studies.title: Glycine increases fat-free mass in malnourished haemodialysis patients: a randomized double-blind crossover trial.
studies.notes: Glycine improved fat-free mass index in patients, indicating a beneficial effect.

indications.summary: There is limited evidence suggesting that glycine may increase fat-free mass in malnourished hemodialysis patients, as indicated by one randomized double-blind crossover trial that reported a benefit with a dose of 7 g taken orally twice daily for 4 months. Overall, the evidence is low-quality and further research is needed to establish the efficacy and safety of glycine for low muscle mass in broader populations.

studies.title: The effects of glycine on auditory mismatch negativity in schizophrenia.
studies.notes: Chronic glycine administration improved clinical symptoms in schizophrenia, indicating a benefit.

studies.title: Efficacy and safety of the glycine transporter type-1 inhibitor AMG 747 for the treatment of negative symptoms associated with schizophrenia.
studies.notes: The primary outcome showed no differences, but secondary outcomes indicated potential benefit at the 15 mg dose, leading to a mixed classification.

indications.summary: The evidence for glycine in treating negative symptoms of schizophrenia is limited and mixed. One study reported a benefit with chronic administration of glycine at doses of 0.2 g/kg and 0.6 g/kg daily, while another study on a glycine transporter inhibitor showed no primary benefit but suggested potential effects at a lower dose of 15 mg. Overall, the findings are not consistent, and further research is needed to clarify its efficacy.

studies.title: Supplementing Glycine and N-Acetylcysteine (GlyNAC) in Older Adults Improves Glutathione Deficiency, Oxidative Stress, Mitochondrial Dysfunction, Inflammation, Physical Function, and Aging Hallmarks: A Randomized Clinical Trial.
studies.notes: The study demonstrated that GlyNAC supplementation improved multiple age-associated abnormalities, indicating a beneficial outcome.

indications.summary: One randomized clinical trial found that supplementation with Glycine and N-Acetylcysteine (GlyNAC) improved markers of oxidative stress and other age-related abnormalities in older adults over a 16-week period. However, the evidence is limited to a single study, and further research is needed to confirm these findings and assess long-term effects and safety.

studies.title: Targeted Treatment of Individuals With Psychosis Carrying a Copy Number Variant Containing a Genomic Triplication of the Glycine Decarboxylase Gene.
studies.notes: The study demonstrated symptom relief in psychotic disorders with glycine augmentation.

indications.summary: The evidence for glycine in treating psychotic symptoms is limited, with only one study reporting a benefit in symptom relief for individuals with specific genetic variants. Overall, the quality of evidence is low, and no consistent dose ranges or adverse effects have been reported. Further research is needed to establish efficacy and safety.

studies.title: Effects of Glycine max (L.) Merr. soy isoflavone vaginal gel on epithelium morphology and estrogen receptor expression in postmenopausal women: a 12-week, randomized, double-blind, placebo-controlled trial.
studies.notes: The study shows significant improvements in vaginal atrophy symptoms and related outcomes, indicating a beneficial effect of the treatment.

indications.summary: Two randomized, double-blind, placebo-controlled trials indicate that glycine, delivered as a 4% vaginal gel, may improve symptoms of vaginal dryness and enhance vaginal vascularization in postmenopausal women over a 12-week period. However, the evidence is limited to these studies, and no adverse effects were reported, necessitating further research to confirm these findings and establish long-term safety and efficacy.

contraindications: Stevens-Johnson Syndrome/Toxic Epidermal Necrolysis reported in one participant
higher rate of adverse effects in ferrous glycine sulfate group

studies.title: Formulation and evaluation on human skin of a water-in-oil emulsion containing Muscat hamburg black grape seed extract.
studies.notes: The formulation showed significant benefits in improving skin conditions without reported adverse effects.

indications.summary: One study evaluated a water-in-oil emulsion containing 2% Muscat hamburg black grape seed extract applied twice daily for 8 weeks, reporting significant benefits in improving skin conditions related to acne without any adverse effects. Overall, the evidence is limited to a single study, indicating a need for further research to confirm these findings.

studies.title: The effects of grape seed extract (Vitis vinifera) supplement on inflammatory markers, neuropeptide Y, anthropometric measures, and appetite in obese or overweight individuals: A randomized clinical trial.
studies.notes: The study showed significant reductions in body weight and inflammatory markers in the GSE group, indicating a beneficial effect on obesity and related health outcomes.

studies.title: Effect of the intake of resveratrol, resveratrol phosphate, and catechin-rich grape seed extract on markers of oxidative stress and gene expression in adult obese subjects.
studies.notes: The study indicates a significant reduction of oxidative stress, suggesting a beneficial outcome.

indications.summary: Clinical evidence suggests that grape seed extract may have beneficial effects on body weight in overweight or obese individuals, with two randomized trials reporting positive outcomes. Doses reported include 300 mg daily for 12 weeks and 1 capsule daily for 28 days. However, the overall evidence is limited, and further research is needed to confirm these findings and assess long-term effects.

studies.title: The effects of grape seed extract supplementation on cardiovascular risk factors, liver enzymes and hepatic steatosis in patients with non-alcoholic fatty liver disease: a randomised, double-blind, placebo-controlled study.
studies.notes: The study showed significant improvements in various metabolic factors and liver health indicators in NAFLD patients after GSE supplementation, indicating a beneficial effect.

indications.summary: One randomized, double-blind, placebo-controlled study reported that grape seed extract (520 mg daily for 2 months) led to significant improvements in metabolic factors and liver health indicators in patients with non-alcoholic fatty liver disease (NAFLD). No studies reported mixed outcomes or harm, but the evidence is limited to a single trial, necessitating caution in interpretation.

studies.title: Efficacy of grape seed extract gel in the treatment of chronic periodontitis: A randomized clinical study.
studies.notes: The study showed significant improvement in gingival index and plaque index, indicating a benefit from the treatment.

indications.summary: One randomized clinical study reported a benefit of grape seed extract gel (2% concentration) in improving gingival and plaque indices in patients with chronic periodontitis. However, the evidence is limited to a single study, and further research is needed to confirm these findings and assess long-term effects and safety.

studies.title: Effects of Acute Grape Seed Extract Supplementation on Hemodynamics in Normal Body Weight and Obese Males.
studies.notes: The study shows a significant reduction in systolic and mean arterial blood pressure after GSE supplementation, indicating a beneficial effect on hemodynamics in both normal weight and obese males.

studies.title: Effects of chronic dietary grape seed extract supplementation on aortic stiffness and hemodynamic responses in obese/overweight males during submaximal exercise.
studies.notes: The study shows a significant reduction in arterial pressure and aortic stiffness, indicating a beneficial effect of grape seed extract supplementation in the studied population.

studies.title: Grape Seed Extract Positively Modulates Blood Pressure and Perceived Stress: A Randomized, Double-Blind, Placebo-Controlled Study in Healthy Volunteers.
studies.notes: The study demonstrated a significant benefit in modulating blood pressure and perceived stress in healthy volunteers.

studies.title: Effect of 7-day dietary supplementation with grape seed extract on cardiac autonomic and hemodynamic responses in elevated and stage 1 hypertension.
studies.notes: The study indicates a reduction in blood pressure, suggesting a beneficial effect of grape seed extract in individuals with elevated and stage 1 hypertension.

studies.title: Effect of grape seed extract on blood pressure in subjects with the metabolic syndrome.
studies.notes: Blood pressure was significantly lowered after treatment with grape seed extract compared to placebo, indicating a beneficial effect.

studies.title: Effects of grape seed extract beverage on blood pressure and metabolic indices in individuals with pre-hypertension: a randomised, double-blinded, two-arm, parallel, placebo-controlled trial.
studies.notes: Grape seed extract significantly reduced blood pressure in individuals with pre-hypertension, indicating a beneficial effect.

studies.title: Grape Seed Extract Supplementation Attenuates the Blood Pressure Response to Exercise in Prehypertensive Men.
studies.notes: The study shows that Grape Seed Extract supplementation benefits prehypertensive males by reducing blood pressure and enhancing endothelial function during exercise.

indications.summary: The evidence from multiple randomized trials indicates that grape seed extract may significantly reduce blood pressure in various populations, including healthy individuals and those with pre-hypertension or metabolic syndrome. Doses reported in these studies typically range from 150 mg to 300 mg daily. No adverse effects were noted in the studies reviewed, but the overall quality of evidence should be interpreted with caution due to variability in study designs and populations.

studies.title: Effects of grape seed extract in Type 2 diabetic subjects at high cardiovascular risk: a double blind randomized placebo controlled trial examining metabolic markers, vascular tone, inflammation, oxidative stress and insulin sensitivity.
studies.notes: Grape seed extract showed significant improvements in markers of inflammation and glycaemia, indicating a beneficial effect.

indications.summary: One randomized controlled trial has reported that grape seed extract (600 mg daily for 4 weeks) may improve markers of inflammation and glycaemia in individuals with Type 2 diabetes at high cardiovascular risk. No studies reported mixed results or harm, but the evidence is limited to a single trial, necessitating caution in interpretation.

studies.title: The effect of red grape seed extract on serum paraoxonase activity in patients with mild to moderate hyperlipidemia.
studies.notes: The study shows significant improvements in lipid profiles and paraoxonase activity, indicating a beneficial effect of grape seed extract.

indications.summary: One randomized trial reported that red grape seed extract (200 mg daily for eight weeks) significantly improved lipid profiles in patients with mild to moderate hyperlipidemia, suggesting a potential benefit for high cholesterol. However, the evidence is limited to a single study, and further research is needed to confirm these findings and assess long-term effects and safety.

studies.title: Beneficial effects of grape seed extract on malondialdehyde-modified LDL.
studies.notes: The study shows significant reductions in oxidized LDL levels, indicating a beneficial effect on cardiovascular health.

studies.title: Red grape seed extract improves lipid profiles and decreases oxidized low-density lipoprotein in patients with mild hyperlipidemia.
studies.notes: The study shows a significant reduction in total cholesterol, LDL cholesterol, and Ox-LDL, indicating a beneficial effect on lipid profiles.

studies.title: Grape seed extract supplementation along with a restricted-calorie diet improves cardiovascular risk factors in obese or overweight adult individuals: A randomized, placebo-controlled trial.
studies.notes: The study showed significant improvements in blood lipid profiles and cardiovascular risk factors, indicating a beneficial effect of GSE supplementation.

indications.summary: Clinical evidence from three randomized trials indicates that grape seed extract may have beneficial effects on LDL cholesterol and overall lipid profiles, with doses commonly reported at 200 mg to 400 mg daily over periods of 8 to 12 weeks. No studies reported harm or lack of benefit, suggesting a consistent positive outcome; however, the overall quality and long-term effects of grape seed extract supplementation remain unclear.

studies.title: Proanthocyanidin-rich grape seed extract reduces leg swelling in healthy women during prolonged sitting.
studies.notes: The study shows that grape seed extract significantly suppressed leg swelling, indicating a beneficial effect.

indications.summary: There is limited evidence suggesting that grape seed extract may reduce leg swelling, as indicated by one study that reported a significant benefit in healthy women during prolonged sitting. However, the overall quality of evidence is low, and further research is needed to confirm these findings and assess long-term effects and safety.

studies.title: Effects of Grape Seed Extract Supplementation on Endothelial Function and Endurance Performance in Basketball Players.
studies.notes: The study demonstrated that Grape seed extract improved endurance performance and endothelial function, indicating a beneficial outcome.

indications.summary: There is limited evidence suggesting that grape seed extract may improve endurance performance, as indicated by one study involving basketball players that reported benefits after 14 days of supplementation. However, due to the low quantity of studies and the lack of corroborating evidence, the overall confidence in this finding is low.

studies.title: Grape seed extract supplementation in non-alcoholic fatty liver disease.
studies.notes: The study shows significant improvements in oxidative stress markers and quality of life in NAFLD patients receiving GSE, indicating a beneficial effect.

indications.summary: One randomized trial reported that grape seed extract (GSE) supplementation at a dose of 250 mg twice daily for two months resulted in significant improvements in oxidative stress markers and quality of life in patients with non-alcoholic fatty liver disease (NAFLD). However, the evidence is limited to a single study, and further research is needed to confirm these findings and assess long-term effects and safety.

studies.title: Comparative effect of grape seed extract (Vitis vinifera) and ascorbic acid in oxidative stress induced by on-pump coronary artery bypass surgery.
studies.notes: The study showed that grape seed extract had antioxidative effects and reduced deleterious effects of CPB, indicating a beneficial outcome.

indications.summary: One randomized trial demonstrated that grape seed extract (100 mg every 6 hours for 24 hours before surgery) has antioxidative effects and may reduce oxidative stress during on-pump coronary artery bypass surgery. No studies reported mixed outcomes or adverse effects, but the evidence is limited to a single trial, indicating a need for further research to confirm these findings.

studies.title: Effect of a standardized grape seed extract on low-density lipoprotein susceptibility to oxidation in heavy smokers.
studies.notes: The study showed a significant reduction in oxidative indices, indicating a benefit from grape seed extract in heavy smokers.

indications.summary: One randomized trial demonstrated that grape seed extract (75 mg, two capsules twice daily for 4 weeks) significantly reduced oxidative indices in heavy smokers, suggesting a potential benefit in addressing oxidative stress from smoking. No adverse effects were reported in this study, but further research is needed to confirm these findings and establish consistency across larger populations.

studies.title: The topical effect of grape seed extract 2% cream on surgery wound healing.
studies.notes: The study showed significant improvement in wound healing with grape seed extract compared to placebo.

indications.summary: One randomized trial reported a significant benefit of a 2% grape seed extract cream applied topically for 21 days in improving wound healing compared to placebo. However, the evidence is limited to a single study, and further research is needed to confirm these findings and assess any potential adverse effects.

studies.title: Bioavailability of bioactive compounds in Hibiscus sabdariffa beverage as a potential anti-inflammatory.
studies.notes: The study indicates potential anti-inflammatory benefits of Hibiscus sabdariffa based on the bioavailability of its compounds.

indications.summary: Current evidence on hibiscus for anti-inflammatory effects is limited, with only one study suggesting potential benefits from a single dose of 60 mL of Hibiscus sabdariffa beverage, based on the bioavailability of its bioactive compounds. Overall, the evidence is low quality and lacks consistency, with no studies reporting harm or clear adverse effects.

studies.title: The aqueous extract of Hibiscus sabdariffa calices modulates the production of monocyte chemoattractant protein-1 in humans.
studies.notes: The study shows a significant decrease in plasma MCP-1 concentrations, indicating a beneficial effect in inflammatory conditions.

indications.summary: There is limited evidence suggesting that Hibiscus sabdariffa may have a beneficial effect on chronic inflammation, as indicated by a single study demonstrating a significant decrease in plasma monocyte chemoattractant protein-1 (MCP-1) concentrations following the administration of 10 g of an aqueous extract. However, due to the low quantity of studies and lack of replication, the overall evidence remains weak and inconclusive.

studies.title: The Efficacy of a Dietary Supplement with Carnosine and Hibiscus Sabdariffa L. (AqualiefTM) in Patients with Xerostomia: a Randomized, Placebo-Controlled, Double-Blind Trial.
studies.notes: The study demonstrated significant improvements in saliva pH and production in xerostomic patients treated with AqualiefTM, indicating a beneficial effect.

indications.summary: One randomized, placebo-controlled trial reported that a dietary supplement containing hibiscus (AqualiefTM) significantly improved saliva pH and production in patients with dry mouth (xerostomia). No adverse effects were noted in this study, but the overall evidence is limited to a single trial, indicating a need for further research to confirm these findings.

studies.title: Hibiscus Collagen Alternative (VC-H1) as an Oral Skin Rejuvenating Agent: A 12-Week Pilot Study.
studies.notes: The study demonstrated significant improvements in skin hydration, elasticity, and wrinkle reduction, indicating a beneficial effect of Hibiscus as a skin rejuvenating agent.

indications.summary: One pilot study (PMID 40806423) reported that a daily dose of 1.5 g of Hibiscus (VC-H1) for 12 weeks led to significant improvements in skin hydration, elasticity, and wrinkle reduction, suggesting a potential benefit for dry skin. However, the evidence is limited to this single study, and further research is needed to confirm these findings and assess long-term effects and safety.

studies.title: Hibiscus sabdariffa tea affects diet-induced thermogenesis and subjective satiety responses in healthy men but not in women: a randomized crossover trial.
studies.notes: The study demonstrated benefits in energy expenditure and satiety responses in men, indicating a positive effect of Hibiscus sabdariffa tea.

indications.summary: One randomized crossover trial found that Hibiscus sabdariffa tea positively affected energy expenditure and subjective satiety responses in healthy men, with no reported adverse effects. However, the evidence is limited to this single study, and findings may not be generalizable to women or other populations.

studies.title: Effectiveness of a polyphenolic extract (Lippia citriodora and Hibiscus sabdariffa) on appetite regulation in overweight and obese grade I population: an 8-week randomized, double-blind, cross-over, placebo-controlled trial.
studies.notes: The study demonstrated a decrease in appetite sensation and reduced calorie intake in the treatment group, indicating a beneficial effect of Hibiscus.

studies.title: Differential effects of a combination of Hibiscus sabdariffa and Lippia citriodora polyphenols in overweight/obese subjects: A randomized controlled trial.
studies.notes: The study demonstrated significant improvements in body weight, abdominal circumference, body fat percentage, heart rate, and systolic blood pressure in overweight subjects, indicating a beneficial effect of Hibiscus.

studies.title: Hibiscus and lemon verbena polyphenols modulate appetite-related biomarkers in overweight subjects: a randomized controlled trial.
studies.notes: The study showed improvements in anthropometric measurements, decreased blood pressure, and positive health perceptions, indicating a beneficial effect of Hibiscus on weight management.

indications.summary: Clinical evidence from three randomized controlled trials indicates that Hibiscus may have beneficial effects on body weight and appetite regulation in overweight and obese individuals. The studies reported improvements in various anthropometric measurements and appetite-related biomarkers, with doses of polyphenolic extracts ranging from 500 mg daily to unspecified amounts over periods of 60 to 60 days. No adverse effects were noted, but the overall quality of evidence is limited to a small number of studies.

studies.title: Hibiscus sabdariffa extract inhibits obesity and fat accumulation, and improves liver steatosis in humans.
studies.notes: The study demonstrated a reduction in obesity and improvement in liver steatosis, indicating a beneficial effect of Hibiscus sabdariffa extract.

indications.summary: One randomized trial suggests that Hibiscus sabdariffa extract may reduce obesity and improve liver steatosis in individuals with fatty liver disease over a 12-week period. However, the overall evidence is limited, with only one study reporting a benefit and no adverse effects noted. Further research is needed to confirm these findings and establish consistent dosing guidelines.

studies.title: Acute Effects of Hibiscus Sabdariffa Calyces on Postprandial Blood Pressure, Vascular Function, Blood Lipids, Biomarkers of Insulin Resistance and Inflammation in Humans.
studies.notes: The study showed significant improvements in vascular function and potential benefits for cardiovascular risk factors, indicating a positive outcome.

studies.title: The acute impact of polyphenols from Hibiscus sabdariffa in metabolic homeostasis: an approach combining metabolomics and gene-expression analyses.
studies.notes: The study indicates beneficial effects on metabolic and cardiovascular health, suggesting a positive outcome direction.

studies.title: A Randomized, Double-Blind, Placebo-Controlled Trial to Determine the Effectiveness of a Polyphenolic Extract (Hibiscus sabdariffa and Lippia citriodora) for Reducing Blood Pressure in Prehypertensive and Type 1 Hypertensive Subjects.
studies.notes: The study demonstrated a significant reduction in blood pressure parameters with the HS-LC extract, indicating a beneficial effect.

studies.title: Clinical efficacy of African traditional medicines in hypertension: A randomized controlled trial with Combretum micranthum and Hibiscus sabdariffa.
studies.notes: The study demonstrated a significant decrease in blood pressure with Hibiscus sabdariffa, indicating a beneficial effect in treating hypertension.

studies.title: The effects of sour tea (Hibiscus sabdariffa) on hypertension in patients with type II diabetes.
studies.notes: The study shows a significant reduction in systolic blood pressure in the Hibiscus group, indicating a beneficial effect.

studies.title: Clinical effects produced by a standardized herbal medicinal product of Hibiscus sabdariffa on patients with hypertension. A randomized, double-blind, lisinopril-controlled clinical trial.

doses.formulation: dried extract of H. sabdariffa calyxes

studies.notes: The study shows significant reductions in blood pressure and good tolerability, indicating a beneficial effect of Hibiscus on hypertension.

studies.title: Effectiveness and tolerability of a standardized extract from Hibiscus sabdariffa in patients with mild to moderate hypertension: a controlled and randomized clinical trial.
studies.notes: The study showed a reduction in blood pressure with Hibiscus, but no significant differences compared to captopril, indicating mixed outcomes.

studies.title: Hibiscus sabdariffa L. tea (tisane) lowers blood pressure in prehypertensive and mildly hypertensive adults.
studies.notes: The study found that hibiscus tea significantly lowered systolic blood pressure, indicating a beneficial effect.

studies.title: Effects of aqueous extract of Hibiscus sabdariffa on the renin-angiotensin-aldosterone system of Nigerians with mild to moderate essential hypertension: A comparative study with lisinopril.
studies.notes: The study showed that Hibiscus extract significantly reduced plasma aldosterone levels comparable to lisinopril, indicating a beneficial effect on hypertension.

studies.title: Effect of Hibiscus sabdariffaon blood pressure and electrolyte profile of mild to moderate hypertensive Nigerians: A comparative study with hydrochlorothiazide.
studies.notes: The study demonstrated that Hibiscus sabdariffa significantly reduced blood pressure and did not cause electrolyte imbalance, indicating a beneficial effect compared to hydrochlorothiazide.

indications.summary: The evidence from randomized trials suggests that Hibiscus sabdariffa may effectively reduce blood pressure in individuals with hypertension, with multiple studies reporting significant benefits. Typical doses reported include 250 mg of dried extract daily, 320 mg of plant powder twice daily, and various aqueous extracts in different forms. However, one study showed mixed results, indicating the need for further research to clarify its efficacy compared to standard treatments.

studies.title: Effects of Hibiscus sabdariffa extract powder and preventive treatment (diet) on the lipid profiles of patients with metabolic syndrome (MeSy).
studies.notes: The study reports significant improvements in lipid profiles and glucose levels in patients with metabolic syndrome treated with Hibiscus extract.

studies.title: Effects of sour tea (Hibiscus sabdariffa) on lipid profile and lipoproteins in patients with type II diabetes.
studies.notes: The study shows significant improvements in lipid profiles in patients consuming sour tea, indicating a benefit.

indications.summary: Human clinical evidence suggests that Hibiscus sabdariffa may improve lipid profiles in patients with metabolic syndrome and type II diabetes, with studies reporting benefits at doses of 100 mg daily and sour tea consumption twice daily for one month. However, the evidence is limited to two studies, both showing positive outcomes without reported harms or adverse effects, indicating a need for further research to confirm these findings.

studies.title: [Therapeutic use Hibiscus sabadariffa extract in the treatment of hypercholesterolemia. A randomized clinical trial].
studies.notes: The study shows that Hibiscus extract significantly reduces triglycerides, indicating a beneficial effect on hypercholesterolemia.

studies.title: Evaluation of the effects of roselle (Hibiscus sabdariffa L.) on oxidative stress and serum levels of lipids, insulin and hs-CRP in adult patients with metabolic syndrome: a double-blind placebo-controlled clinical trial.
studies.notes: The study showed significant reductions in serum triglycerides and systolic blood pressure, indicating a beneficial effect of Hibiscus in patients with metabolic syndrome.

indications.summary: Clinical evidence from two randomized trials indicates that Hibiscus sabdariffa may significantly reduce triglyceride levels in patients, with doses reported as 10 mg and 20 mg of extract over 12 weeks, and 500 mg of calyx powder once daily for 4 weeks. No studies reported harm or lack of benefit, suggesting a consistent positive effect; however, further research is needed to confirm these findings and assess long-term safety.

studies.title: The Effect of Green Tea and Sour Tea (Hibiscus sabdariffa L.) Supplementation on Oxidative Stress and Muscle Damage in Athletes.
studies.notes: The study showed beneficial effects of Hibiscus on oxidative stress but no significant effects on muscle damage, leading to a classification of 'benefit' for oxidative stress.

studies.title: Consumption of Hibiscus sabdariffa L. aqueous extract and its impact on systemic antioxidant potential in healthy subjects.
studies.notes: The study shows that Hibiscus extract enhances antioxidant potential and reduces oxidative stress, indicating a beneficial outcome.

indications.summary: Current evidence from two randomized trials suggests that Hibiscus sabdariffa may have beneficial effects on oxidative stress, with one study reporting positive outcomes at a dose of 450 mg daily for six weeks. However, the overall quality of the evidence is limited, and further research is needed to confirm these findings and establish optimal dosing. No adverse effects were reported in the studies reviewed.

studies.title: Hibiscus extract, vegetable proteases and Commiphora myrrha are useful to prevent symptomatic UTI episode in patients affected by recurrent uncomplicated urinary tract infections.

doses.formulation: combination of Hibiscus extract, vegetable proteases and Commiphora myrrha extract

studies.notes: The study demonstrated a significant reduction in symptomatic UTI episodes and improvement in quality of life, indicating a beneficial effect of the supplement.

studies.title: L-Methionine associated with Hibiscus sabdariffa and Boswellia serrata extracts are not inferior to antibiotic treatment for symptoms relief in patients affected by recurrent uncomplicated urinary tract infections: Focus on antibiotic-sparing approach.
studies.notes: The study demonstrated that the phytotherapic combination improved quality of life and reduced symptoms compared to antibiotics, indicating a benefit.

indications.summary: Human clinical evidence suggests that Hibiscus extract may be beneficial in preventing symptomatic episodes of recurrent uncomplicated urinary tract infections, with two studies reporting positive outcomes related to symptom relief and quality of life. The typical dose reported was 1 tablet of a combination supplement taken twice daily for 7 days. However, the overall evidence is limited and further research is needed to confirm these findings and assess long-term safety and efficacy.

studies.title: Efficacy and Safety of 4% Hibiscus rosa-sinensis Leaf Extract Ointment as an Adjunct Treatment to Compression Stockings on the Closure of Venous Leg Ulcers: A Pilot Study.
studies.notes: The study demonstrated that the hibiscus ointment, when used with compression stockings, significantly contributed to the closure of venous leg ulcers, indicating a beneficial outcome.

indications.summary: There is low-quality evidence suggesting that a 4% hibiscus rosa-sinensis leaf extract ointment, applied twice daily for 12 weeks, may aid in the closure of venous leg ulcers when used alongside compression stockings. However, this finding is based on a single pilot study, and further research is needed to confirm these results and assess long-term safety and efficacy.

contraindications: Caution with caffeine or similar substrates of CYP1A2
Counsel patients against the use of plant beverages with drugs.
adverse effects on HDL-C concentrations in homozygous B1B1 and E4 carriers
co-administration with simvastatin should be discouraged until more clinical data are available

studies.title: Acute Inositol-Stabilized Arginine Silicate Improves Cognitive Outcomes in Healthy Adults.
studies.notes: The study demonstrated significant improvements in cognitive outcomes, indicating a beneficial effect of the supplement.

studies.title: Effects of Inositol-Enhanced Bonded Arginine Silicate Ingestion on Cognitive and Executive Function in Gamers.
studies.notes: The study shows significant improvements in cognitive tasks after ingestion of ASI + I, indicating a benefit.

indications.summary: Two randomized trials have reported beneficial effects of inositol, specifically in the form of inositol-stabilized arginine silicate, on cognitive outcomes in healthy adults following single doses of 1.5 g and 1.6 g. However, the evidence is limited to acute effects and does not provide information on long-term use or potential adverse effects.

studies.title: Time-to-conception and clinical pregnancy rate with a myo-inositol, probiotics, and micronutrient supplement: secondary outcomes of the NiPPeR randomized trial.
studies.notes: The intervention showed mixed results; it improved time-to-conception in overweight women but lengthened it in women with obesity, indicating a need for further studies.

indications.summary: The evidence regarding the use of inositol for difficulty conceiving is low and mixed. A randomized trial indicated that while myo-inositol may improve time-to-conception in overweight women, it may have the opposite effect in women with obesity, suggesting variability in response and the need for further research. No consistent dose ranges were reported, and no adverse effects were noted in the studies reviewed.

studies.title: Clinical effectiveness of α-lipoic acid, myo-inositol and propolis supplementation on metabolic profiles and liver function in obese patients with NAFLD: A randomized controlled clinical trial.
studies.notes: The study shows improvements in metabolic parameters and liver function, indicating a benefit from myo-inositol supplementation.

indications.summary: One randomized controlled trial reported that myo-inositol supplementation for 8 weeks improved metabolic parameters and liver function in obese patients with non-alcoholic fatty liver disease (NAFLD), indicating a potential benefit. However, the evidence is limited to a single study, and further research is needed to confirm these findings and assess long-term effects and safety.

studies.title: The effect of myo-inositol supplementation on the prevention of gestational diabetes in overweight pregnant women: a randomized, double-blind, controlled trial.
studies.notes: The study shows a significant reduction in the incidence of gestational diabetes in the myo-inositol group, indicating a beneficial effect.

indications.summary: One randomized, double-blind, controlled trial found that myo-inositol supplementation at a dose of 2000 mg daily for 10 weeks significantly reduced the incidence of gestational diabetes in overweight pregnant women. No studies reported mixed outcomes or harm, suggesting a potential benefit, though further research may be needed to confirm these findings and assess long-term effects.

studies.title: Effectiveness of a Food Supplement Based on Glucomannan, D-Chiro-Inositol, Cinnamomum zeylanicum Blume and Inulin in Patients with Metabolic Syndrome.
studies.notes: The study demonstrated significant improvements in various health parameters, indicating a beneficial effect of the supplement.

indications.summary: One randomized trial reported a beneficial effect of inositol, specifically in combination with other supplements, on health parameters in patients with metabolic syndrome, which may include those with high blood sugar. The study used a daily dose of 4 g for four months. Overall, the evidence is limited to a single study, and further research is needed to confirm these findings and assess long-term safety and efficacy.

studies.title: Effect of dietary myo-inositol supplementation on the insulin resistance and the prevention of gestational diabetes mellitus: an open-label, randomized controlled trial.
studies.notes: The study shows that MI supplementation significantly reduces the incidence of GDM and improves insulin sensitivity, indicating a beneficial effect.

indications.summary: One randomized controlled trial indicates that myo-inositol supplementation (4000 mg daily) may reduce the incidence of gestational diabetes mellitus (GDM) and improve insulin sensitivity in pregnant women. However, the evidence is limited to a single study, and further research is needed to confirm these findings and assess long-term safety and efficacy.

studies.title: Myo-inositol nutritional supplement for prevention of gestational diabetes (EMmY): a randomised, placebo-controlled, double-blind pilot trial with nested qualitative study.
studies.notes: The study shows a signal for efficacy in reducing insulin resistance with myo-inositol, indicating a potential benefit.

indications.summary: One randomized, placebo-controlled trial indicates that myo-inositol supplementation (2 g twice daily until delivery) may reduce insulin resistance in pregnant women, suggesting a potential benefit for managing high blood sugar during pregnancy. However, the evidence is limited to a single study, and further research is needed to confirm these findings and assess long-term safety and efficacy.

studies.title: A multicenter clinical study with myo-inositol and alpha-lactalbumin in Mexican and Italian PCOS patients.
