studies.title: Efficacy and tolerability of an oral supplement containing amino acids, iron, selenium, and marine hydrolyzed collagen in subjects with hair loss (androgenetic alopecia, AGA or FAGA or telogen effluvium). A prospective, randomized, 3-month, controlled, assessor-blinded study.

studies.title: Selenium Supplementation and Gestational Diabetes: A Randomised Controlled Trial.
studies.notes: Selenium supplementation showed a beneficial impact on blood glucose levels in pregnant women with GDM compared to diet alone.

indications.summary: One randomized controlled trial reported that selenium supplementation (200 µg daily for 4 weeks) may benefit blood glucose levels in pregnant women with gestational diabetes mellitus (GDM) compared to diet alone. studies.title: Selenium and coenzyme Q10 improve the systemic redox status while reducing cardiovascular mortality in elderly population-based individuals.
studies.notes: The study shows that selenium supplementation improved serum R-SH levels and was associated with reduced cardiovascular mortality, indicating a beneficial outcome.

indications.summary: One randomized trial indicates that selenium supplementation (200 μg daily for 48 months) may improve systemic redox status and is associated with reduced cardiovascular mortality in an elderly population. No studies reported mixed results or harm, but further research is needed to confirm these findings and establish long-term safety and efficacy.

studies.title: Adding L-Carnitine and Selenium to Methimazole in Graves' Disease: A Prospective Randomized Trial on Thyroid Markers and Quality of Life.
studies.notes: The study shows clinical benefits of adding L-Carnitine and Selenium to Methimazole in Graves' Disease, including improved TRAb negativity and lower MMI requirements.

indications.summary: One randomized trial suggests that adding selenium to methimazole may provide clinical benefits in patients with Graves' disease, including improved thyroid markers and reduced medication requirements. studies.title: Investigation of the Effect of Oral Selenium on the Reduction of Clinical Symptoms and Joint Pain in Patients With Rheumatoid Arthritis in the Iranian Population.
studies.notes: The study shows a significant reduction in clinical symptoms and joint pain in the selenium group compared to placebo.

indications.summary: One randomized trial reported a significant reduction in joint pain and clinical symptoms in patients with rheumatoid arthritis after 12 weeks of oral selenium supplementation at a dose of 200 μg twice daily, compared to placebo. However, the overall evidence is limited, with only one study available, and further research is needed to confirm these findings and assess long-term effects.

studies.title: Effects of Selenium Supplementation on the Indices of Disease Activity, Inflammation and Oxidative Stress in Patients with Rheumatoid Arthritis: a Randomized Clinical Trial.
studies.notes: The selenium group showed some clinically relevant improvements in biomarkers, but between-group comparisons were not statistically significant.

indications.summary: The evidence regarding selenium supplementation for rheumatoid arthritis is mixed and unclear, based on one randomized clinical trial that reported some improvements in biomarkers without statistically significant between-group differences. The study utilized a dose of 200 μg daily for 12 weeks. Overall, there is insufficient evidence to draw definitive conclusions about the efficacy of selenium for this indication.

studies.title: Maintenance effect of a once-weekly regimen of a Selenium Disulfide-based shampoo in moderate-to-severe scalp seborrheic dermatitis after initial treatment with topical corticosteroid/salicylic acid.
studies.notes: The study shows a significant reduction in relapse rates and improvement in pruritus, indicating a beneficial effect of the Selenium disulfide shampoo.

However, the evidence is limited to a single study, and further research is needed to confirm these findings and assess long-term safety and efficacy.

studies.title: Efficacy and Safety of Dietary Undenatured Type II Collagen on Joint and Motor Function in Healthy Volunteers: A Randomized, Double-Blind, Placebo-Controlled, Parallel-Group Study.
studies.notes: The study demonstrated significant improvements in joint flexibility, mobility, and pain reduction, indicating a beneficial effect of the supplement.

studies.title: [Efficacy and safety of undenatured type II collagen in patients with knee osteoarthritis: a multicenter, prospective, double-blind, placebo-controlled, randomized trial].

doses.formulation: Artneo complex containing undenatured chicken collagen type II

studies.notes: The study demonstrated a positive effect of the supplement on knee osteoarthritis, showing benefits in pain reduction, stiffness, and quality of life.
studies.evidence_tier_rationale: Multicenter, double-blind, placebo-controlled RCT (n=212) in knee osteoarthritis showed significant reductions in pain (WOMAC/KOOS/VAS) and improved function/QoL over 180 days. Joint pain was a primary clinical outcome. Attribution specifically to undenatured type II collagen is somewhat tempered because the tested product was a combination formula containing UC-II.

indications.summary: Human clinical evidence suggests that undenatured type II collagen may provide benefits for knee pain, particularly in the context of osteoarthritis, with two randomized, double-blind, placebo-controlled trials reporting positive outcomes related to pain reduction and joint function. Doses reported include 3.2 mg daily and one capsule daily for 180 days, but the overall evidence remains limited and further studies are needed to confirm these findings and assess long-term safety. No adverse effects were reported in the studies reviewed.

studies.title: Efficacy and tolerability of an undenatured type II collagen supplement in modulating knee osteoarthritis symptoms: a multicenter randomized, double-blind, placebo-controlled study.
studies.notes: The study demonstrated significant improvements in knee OA symptoms with UC-II compared to placebo and GC, indicating a beneficial effect.
studies.evidence_tier_rationale: Multicenter, randomized, double-blind, placebo-controlled RCT (n=191) in knee osteoarthritis with 180-day follow-up. Primary outcome (WOMAC total and pain subscale) directly reflects joint pain and showed significant benefit vs placebo (and vs glucosamine/chondroitin). Adequate size, rigorous methods, and clinically meaningful endpoints support strong human evidence.

studies.title: Safety and efficacy of undenatured type II collagen in the treatment of osteoarthritis of the knee: a clinical trial.
studies.notes: The study demonstrated significant efficacy of UC-II in reducing symptoms of osteoarthritis compared to glucosamine and chondroitin, indicating a clear benefit.
studies.evidence_tier_rationale: Single human randomized controlled trial in osteoarthritis patients with clinically relevant primary outcomes (WOMAC, VAS, Lequesne) showed benefit of undenatured type II collagen over glucosamine/chondroitin over 90 days. However, the study appears small, with limited duration and unclear blinding/placebo control, so evidence is moderate rather than strong.

studies.title: [Comparative efficacy of a combination of undenatured type II collagen, Boswellic acids, methylsulfonylmethane, vitamins C and D3 and a combination of chondroitin sulfate and glucosamine hydrochloride in the treatment of primary osteoarthritis of the knee joint].
studies.notes: The study showed improvement in pain and quality of life with no significant adverse reactions, indicating a benefit from the supplement.
source_conditions: primary osteoarthritis of the knee joint
studies.evidence_tier_rationale: This RCT evaluated a multi-ingredient product (undenatured type II collagen plus Boswellic acids, MSM, vitamins C and D3) versus glucosamine/chondroitin in knee osteoarthritis. Although pain and quality-of-life benefits were observed, the study does not test undenatured type II collagen as a standalone supplement, so effects cannot be attributed specifically to it. Therefore, it does not constitute direct evidence for undenatured type II collagen alone for joint pain.

studies.title: [Experience with the use of undenatured type II collagen in patients with stage III knee osteoarthritis: a multicenter, prospective, double-blind, placebo-controlled, randomized trial].
studies.notes: The study demonstrated significant superiority of the supplement over placebo in improving clinical manifestations of osteoarthritis, indicating a clear benefit.
studies.evidence_tier_rationale: Multicenter, double-blind, placebo-controlled RCT with clinically relevant primary outcomes (pain VAS, WOMAC, KOOS) showed significant benefit. However, the analyzed cohort for stage III knee OA was small (n=50; 28 vs 22), and the indication here is broader 'joint pain,' limiting generalizability. Strong methods but modest sample size and single study keep it below Tier 1.

original_labels: primary osteoarthritis of the knee joint
indications.summary: Clinical evidence from four randomized, double-blind, placebo-controlled trials indicates that undenatured type II collagen may improve symptoms of knee osteoarthritis, with doses ranging from 40 mg daily to 1 capsule per day for durations of 90 to 180 days. All studies reported benefits without significant adverse effects; however, the overall quality of the evidence is considered tier 3, suggesting further research may be needed to confirm these findings.

studies.title: Evaluation and comparison of vitamin A supplementation with standard therapies in the treatment of patients with COVID-19.
studies.notes: Vitamin A supplementation showed significant improvements in clinical symptoms compared to standard treatment.

indications.summary: Current evidence on vitamin A supplementation for COVID-19 symptoms is limited, with one study reporting significant improvements in clinical symptoms when administered at a dose of 25,000 IU daily for 10 days compared to standard treatment. Overall, the evidence is low-quality and further research is needed to confirm these findings and assess safety and efficacy.

contraindications: Excessive Vitamin A supplementation may increase the incidence of ARTI in well-nourished children.
High dietary intake of total vitamin A increases hip fracture risk
Two infants developed definite necrotizing enterocolitis in the vitamin A group.
increased risk of vomiting within the first 48 hours of VAS
slightly increased bulging fontanelle of neonates and infants
vitamin E supplementation should be avoided

studies.title: A Randomized Control Trial of Dexketoprofen/Vitamin B (Thiamine, Pyridoxine and Cyanocobalamin) Fixed-Dose Combination in Post-Traumatic Grade I-II Cervical Sprains.
studies.notes: The study demonstrated a statistically significant reduction in pain intensity and a better safety profile with the fixed-dose combination compared to monotherapy.
studies.evidence_tier_rationale: Although this was a well-designed randomized, double-blind trial with a clinically relevant primary outcome (pain reduction), the intervention combined dexketoprofen with thiamine, pyridoxine, and cyanocobalamin and compared it to dexketoprofen alone. The benefit cannot be attributed to thiamine specifically, making the evidence indirect for vitamin B1 alone in musculoskeletal pain.

indications.summary: One randomized controlled trial reported a benefit of a fixed-dose combination of dexketoprofen and 100 mg of vitamin B1 (thiamine) administered every 8 hours for 7 days in reducing pain intensity in patients with post-traumatic cervical sprains. No studies reported mixed outcomes or harm, but the overall evidence is limited to a single trial, indicating a need for further research to confirm these findings.

studies.title: B-vitamins, related vitamers, and metabolites in patients with quiescent inflammatory bowel disease and chronic fatigue treated with high dose oral thiamine.
studies.notes: The study reports improvement in clinical fatigue scores, indicating a beneficial effect of thiamine.
studies.evidence_tier_rationale: Randomized clinical trial in quiescent IBD patients with chronic fatigue reported improvement in clinical fatigue after 4 weeks of high-dose oral thiamine. Fatigue appears to be a primary clinical outcome. However, details on sample size and blinding are unclear, and the study population is a specific subgroup, suggesting a likely smaller trial with limited generalizability.

studies.title: Randomised clinical trial: high-dose oral thiamine versus placebo for chronic fatigue in patients with quiescent inflammatory bowel disease.
studies.notes: The study showed a significant beneficial effect of high-dose thiamine on chronic fatigue, indicating a positive outcome.
studies.evidence_tier_rationale: Randomized, double-blind, placebo-controlled crossover RCT with fatigue as the primary outcome showed significant benefit of high-dose thiamine in quiescent IBD patients. However, the sample size is small (n=40), duration short (4 weeks per period), and the population is disease-specific (IBD), limiting generalizability to broader fatigue. Methods are strong but size/scope keep it from Tier 1.

indications.summary: Two randomized clinical trials have reported a beneficial effect of high-dose oral thiamine (600-1800 mg daily) on chronic fatigue in patients with quiescent inflammatory bowel disease, with improvements in clinical fatigue scores noted. There are no reports of harm or no benefit in the studies reviewed, but the evidence is limited to a specific patient population and further research is needed to confirm these findings in broader contexts.

studies.title: The Utility of Oral Vitamin B1 and Mecobalamin to Improve Corneal Nerves in Dry Eye Disease: An In Vivo Confocal Microscopy Study.
studies.notes: The study shows significant improvements in various symptoms and corneal nerve parameters, indicating a beneficial effect of Vitamin B1.
studies.evidence_tier_rationale: Double-blind randomized controlled trial with a large sample showed clinically relevant improvements (OSDI, symptoms, corneal staining) in dry eye disease. However, Vitamin B1 was administered in combination with mecobalamin, so the effect cannot be attributed to thiamine alone; dose details are also not specified here. Strong design but indirect for B1 specifically, warranting a downgrade from Tier 1.

indications.summary: One study suggests that oral Vitamin B1 may improve symptoms and corneal nerve parameters in individuals with dry eye disease, indicating a potential benefit. However, the evidence is limited to a single study, and further research is needed to confirm these findings and establish consistent dosing and safety profiles.

studies.title: The effect of vitamin B1 on bleeding and spotting in women using an intrauterine device: a double-blind randomised controlled trial.
studies.notes: The intervention group showed significant reduction in menstrual bleeding and spotting, indicating a beneficial effect of vitamin B1.

indications.summary: One randomized controlled trial reported a beneficial effect of vitamin B1 (thiamine) at a dose of 100 mg daily for three months in reducing menstrual bleeding and spotting in women using an intrauterine device. However, the overall evidence is limited, with only one study available, and further research is needed to confirm these findings and assess long-term safety and efficacy.

studies.title: Effect of Combined Vitamin C and Thiamine Therapy on Myocardial and Inflammatory Markers in Cardiac Surgery: A Randomized Controlled Clinical Trial.
studies.notes: The study shows that combined therapy significantly reduced markers of myocardial injury and inflammatory responses, indicating a beneficial effect.

indications.summary: There is limited evidence suggesting that vitamin B1 (thiamine) may have a beneficial effect on inflammatory markers when used in combination with vitamin C in a perioperative setting, as demonstrated in one randomized controlled trial. The study reported a dose of 100 mg administered at four time points over 24 hours postoperatively. Overall, the evidence is sparse and further research is needed to confirm these findings and assess the consistency of effects across different populations and contexts.

studies.title: The effects of fish oil capsules and vitamin B1 tablets on duration and severity of dysmenorrhea in students of high school in Urmia-Iran.
studies.notes: The study shows significant reduction in pain severity and duration with Vitamin B1, indicating a beneficial effect.
studies.evidence_tier_rationale: Double-blind, randomized, placebo-controlled trial with four arms (n≈60 per arm) in women with primary dysmenorrhea showed significant reductions in pain severity and duration with vitamin B1 (100 mg/day for 2 months) versus placebo. Outcomes were clinically relevant and primary. While methods look solid and sample size is adequate, confidence is tempered slightly by reliance on a single study and limited methodological detail in the abstract.

indications.summary: One randomized trial reported that Vitamin B1 (thiamine) at a dose of 100 mg daily for two months significantly reduced the severity and duration of dysmenorrhea in high school students. However, the overall evidence is limited, with only one study available, and further research is needed to confirm these findings and assess long-term safety and efficacy.

studies.title: Evaluation of the Efficacy of the Addition of a Combination of Pyrimidine Nucleotides and Vitamin B1 and B12 to Standard Treatment in the Management of Painful Radiculopathy and in the Quality of Life of Patients.
studies.notes: The study showed mixed results; while there was functional improvement, pain reduction was not statistically significant.
studies.evidence_tier_rationale: Single RCT in painful radiculopathy tested a combination (pyrimidine nucleotides + vitamins B1 and B12) added to standard care, not thiamine alone. Results were mixed: functional improvement but no statistically significant pain reduction. Because the intervention is multi-ingredient and effects cannot be attributed specifically to thiamine, the evidence for thiamine for sciatic pain is indirect and low in strength.

indications.summary: The evidence for Vitamin B1 (Thiamine) in managing pain is limited and of low quality. One study reported mixed results, indicating functional improvement but no statistically significant reduction in pain. There are no consistent dose ranges or reported adverse effects in the available literature.

studies.title: Effect of vitamin B1 supplementation on bone turnover markers in adults: an exploratory single-arm pilot study.
studies.notes: The study showed a significant reduction in a bone resorption marker, indicating a potential benefit for bone health.
studies.evidence_tier_rationale: Single-arm, pre–post pilot study in older adults with 1-month thiamine supplementation measured surrogate bone turnover markers (TRACP 5b decreased) without a control group and without direct bone density (BMD) outcomes. Exploratory design and short duration provide weak/preliminary human evidence relevant to bone health but not direct proof of improved bone density.

indications.summary: The evidence for vitamin B1 (thiamine) supplementation in improving bone health is limited, with only one exploratory pilot study reporting a benefit through a significant reduction in a bone resorption marker at a dose of 28 mg daily for one month. Overall, the evidence is low quality and further research is needed to establish any definitive effects on bone health.

studies.title: The effects of vitamin B1 on ameliorating the premenstrual syndrome symptoms.
studies.notes: Vitamin B1 significantly reduced mental and physical symptoms of PMS, indicating a beneficial effect.
studies.evidence_tier_rationale: Double-blind, placebo-controlled RCT in women with PMS (n≈80) with PMS symptom severity as the primary outcome showed significant benefit from thiamine. Methods are appropriate and outcomes are directly relevant to the indication, though the single-center student population and modest sample size slightly limit generalizability.

indications.summary: One randomized trial suggests that Vitamin B1 (Thiamine) may significantly reduce mental and physical symptoms of premenstrual syndrome (PMS), indicating a potential benefit. However, the evidence is limited to a single study, and further research is needed to confirm these findings and assess the consistency of the results. No adverse effects were reported in the study.

studies.title: Impact of Vitamin B1 and Vitamin B2 Supplementation on Anxiety, Stress, and Sleep Quality: A Randomized, Double-Blind, Placebo-Controlled Trial.
studies.notes: Vitamin B1 supplementation showed benefits in reducing stress and improving sleep quality, but no significant effect on anxiety.
studies.evidence_tier_rationale: Randomized, double-blind, placebo-controlled human trial with reported benefit on stress for thiamine, but stress appears likely a secondary outcome (study categorized under sleep), sample size not provided, short duration (4 weeks), and mixed overall results (no anxiety effect). This supports moderate human evidence rather than strong.

indications.summary: The evidence for Vitamin B1 (Thiamine) supplementation in reducing stress is limited and mixed. One randomized, double-blind, placebo-controlled trial reported some benefits in stress reduction and sleep quality at a dose of 100 mg for 4 weeks, but no significant effect on anxiety was observed. Overall, the findings do not support a clear benefit for this indication.

contraindications: higher mortality in lactate > 5 mmol/L group
mild and transient adverse events recorded
potential harm in unplanned subgroup analysis

studies.title: Transcutaneous electrical nerve stimulation in combination with cobalamin injection for postherpetic neuralgia: a single-center randomized controlled trial.
studies.notes: The study shows significant analgesic effects and improvements in activities of daily living and quality of life with the use of cobalamin injections.
studies.evidence_tier_rationale: Single-center randomized controlled trial (n=90) in postherpetic neuralgia showed clinically meaningful pain, ADL, and QoL improvements with local cobalamin injections (with TENS) versus comparator arms. However, it used combination therapy (all groups received TENS), likely limited/unclear blinding, and short duration, so evidence is moderate rather than strong.

indications.summary: One randomized controlled trial reported significant analgesic effects and improvements in activities of daily living and quality of life with vitamin B12 (cobalamin) injections for chronic pain from postherpetic neuralgia over an 8-week period. However, the overall evidence is limited, with only one study demonstrating benefit and no reports of harm or mixed outcomes.

studies.title: Effects of Folic Acid and Vitamin B12 Supplementation on Cognitive Impairment and Inflammation in Patients with Alzheimer's Disease: A Randomized, Single-Blinded, Placebo-Controlled Trial.
studies.notes: The study found beneficial effects on cognitive performance in Alzheimer's patients receiving Vitamin B12 supplementation.
studies.evidence_tier_rationale: Although this is a randomized, single-blind, placebo-controlled trial with clinically relevant cognitive outcomes in Alzheimer’s patients, the intervention was a combination of folic acid plus vitamin B12. The co-supplementation prevents attributing benefits specifically to vitamin B12, making the evidence indirect for B12 alone despite positive results.

studies.title: Cobalamin supplementation improves cognitive and cerebral function in older, cobalamin-deficient persons.

doses.duration: 1 month placebo followed by 5 months treatment

studies.notes: The study shows improvements in cognitive and cerebral function after supplementation, indicating a beneficial effect.
studies.evidence_tier_rationale: The trial tested hydroxocobalamin in cobalamin-deficient, cognitively normal older adults and assessed cognitive tests and qEEG, not Alzheimer’s disease patients or AD-related outcomes (diagnosis, progression, or AD-specific scales). Thus it does not directly evaluate vitamin B12 for Alzheimer’s disease treatment or prevention. Findings are indirect and cannot be extrapolated to AD.

studies.title: Improvement of cognitive functions after cobalamin/folate supplementation in elderly patients with dementia and elevated plasma homocysteine.
studies.notes: Patients with mild-moderate dementia showed improvement in cognitive function after supplementation, indicating a beneficial outcome.
studies.evidence_tier_rationale: Small, uncontrolled pre–post clinical study (n≈33) using combined cobalamin/folate supplementation with cognitive test outcomes. No randomization or control group; effects reported only in a subgroup (mild–moderate dementia with elevated homocysteine). Population was ‘dementia’ rather than specifically Alzheimer’s disease, and the combination therapy limits attribution to B12 alone. Thus, preliminary human evidence with indirect relevance to AD.

studies.title: Vitamin B12 supplementation improves cognitive function in middle aged and elderly patients with cognitive impairment.
studies.notes: The study shows significant improvement in cognitive function with Vitamin B12 supplementation, indicating a beneficial outcome.
studies.evidence_tier_rationale: The study is a randomized controlled trial but enrolled participants with general cognitive impairment rather than specifically diagnosed Alzheimer’s disease. Outcomes were global cognitive tests (MMSE, MoCA) showing improvement, which is clinically relevant but indirect for Alzheimer’s as the indication. Thus, it provides very low/indirect human evidence for Vitamin B12 in Alzheimer’s disease.

indications.summary: The evidence from four randomized trials indicates that Vitamin B12 supplementation may improve cognitive function in individuals with cognitive impairment or dementia. Doses varied, including daily oral doses of 50 μg and intramuscular injections of hydroxocobalamin and other forms, but no adverse effects were reported. Overall, the findings suggest a beneficial effect, though the quality and consistency of the evidence warrant cautious interpretation.

studies.title: Thiamine, cobalamin, locally injected alone or combination for herpetic itching: a single-center randomized controlled trial.
studies.notes: Cobalamin showed significant pain relief, indicating a beneficial outcome for the treatment of herpetic itching.
studies.evidence_tier_rationale: Single-center randomized controlled trial (~20 per arm) tested locally injected cobalamin in patients with herpetic itching and measured pruritus as a primary clinical outcome. While the RCT design provides moderate-quality human evidence, cobalamin alone did not significantly reduce itch (benefit was on pain), and sample size/blinding details limit robustness. Relevant to the indication but does not show efficacy for itching.

indications.summary: One randomized controlled trial (PMID 23887347) reported that locally injected vitamin B12 (cobalamin) provided significant pain relief for herpetic itching over a 4-week period. No studies reported mixed outcomes or harm, but the evidence is limited to a single trial, indicating a need for further research to confirm these findings.

studies.title: Daily Folic Acid and/or Vitamin B12 Supplementation Between 6 and 30 Months of Age and Cardiometabolic Risk Markers After 6-7 Years: A Follow-Up of a Randomized Controlled Trial.
studies.notes: The study shows a decrease in plasma tHcy concentrations, indicating a beneficial effect of vitamin B12 supplementation.
studies.evidence_tier_rationale: Large, double-blind randomized factorial trial with homocysteine as a measured outcome shows benefit, but the significant reduction in tHcy was observed with combined vitamin B12 plus folic acid rather than clearly with B12 alone. The intervention occurred in early childhood with outcomes measured 6 years later, which limits direct applicability to treating high homocysteine and to B12 monotherapy.

studies.title: Cobalamin dose regimen for maximum homocysteine reduction in end-stage renal disease.
studies.notes: The study shows that intravenous cyanocobalamin significantly reduces plasma homocysteine levels, indicating a beneficial effect in patients with end-stage renal disease.
studies.evidence_tier_rationale: Randomized controlled trial in hemodialysis patients showed that more frequent intravenous cyanocobalamin (every 7–14 days) significantly reduced plasma homocysteine versus monthly dosing. The outcome (tHcy) directly matches the indication (high homocysteine) and is objective. However, the study appears relatively small, likely unblinded, limited to CKD/ESRD patients, and compares dosing regimens rather than supplement vs placebo/no treatment, which constrains generalizability.

studies.title: Cobalamin reduces homocysteine in older adults on folic acid-fortified diet: a pilot, double-blind, randomized, placebo-controlled trial.
studies.notes: The study shows a benefit in reducing homocysteine levels, which is clinically relevant for older adults.
studies.evidence_tier_rationale: Double-blind, randomized, placebo-controlled trial in older adults showing B12 lowers homocysteine, which is the primary outcome for the indication. However, it is a pilot (small) study, limiting strength despite good methodology.

indications.summary: Evidence from three randomized controlled trials indicates that vitamin B12 supplementation is associated with a reduction in plasma homocysteine levels. Doses reported include 1.8 μg daily and 1 mg intravenously every 7 or 14 days. Overall, the findings suggest a beneficial effect of vitamin B12 on high homocysteine levels, although the studies vary in population and dosing regimens.

studies.title: Artificial intelligence analysis to explore synchronize exercise, cobalamin, and magnesium as new actors to therapeutic of migraine symptoms: a randomized, placebo-controlled trial.
studies.notes: The study shows a significant reduction in migraine symptoms with the combination of vitamin B12 and magnesium, indicating a beneficial outcome.
studies.evidence_tier_rationale: Although this was a randomized, placebo-controlled trial with clinical migraine outcomes (frequency, intensity, duration, MIDAS), the supplementation arm used a combination of vitamin B12 plus magnesium and the main significant improvements occurred only in the HIIT + supplementation group. The study does not demonstrate a clear benefit for supplementation alone, nor isolate the effect of vitamin B12 independent of magnesium and exercise. Small sample size (~60) and short duration (2 months) further limit conclusions for B12 specifically.

indications.summary: One randomized, placebo-controlled trial reported a significant reduction in migraine symptoms with the combination of vitamin B12 and magnesium over a 2-month supplementation period. However, the evidence is limited to a single study, and further research is needed to confirm these findings and assess the consistency of the results. No adverse effects were reported in the study.

studies.title: [Randomized Clinical Trial for Treatment of Patients with Acute Ischemic Cerebral Stroke by Acupoint Injection of Cobalamin or Gangliosides].
studies.notes: The study shows significant improvement in neurological function and daily living ability in stroke patients treated with Cobalamin.
studies.evidence_tier_rationale: Randomized controlled trial in acute ischemic stroke with clinically relevant outcomes (neurological function and ADLs) showing benefit from cobalamin injections. However, sample size is small (~30 per arm), blinding and allocation concealment are unclear, outcomes include subjective 'effective rate,' and the acupoint injection method may introduce placebo or procedural effects and limits generalizability to standard B12 use. Thus, moderate but not strong human evidence.

indications.summary: One randomized clinical trial reported a benefit of vitamin B12 (cobalamin) in improving neurological function and daily living ability in patients with acute ischemic stroke, using a dose of 1 mL injected once daily for two weeks. However, the evidence is limited to a single study, and further research is needed to confirm these findings and assess long-term effects and safety.

studies.title: The effects of vitamin B12 supplementation on metabolic profile of patients with non-alcoholic fatty liver disease: a randomized controlled trial.
studies.notes: Vitamin B12 supplementation showed a significant decrease in homocysteine but mixed results for other metabolic parameters compared to placebo.
studies.evidence_tier_rationale: Double-blind randomized controlled trial in NAFLD patients (n=40) directly measured liver-related outcomes (steatosis grade, liver enzymes) but found no significant between-group improvements versus placebo; only homocysteine decreased significantly. Study quality is moderate (RCT, blinded) but small sample and short duration with mixed/negative clinical results for the indication.

indications.summary: The evidence regarding vitamin B12 supplementation for non-alcoholic fatty liver disease is limited and mixed, with one randomized controlled trial reporting a significant decrease in homocysteine but unclear effects on other metabolic parameters. The study utilized a dose of 1000 µg once daily for 12 weeks. Overall, the quality of evidence is low, and no clear benefits have been established.

studies.title: Coronary endothelial function in hyperhomocysteinemia: improvement after treatment with folic acid and cobalamin in patients with coronary artery disease.
studies.notes: The study shows a significant improvement in coronary endothelial function after treatment with cobalamin, indicating a beneficial outcome.
studies.evidence_tier_rationale: Randomized, placebo-controlled trial in hyperhomocysteinemic CAD patients showed improved coronary endothelial function after six months, but the intervention combined folic acid (5 mg) with cobalamin (400 mcg), so the effect cannot be attributed to B12 alone. The primary outcome was a surrogate physiological measure (acetylcholine-stimulated coronary blood flow) and the sample size was very small (n=15), making the evidence preliminary despite the RCT design.

indications.summary: One randomized trial indicates that vitamin B12 (cobalamin) supplementation at a dose of 400 micrograms daily for six months may improve coronary endothelial function in patients with coronary artery disease. However, the overall evidence is limited, with only one study showing a benefit and no reports of harm or mixed outcomes.

studies.title: Efficacy and safety of the combined metabolic medication, containing inosine, nicotinamide, riboflavin and succinic acid, for the treatment of diabetic neuropathy: a multicenter randomized, double-blind, placebo-controlled parallel group clinical trial (CYLINDER).
studies.notes: The study shows a significant reduction in diabetic neuropathy symptoms, indicating a beneficial effect of the treatment including riboflavin.
studies.evidence_tier_rationale: Although this is a well-designed, double-blind, placebo-controlled RCT in patients with diabetic neuropathy showing symptomatic benefit, the intervention was a multi-ingredient combination (inosine, nicotinamide, riboflavin, succinic acid). Because riboflavin was not isolated and its specific dose/effect cannot be disentangled, the evidence for riboflavin alone in neuropathic pain is indirect.

indications.summary: One randomized, double-blind, placebo-controlled trial reported a significant reduction in symptoms of diabetic neuropathy with a treatment regimen that included riboflavin, administered intravenously for 10 days followed by oral dosing for 75 days. Overall, the evidence is limited to this single study, and further research is needed to confirm these findings and assess long-term safety and efficacy.

studies.title: Blood pressure in treated hypertensive individuals with the MTHFR 677TT genotype is responsive to intervention with riboflavin: findings of a targeted randomized trial.
studies.notes: Riboflavin supplementation significantly lowered systolic blood pressure in the targeted population, indicating a beneficial effect.
studies.evidence_tier_rationale: Randomized, placebo-controlled human trial with systolic blood pressure as a primary clinical outcome showed a significant reduction with riboflavin in hypertensive individuals carrying the MTHFR 677TT genotype. Sample size was modest (~91), diastolic BP was not significantly affected, and findings are genotype-specific, limiting generalizability. Thus, moderate-quality human evidence.

studies.title: Riboflavin offers a targeted strategy for managing hypertension in patients with the MTHFR 677TT genotype: a 4-y follow-up.
studies.notes: Riboflavin supplementation resulted in a significant decrease in both systolic and diastolic blood pressure, indicating a beneficial effect.
studies.evidence_tier_rationale: Placebo-controlled randomized/crossover trial in humans with hypertension risk (MTHFR 677TT genotype) showed significant reductions in systolic and diastolic blood pressure with riboflavin. Primary, clinically meaningful outcome. However, the sample size was small (n≈31 in the target genotype), design complexity across two time points, and applicability is limited to a specific genetic subgroup rather than the general hypertensive population.

indications.summary: Vitamin B2 (riboflavin) supplementation at a dose of 1.6 mg daily for 16 weeks has shown beneficial effects on blood pressure in individuals with the MTHFR 677TT genotype, as evidenced by three randomized trials reporting significant reductions in both systolic and diastolic blood pressure. However, the evidence is specific to this genetic subgroup, and no adverse effects were reported in the studies reviewed.

studies.title: Riboflavin Supplementation in Patients with Crohn's Disease [the RISE-UP study].
studies.notes: Riboflavin supplementation resulted in decreased inflammatory markers and clinical symptoms, indicating a beneficial effect.
studies.evidence_tier_rationale: Prospective pre–post clinical intervention without randomization or control group (open-label) in Crohn’s disease patients (n=70) showing reductions in inflammatory markers and HBI after 3 weeks of riboflavin 100 mg/day. Clinically relevant outcomes were assessed, but lack of blinding/control and short duration limit the strength to preliminary human evidence.

indications.summary: Current evidence on the use of vitamin B2 (riboflavin) for inflammation in Crohn's disease is limited, with only one study reporting a benefit. In this study, a daily dose of 100 mg for three weeks was associated with decreased inflammatory markers and clinical symptoms. Overall, the evidence is low-quality and further research is needed to confirm these findings.

studies.title: Improvement of migraine symptoms with a proprietary supplement containing riboflavin, magnesium and Q10: a randomized, placebo-controlled, double-blind, multicenter trial.

doses.formulation: proprietary supplement containing riboflavin, magnesium and Q10

studies.notes: The study showed significant reduction in migraine pain and burden of disease, indicating a beneficial effect of the supplement.
studies.evidence_tier_rationale: This is a well-designed RCT with clinically relevant outcomes for migraine, but it tested a multi-ingredient product (riboflavin + magnesium + CoQ10), not riboflavin alone. Effects cannot be attributed specifically to riboflavin. Additionally, the primary measure of migraine days did not reach statistical significance, with benefits seen mainly in secondary outcomes. Thus, evidence for riboflavin itself is indirect/very low based on this study.

indications.summary: Clinical evidence suggests that riboflavin may be beneficial for migraine treatment, with two randomized trials reporting positive outcomes. One study indicated effectiveness at a dose of 400 mg daily for four months, while the other involved a proprietary supplement containing riboflavin, magnesium, and Coenzyme Q10 over three months. However, the overall evidence remains limited and further research is needed to confirm these findings and assess long-term safety.

studies.title: Impact of Vitamin B1 and Vitamin B2 Supplementation on Anxiety, Stress, and Sleep Quality: A Randomized, Double-Blind, Placebo-Controlled Trial.
studies.notes: Vitamin B2 supplementation showed benefits in reducing stress and improving sleep quality, but no significant effect on anxiety.
studies.evidence_tier_rationale: A randomized, double-blind, placebo-controlled human trial assessed riboflavin (100 mg, 4 weeks) with stress as a measured clinical outcome and reported benefits for stress (though anxiety showed no effect). While methods appear strong, sample size is unknown and outcomes were mixed/unclear overall, so evidence is moderate rather than strong.

indications.summary: The evidence for Vitamin B2 (Riboflavin) in reducing stress is limited and mixed, based on one randomized, double-blind, placebo-controlled trial that reported some benefits in stress reduction and sleep quality but no significant effect on anxiety. The study utilized a dose of 100 mg for four weeks. Overall, the findings do not support a clear benefit for this indication.

studies.title: Topical riboflavin attenuates ultraviolet B- and ultraviolet A-induced immunosuppression in humans.
studies.notes: The study shows that topical riboflavin provides immune protection against UV-induced immunosuppression, indicating a beneficial outcome.
studies.evidence_tier_rationale: Single small human, split-site controlled trial using topical riboflavin showed protection against UV-induced immunosuppression measured by contact hypersensitivity (a surrogate immune function endpoint). While relevant to immune effects, it is localized/topical and does not demonstrate systemic immune fortification or clinical outcomes, so evidence is preliminary.

indications.summary: Current evidence on the use of vitamin B2 (riboflavin) for enhancing immune response is limited and primarily derived from a single study, which demonstrated that topical riboflavin can attenuate UV-induced immunosuppression in humans. No adverse effects were reported, but the overall evidence quality is low, and further research is needed to establish its efficacy and safety for this indication.

contraindications: Four patients discontinued due to adverse events related with deferiprone.
One mild fever documented in the <5 day storage group.
greater in-treatment pain and burning sensation
lower riboflavin status in smokers and COPD patients

studies.title: Niacin biological challenge: A paradigm to evaluate social concerns.
studies.notes: Participants in the niacin condition reported higher panic symptoms post-speech compared to the placebo group, indicating a harmful effect.
studies.evidence_tier_rationale: Randomized, placebo-controlled study in healthy students used niacin as a biological challenge and measured self-reported panic symptoms after a speech task. Although results suggest a harmful effect, the outcome is an induced, surrogate measure in a non-clinical population, not treatment or prevention of clinical panic attacks. Therefore evidence for the supplement–indication pairing is indirect/experimental rather than clinically targeted.

indications.summary: Current clinical evidence regarding the use of vitamin B3 (niacin) for anxiety is limited and indicates potential harm. A study reported that participants receiving 100 mg of niacin experienced increased panic symptoms compared to a placebo group. No studies have demonstrated a benefit for this indication.

studies.title: Effects of Extended-Release Niacin Added to Simvastatin/Ezetimibe on Glucose and Insulin Values in AIM-HIGH.
studies.notes: The study shows mixed effects on glycemia and an increased risk of impaired fasting glucose, indicating potential harm.
studies.evidence_tier_rationale: A large randomized controlled trial with prespecified glycemic analyses assessed fasting glucose/insulin under extended-release niacin versus placebo. Although glycemia was a secondary (not primary) outcome, it is clinically relevant. The study found niacin increased fasting glucose and insulin and raised the risk of impaired fasting glucose, indicating harm rather than benefit for high blood glucose.

indications.summary: The evidence regarding the use of vitamin B3 (niacin) for high blood sugar (impaired fasting glucose) is low quality, with a single study reporting mixed effects on glycemia and an increased risk of impaired fasting glucose. No consistent beneficial outcomes were observed, and potential harm was indicated. Typical doses were not consistently reported across studies.

studies.title: Serious Adverse Effects of Extended-release Niacin/Laropiprant: Results From the Heart Protection Study 2-Treatment of HDL to Reduce the Incidence of Vascular Events (HPS2-THRIVE) Trial.
studies.notes: The study found significant risks of serious adverse effects associated with niacin-laropiprant therapy, indicating harm.
studies.evidence_tier_rationale: Large, well-conducted randomized controlled trial (HPS2-THRIVE) showed increased risk of new-onset diabetes and worsened diabetes control with extended-release niacin/laropiprant. Glycemic outcomes were prespecified safety endpoints (not the primary cardiovascular endpoint), making them secondary but clinically relevant to high blood glucose. Use of a niacin–laropiprant combination slightly limits direct attribution to niacin alone, but the findings align with known niacin effects on glycemia.

indications.summary: Current evidence does not support the use of vitamin B3 (niacin) for high blood sugar or new-onset diabetes, as there are no studies demonstrating benefit. One trial reported significant risks of serious adverse effects associated with extended-release niacin-laropiprant therapy at a dose of 2000 mg daily. Overall, the evidence indicates potential harm rather than benefit for this indication.

studies.title: Postprandial effects of long-term niacin/laropiprant use on glucose and lipid metabolism and on cardiovascular risk in patients with polycystic ovary syndrome.
studies.notes: The study found that niacin/laropiprant had a significant negative impact on postprandial glucose and did not improve postprandial hypertriglyceridaemia.
studies.evidence_tier_rationale: This is a double-blind randomized placebo-controlled trial in PCOS women over 12 weeks assessing glucose metabolism (postprandial glucose AUC, HOMA-IR), outcomes directly relevant to high blood glucose, and it found harm. However, the sample size was very small (n≈25 total) and the intervention was niacin combined with laropiprant, which may limit generalizability to niacin alone. Thus the study provides moderate human evidence for this indication.

studies.title: Effect of Extended-Release Niacin/Laropiprant Combination on Plasma Adiponectin and Insulin Resistance in Chinese Patients with Dyslipidaemia.
studies.notes: The study showed significant increases in glucose and insulin resistance despite increased adiponectin levels, indicating mixed outcomes.
studies.evidence_tier_rationale: Single-arm, uncontrolled clinical trial (N=121) of ER niacin combined with laropiprant measured fasting glucose and insulin resistance over 12 weeks. Outcomes directly relate to high blood glucose but lack a control group and use a combination product in dyslipidemic (not specifically hyperglycemic) patients, making the evidence preliminary despite significant changes observed.

indications.summary: The evidence regarding the use of niacin for high blood sugar in Type 2 Diabetes is limited and of low quality. One study indicated potential harm, showing that niacin/laropiprant negatively impacted postprandial glucose levels, while another study reported mixed outcomes with increased glucose and insulin resistance despite elevated adiponectin levels. Typical doses reported include 1 g and 2 g of extended-release niacin/laropiprant daily, but overall findings do not support a beneficial effect on blood sugar control.

studies.title: Extended-release niacin increases anti-apolipoprotein A-I antibodies that block the antioxidant effect of high-density lipoprotein-cholesterol: the EXPLORE clinical trial.
studies.notes: The study shows an increase in HDL-C but no improvement in antioxidant capacity, indicating mixed outcomes regarding cardiovascular risk reduction.
studies.evidence_tier_rationale: Small randomized controlled trial (n≈21) of extended-release niacin showed an increase in HDL-C over 12 weeks, directly relevant to the indication of low HDL. However, HDL improvement was a secondary outcome, the trial was small, and overall findings were mixed due to lack of improved antioxidant capacity and emergence of anti–ApoA-I antibodies. Thus, moderate but limited human evidence for raising HDL in this study.

indications.summary: The evidence regarding the use of vitamin B3 (niacin) for high cholesterol is mixed and unclear, with one clinical trial indicating an increase in HDL-C but no corresponding improvement in antioxidant capacity, suggesting potential limitations in cardiovascular risk reduction. No studies reported consistent benefits, and there are no established dose ranges for this indication. Overall, the quality of evidence is low, and further research is needed to clarify its efficacy.

studies.title: Effects of extended-release niacin/laropiprant on correlations between apolipoprotein B, LDL-cholesterol and non-HDL-cholesterol in patients with type 2 diabetes.
studies.notes: The study shows that niacin treatment improved correlations between lipid levels, suggesting a potential benefit in reducing coronary risk.
studies.evidence_tier_rationale: Large, double-blind RCT in humans, but the primary/assessed endpoint was change in correlations between apoB and LDL-C/non-HDL-C rather than LDL reduction itself. The use of a combination product (extended‑release niacin with laropiprant) further limits direct applicability to niacin alone. Thus, evidence for treating high LDL from this study is indirect and not focused on the indication.

studies.title: Niacin Therapy Increases High-Density Lipoprotein Particles and Total Cholesterol Efflux Capacity But Not ABCA1-Specific Cholesterol Efflux in Statin-Treated Subjects.
studies.notes: The study shows mixed results regarding the effectiveness of niacin in improving HDL metrics, indicating potential limitations in its atheroprotective effects.
studies.evidence_tier_rationale: Human RCT but designed to assess HDL particle metrics and cholesterol efflux in statin-treated subjects. The indication here is high LDL, and the study did not evaluate niacin’s LDL-lowering effect as a primary or meaningful secondary outcome; LDL changes for the niacin arm are not reported in the abstract. Thus, it is not actual evidence for this indication.

studies.title: Effects of niacin, statin, and fenofibrate on circulating proprotein convertase subtilisin/kexin type 9 levels in patients with dyslipidemia.
studies.notes: Niacin therapy was shown to decrease PCSK9 levels, indicating a beneficial effect on lipid parameters.
studies.evidence_tier_rationale: Human randomized studies included niacin (mostly in combination with statins) but assessed PCSK9 as the primary outcome, a surrogate mechanistic marker rather than LDL-C as a primary clinical endpoint. While PCSK9 reductions were observed and correlated with LDL-C changes, direct, primary evidence of LDL lowering from niacin within this trial is indirect and secondary, and includes combination therapy rather than niacin monotherapy.

studies.title: Effect of Extended-Release Niacin on High-Density Lipoprotein (HDL) Functionality, Lipoprotein Metabolism, and Mediators of Vascular Inflammation in Statin-Treated Patients.
studies.notes: The study shows varied effects on HDL functionality and LDL quality, indicating mixed outcomes despite HDL-C increase.
studies.evidence_tier_rationale: Double-blind, randomized, placebo-controlled crossover RCT in statin-treated patients showed a significant reduction in LDL-C with extended-release niacin/laropiprant. However, the sample size was small (n=27), LDL lowering was not the primary endpoint, and the formulation included laropiprant, so the evidence for niacin specifically for high LDL is moderate rather than strong.

studies.title: Extended-release niacin/laropiprant significantly improves lipid levels in type 2 diabetes mellitus irrespective of baseline glycemic control.
studies.notes: The study shows significant lipid improvements but also indicates potential worsening of diabetes control.
studies.evidence_tier_rationale: Double-blind randomized controlled trial (n≈796) showed significant improvements in LDL-C and other lipids with extended-release niacin (with laropiprant) versus placebo over 12–36 weeks. Lipid change is a primary/major outcome for the indication of high LDL. Slight downgrades to confidence due to use of a combination product (laropiprant) and post hoc subgroup framing, though laropiprant is not expected to affect lipid outcomes. Adverse glycemic effects were noted but do not reduce the strength of evidence for LDL lowering.

studies.title: Effects of extended-release niacin on the postprandial metabolism of Lp(a) and ApoB-100-containing lipoproteins in statin-treated men with type 2 diabetes mellitus.
studies.notes: The study shows significant decreases in plasma Lp(a) and apoB-100-containing lipoproteins, indicating a beneficial effect on lipid profiles in the studied population.
studies.evidence_tier_rationale: Single small randomized crossover trial (n=11) of extended-release niacin in statin-treated men with type 2 diabetes showed significant reductions in LDL-C and apoB-containing lipoproteins. While it is an RCT, the sample is very small, short-term, and focused primarily on kinetic/mechanistic lipid endpoints in a specific population, making LDL reduction a clinically relevant but secondary outcome. Thus, moderate human evidence for high LDL, with limited generalizability.

indications.summary: The evidence for niacin in lowering high LDL cholesterol is mixed, with four studies indicating benefit and three showing unclear results regarding its effectiveness. Typical doses reported include 1 g to 2 g of extended-release niacin daily. Notably, some studies suggest potential adverse effects on diabetes control, highlighting the need for caution in specific populations.

studies.title: Lowering of lipoprotein(a) level under niacin treatment is dependent on apolipoprotein(a) phenotype.
studies.notes: The study shows a significant reduction in lipoprotein(a) levels with niacin treatment, indicating a benefit for cardiovascular risk management.
studies.evidence_tier_rationale: Single small, prospective open-label, uncontrolled human study (n=30 men) assessing ER niacin’s effect on Lp(a). The primary outcome (Lp[a] level) is directly relevant to the indication but is a surrogate marker. Benefits were observed only in the low–molecular weight apo(a) subgroup. Lack of randomization/blinding/control and small sample size limit evidential strength.

studies.title: Detrimental effects of niacin/laropiprant on microvascular reactivity and red cell deformability in patients with elevated lipoprotein(a) levels.
studies.notes: The study found detrimental effects on microvascular reactivity and red cell deformability, indicating harm associated with niacin treatment.
studies.evidence_tier_rationale: Single-arm, small human interventional study (n=46) without a control group measured pre–post changes. Lp(a) reduction (~32%) is a surrogate outcome and not clearly the primary endpoint (study focused on microvascular outcomes). Use of niacin with laropiprant reduces directness to niacin alone. Thus, evidence for niacin lowering high Lp(a) from this study is preliminary.

indications.summary: The evidence regarding vitamin B3 (niacin) for lowering high lipoprotein(a) levels is limited and mixed. One study reported a significant reduction in lipoprotein(a) levels with extended-release niacin at a dose of 500 mg daily for 24 weeks, suggesting a potential benefit. However, another study indicated harmful effects on microvascular reactivity and red cell deformability associated with niacin treatment, highlighting safety concerns. Overall, the quality of evidence is low.

studies.title: Extended-Release Niacin/Laropiprant Improves Overall Efficacy of Postprandial Reverse Cholesterol Transport.
studies.notes: The study shows that ERN/LRPT significantly reduces postprandial hypertriglyceridemia and improves cholesterol transport, indicating a beneficial effect.
studies.evidence_tier_rationale: Small, uncontrolled, before–after human trial (n=10) using extended‑release niacin/laropiprant on statin background. It showed a significant reduction in postprandial triglyceride AUC (−53%), but outcomes were surrogate (postprandial TG and RCT function), not fasting TG or clinical endpoints. No control group and small sample size make the evidence preliminary.

studies.title: Effect of extended-release niacin on cardiovascular events and kidney function in chronic kidney disease: a post hoc analysis of the AIM-HIGH trial.
studies.notes: The study showed improved lipid profiles but no improvement in cardiovascular outcomes or kidney function, with an increase in all-cause mortality.
studies.evidence_tier_rationale: Randomized, placebo-controlled trial (AIM-HIGH) with a post hoc CKD subgroup reported significant triglyceride reductions with extended-release niacin versus placebo over ~3 years. However, triglyceride change was a secondary endpoint and this was a subgroup analysis of a trial powered for cardiovascular events, not hypertriglyceridemia. Additionally, increased all-cause mortality in the niacin arm tempers interpretation. Overall, moderate human evidence for lowering triglycerides in this context.

studies.title: Effect of niacin on triglyceride-rich lipoprotein apolipoprotein B-48 kinetics in statin-treated patients with type 2 diabetes.
studies.notes: The study shows that ER niacin reduces apoB-48 concentration and may provide cardiovascular disease risk benefit, indicating a positive outcome.
studies.evidence_tier_rationale: Small randomized cross-over trial (n=12) in statin-treated men with type 2 diabetes focused primarily on apoB-48 kinetics (a surrogate). It showed reduced apoB-48 and lower postprandial triglyceride AUC with ER niacin over 12 weeks, but did not report clear changes in fasting triglycerides (the typical target for high triglycerides). The study is mechanistic with surrogate outcomes and limited size, providing preliminary human evidence for the indication.

studies.title: Effects of niacin and omega-3 fatty acids on the apolipoproteins in overweight patients with elevated triglycerides and reduced HDL cholesterol.
studies.notes: The study shows that ERN produced a beneficial reduction in plasma apoB, indicating a positive health outcome.
studies.evidence_tier_rationale: Randomized controlled trial in patients with elevated triglycerides, but the primary outcomes were surrogate lipid markers (apolipoproteins, apoC3 glycosylation) rather than triglyceride levels. While niacin showed beneficial changes (e.g., reduced apoB), the study provides indirect, exploratory evidence for the high triglycerides indication and has a small sample size.

studies.title: Effects of immediate-release niacin and dietary fatty acids on acute insulin and lipid status in individuals with metabolic syndrome.
studies.notes: The study shows mixed effects on postprandial insulin and lipid levels, indicating both increases and decreases depending on the type of dietary fat.
studies.evidence_tier_rationale: Small, single-dose crossover study focused on postprandial triglyceride responses to different dietary fat types with niacin co-administered in all arms. There was no no-niacin control and no assessment of chronic triglyceride lowering. Outcomes were mixed and context-dependent, so this does not test niacin for the indication of treating high triglycerides.

indications.summary: The evidence for vitamin B3 (niacin) in reducing high triglycerides is mixed. Three studies indicate a benefit, particularly with extended-release formulations at doses of 1-2 g daily, while two studies present unclear outcomes regarding cardiovascular benefits and mortality. No studies reported harm, but the mixed results highlight the need for caution in interpreting the overall efficacy of niacin for this indication.

studies.title: Niacin induces miR-502-3p expression which impairs insulin sensitivity in human adipocytes.
studies.notes: The study found that niacin treatment decreased insulin sensitivity, indicating a harmful effect.
studies.evidence_tier_rationale: Small double-blind RCT (n=22) over 8 weeks found niacin decreased insulin sensitivity, indicating potential harm. However, the study’s primary focus was mechanistic (microRNA changes), and it did not directly measure or target high insulin as a primary clinical outcome. Insulin sensitivity is a surrogate for hyperinsulinemia, making the evidence indirect and preliminary for the specific indication of high insulin.

indications.summary: Current evidence regarding the use of vitamin B3 (niacin) for improving insulin resistance is limited and indicates potential harm. A study found that niacin treatment decreased insulin sensitivity in human adipocytes, suggesting a negative effect. No studies reported a benefit or mixed outcomes for this indication.

studies.title: Remarkable quantitative and qualitative differences in HDL after niacin or fenofibrate therapy in type 2 diabetic patients.
studies.notes: The study shows mixed results regarding HDL changes and does not indicate clear benefits or harms.
studies.evidence_tier_rationale: Randomized crossover trial (n=30) in type 2 diabetic patients with low HDL tested niacin (with laropiprant) as add-on to statin for 12 weeks with HDL as a primary outcome. Niacin+laropiprant significantly increased HDL-C, though qualitative HDL changes were mixed. Small sample, short duration, add-on and combination therapy reduce strength and generalizability, yielding moderate human evidence for this indication.

indications.summary: The evidence regarding the effect of Vitamin B3 (Niacin) on increasing HDL cholesterol is mixed and unclear, as indicated by a single study that reported variable outcomes without demonstrating clear benefits or harms. No consistent dose ranges were reported across the studies, and overall, the findings do not support a definitive conclusion about its efficacy for this indication.

studies.title: Short-term effects of extended-release niacin with and without the addition of laropiprant on endothelial function in individuals with low HDL-C: a randomized, controlled crossover trial.
studies.notes: The study shows that short-term niacin treatment might improve endothelial function, indicating a benefit.
studies.evidence_tier_rationale: Randomized controlled crossover trial with a very small sample (n=18) and short duration (7 days per period). The primary outcome was endothelial function assessed by flow-mediated dilation, a surrogate rather than a clinical endpoint. While results suggested benefit, the small size, brief exposure, and surrogate measure place this as preliminary human evidence.

indications.summary: One randomized controlled trial reported that short-term treatment with extended-release niacin (1 g daily) may improve endothelial function in individuals with low HDL-C. However, the evidence is limited to a single study, and further research is needed to confirm these findings and assess long-term effects and safety.

studies.title: Fenofibrate and extended-release niacin improve the endothelial protective effects of HDL in patients with metabolic syndrome.
studies.notes: The study shows that both fenofibrate and ER niacin improved HDL function, indicating a beneficial effect on endothelial health in patients with metabolic syndrome.
studies.evidence_tier_rationale: Randomized cross-over study (n=37) with ER niacin showed improvements in ex vivo HDL-mediated endothelial effects (eNOS/NO, VCAM-1) after 6 weeks, but did not assess in vivo endothelial function (e.g., FMD) or clinical outcomes. Small, short, open-label design with mechanistic, indirect endpoints supports very low/indirect evidence for endothelial function.

indications.summary: One randomized trial indicates that extended-release niacin may improve endothelial health by enhancing HDL function in patients with metabolic syndrome. However, the evidence is limited to a single study, and further research is needed to confirm these findings and assess long-term effects and safety.

studies.title: Effects of Vascular and Nonvascular Adverse Events and of Extended-Release Niacin With Laropiprant on Health and Healthcare Costs.
studies.notes: The study found that niacin-laropiprant did not significantly reduce major vascular events and was associated with increased hospital costs and decreased quality of life.
studies.evidence_tier_rationale: This is a large randomized controlled trial dataset (HPS2-THRIVE; n=25,673) testing extended-release niacin 2 g/day with laropiprant versus placebo on top of statins. However, this specific paper’s primary outcomes are quality-adjusted life years and hospital costs, making its relevance to the indication of cardiac risk indirect/secondary. It notes no significant reduction in major vascular events and increased adverse events, aligning with harm/no benefit for cardiac outcomes, but the study’s focal endpoints are economic and HRQoL rather than cardiac risk as a primary outcome.

indications.summary: Current evidence regarding the use of vitamin B3 (niacin) for improving quality of life in individuals with cardiovascular events is lacking, with a notable study indicating that extended-release niacin with laropiprant (2 g daily for 4 years) did not reduce major vascular events and was associated with increased healthcare costs and decreased quality of life. No studies have demonstrated a benefit for this indication, and one study reported harm.

studies.title: Niacin modulates macrophage polarization in Parkinson's disease.
studies.notes: The study suggests that low dose niacin may improve quality of life and modulate inflammation in Parkinson's disease.
studies.evidence_tier_rationale: Single small human clinical study with primarily mechanistic outcomes (macrophage polarization) and exploratory quality-of-life improvements; likely open-label/uncontrolled rather than a well-powered RCT. Indicates preliminary benefit but not robust, controlled evidence for Parkinson’s disease.

indications.summary: Current evidence on the use of vitamin B3 (niacin) for improving quality of life in Parkinson's disease is limited and primarily based on a single study, which suggests a potential benefit at lower doses. However, due to the low quantity and quality of available research, further studies are needed to confirm these findings and assess safety and efficacy.

studies.title: Improvement in inner retinal function in glaucoma with nicotinamide (vitamin B3) supplementation: A crossover randomized clinical trial.
studies.notes: The study shows a significant improvement in inner retinal function with nicotinamide supplementation compared to placebo.
studies.evidence_tier_rationale: Double-masked crossover RCT (n=57) in glaucoma showed significant improvements in ERG-based inner retinal function (PhNR), with only a trend for visual field improvement. Primary outcomes were surrogate electrophysiologic measures rather than clinical endpoints; study was short and had no washout, limiting interpretability. Thus, preliminary human evidence based on surrogate outcomes.

indications.summary: One randomized clinical trial reported a significant improvement in inner retinal function in patients with glaucoma following supplementation with nicotinamide (vitamin B3) at doses of 1.5 g and 3.0 g daily for 6 weeks compared to placebo. Overall, the evidence is limited to a single study with no reported adverse effects or mixed outcomes, indicating a need for further research to confirm these findings.

contraindications: Higher risk of coronary disease related death in placebo group
Increased risk for acute coronary syndrome in placebo group
aspartate aminotransferase increased in niacin group
higher all-cause mortality in ERN group
increased incidence of disturbances in diabetes control
increased risk of developing impaired fasting glucose
increased risk of hip fractures with high and low niacin intake
increased risk of serious adverse events
increased serious adverse events associated with bleeding
increased serious adverse events associated with gastrointestinal system
increased serious adverse events associated with infection
increased serious adverse events associated with musculoskeletal system
increased serious adverse events associated with skin
requirement for intensification of antihyperglycemic medication
trend toward increased development of new-onset diabetes

studies.title: Pantethine, a derivative of vitamin B5, favorably alters total, LDL and non-HDL cholesterol in low to moderate cardiovascular risk subjects eligible for statin therapy: a triple-blinded placebo and diet-controlled investigation.
studies.notes: The study shows a significant decrease in cholesterol levels, indicating a benefit from pantethine treatment.
studies.evidence_tier_rationale: The study is a small, triple-blinded, placebo-controlled RCT showing significant LDL reductions, but it tested pantethine (a derivative of vitamin B5), not pantothenic acid itself. This makes the evidence indirect for the specified supplement. Sample size (n=32) is also limited. Thus, for pantothenic acid and high LDL, this provides very low/indirect human evidence despite positive findings for pantethine.

indications.summary: One randomized trial demonstrated that pantethine, a derivative of vitamin B5, significantly reduced total, LDL, and non-HDL cholesterol levels in subjects at low to moderate cardiovascular risk. The doses used in this study were 600 mg and 900 mg daily for 8 weeks. Overall evidence is limited to this single study, and further research is needed to confirm these findings and assess long-term safety and efficacy.

studies.title: A Randomized Control Trial of Dexketoprofen/Vitamin B (Thiamine, Pyridoxine and Cyanocobalamin) Fixed-Dose Combination in Post-Traumatic Grade I-II Cervical Sprains.
studies.notes: The study demonstrated a statistically significant reduction in pain intensity and a better safety profile with the fixed-dose combination compared to monotherapy.
studies.evidence_tier_rationale: The study is a well-designed RCT with clinically relevant pain outcomes in acute cervical sprain, but the intervention is a fixed-dose combination of dexketoprofen plus vitamins B1, B6, and B12 versus dexketoprofen alone. Because pyridoxine was not isolated and was co-administered with other vitamins and an NSAID, the effect cannot be attributed to vitamin B6 specifically. Thus, evidence for B6 itself in musculoskeletal pain is indirect/very low despite positive results for the combination.

indications.summary: One randomized controlled trial reported a benefit of a fixed-dose combination of dexketoprofen and vitamin B6 (50 mg every 8 hours for 7 days) in reducing pain intensity in patients with post-traumatic grade I-II cervical sprains. No studies reported mixed outcomes or harm, but evidence is limited to a single trial, indicating a need for further research to confirm these findings.

studies.title: Folic acid, pyridoxine, and cyanocobalamin combination treatment and age-related macular degeneration in women: the Women's Antioxidant and Folic Acid Cardiovascular Study.
studies.notes: The study shows a significant reduction in the incidence of AMD with the combination treatment, indicating a benefit.
studies.evidence_tier_rationale: Although a large, well-designed RCT showed reduced AMD incidence, vitamin B6 was administered only in combination with folic acid and vitamin B12. The benefit cannot be attributed to B6 alone, making the evidence for B6 specifically indirect.

indications.summary: There is limited evidence suggesting that vitamin B6, in combination with folic acid and cyanocobalamin, may reduce the incidence of age-related macular degeneration, as indicated by one study that reported a significant benefit with a daily dose of 50 mg for 7.3 years. However, the overall evidence is sparse, and further research is needed to confirm these findings and assess long-term safety and efficacy.

studies.title: High-dose Vitamin B6 supplementation reduces anxiety and strengthens visual surround suppression.
studies.notes: Vitamin B6 supplementation was associated with reduced anxiety and a trend towards reduced depression, indicating a beneficial outcome.
studies.evidence_tier_rationale: This was a double-blind RCT showing reduced self-reported anxiety with high-dose vitamin B6, but it did not measure stress or perceived stress; clinical outcomes targeted anxiety/depression. Thus, for the indication 'stress,' the evidence is indirect despite a strong study design.

studies.title: Effect of magnesium and vitamin B6 supplementation on mental health and quality of life in stressed healthy adults: Post-hoc analysis of a randomised controlled trial.
studies.notes: The study shows significant improvement in mental health outcomes with the combination of magnesium and vitamin B6.
studies.evidence_tier_rationale: This is a human randomized controlled trial in highly stressed adults showing greater stress reduction with magnesium plus vitamin B6 versus magnesium alone, implying an added benefit from B6. However, B6 was tested only as an adjunct to magnesium (not monotherapy), and the reported mental health analyses are post-hoc. Details on sample size and blinding are not provided here. Thus, it supports moderate human evidence for vitamin B6’s effect on stress, but not at the strongest level.

indications.summary: Current evidence from two randomized controlled trials suggests that Vitamin B6 supplementation may reduce anxiety, with one study indicating benefits from high-dose Vitamin B6 for one month and another showing improvements with a daily dose of 30 mg in combination with magnesium over eight weeks. However, the overall evidence is limited, and further research is needed to confirm these findings and establish optimal dosing and long-term safety.

studies.title: Folic Acid, Vitamin B6, and Vitamin B12 in Combination and Age-Related Cataract in a Randomized Trial of Women.
studies.notes: The study found no significant effect on cataract incidence but suggested an increased risk of cataract extraction.
studies.evidence_tier_rationale: Large, well-conducted RCT with cataract outcomes, but the intervention combined folic acid, vitamin B6, and vitamin B12, so effects cannot be attributed to vitamin B6 alone. Results showed no reduction in cataract incidence and a possible increase in cataract extraction, making the evidence indirect and not specific to pyridoxine.

indications.summary: The evidence regarding Vitamin B6 (Pyridoxine) for the prevention of cataracts is low quality, with a single randomized trial indicating mixed results. This study reported no significant effect on cataract incidence but suggested a potential increased risk of cataract extraction with a daily dose of 50 mg over 7.3 years. Overall, the findings do not support a clear benefit for this indication.

studies.title: Vitamin B6 Supplementation Reduces Symptoms of Depression in College Women Taking Oral Contraceptives: A Randomized, Double-Blind Crossover Trial.
studies.notes: Vitamin B6 supplementation significantly reduced depression symptoms as measured by BDI-II scores.
studies.evidence_tier_rationale: Randomized, double-blind, crossover RCT showing benefit on a primary clinical outcome (BDI-II depression scores) in women using oral contraceptives. However, the study appears short (4-week periods), likely small in size, and restricted to a specific subgroup, limiting generalizability and strength; thus moderate rather than strong human evidence.

studies.title: Supplementation with vitamin B6 reduces side effects in Cambodian women using oral contraception.
studies.notes: The study shows that Vitamin B6 supplementation leads to a reduction in reported side effects, indicating a beneficial outcome.
studies.evidence_tier_rationale: Indirect, low-quality human evidence for depression. The study assessed self-reported 'depression' as a contraceptive side effect in Cambodian women using oral contraceptives, not clinical depression as a primary indication, and lacked placebo/blinding and clear randomization. Although large and controlled, outcomes were not validated depression measures and applicability to general depression is limited.

indications.summary: Two randomized trials suggest that Vitamin B6 supplementation may reduce symptoms of depression, particularly in specific populations such as college women taking oral contraceptives. Doses reported include 100 mg daily for a duration of 4 weeks. Overall, the evidence indicates a potential benefit, but further research is needed to confirm these findings across broader populations and to assess long-term effects and safety.

studies.title: Effects of combined lipoic acid and pyridoxine on albuminuria, advanced glycation end-products, and blood pressure in diabetic nephropathy.
studies.notes: The study shows significant improvements in albuminuria and oxidative stress markers, indicating a benefit from the intervention.
studies.evidence_tier_rationale: Small randomized placebo-controlled trial (n=34) in diabetic nephropathy showed reduced albuminuria and oxidative stress, but pyridoxine was given in combination with alpha-lipoic acid, making attribution to vitamin B6 alone unclear. Outcomes were short-term and largely surrogate (albuminuria, biomarkers), and study duration was only 12 weeks. Relevant to CKD but evidence for B6 specifically is indirect.

indications.summary: One randomized trial reported that a daily dose of 80 mg of vitamin B6 (pyridoxine) for 12 weeks resulted in significant improvements in albuminuria and oxidative stress markers in patients with diabetic nephropathy, indicating a potential benefit. However, the overall evidence is limited, with only one study available, and further research is needed to confirm these findings and assess long-term effects and safety.

studies.title: Effects of Vitamin B6 (Pyridoxine) and a B Complex Preparation on Dreaming and Sleep.
studies.notes: Vitamin B6 improved dream recall but did not significantly affect other sleep-related variables; the B complex preparation had negative effects on sleep quality.
studies.evidence_tier_rationale: Randomized, double-blind, placebo-controlled RCT (n≈100) directly tested vitamin B6 for dream recall and found a significant increase in amount of dream content recalled over five nights.
